Waiters and greeters in the restaurant were the most friendly staff in the hotel.Valet parking only, which although I can understand that they need to do this to compete with the best I would have liked a self parking facility also.Would stay again, but would prefer to try elsewhere first.

The beds were incredibly comfortable The hotel itself was beautiful and every inch was immaculate. I was out on a frenetic tour with a band and I always have difficulty getting any rest under those circumstances, but the beds were unbelievably comfortable! I slept like a baby and I got the same comments from just about everyone in the entourage.  The showers were fantastic and the service was excellent. I highly reccomend this hotel if you are looking to treat yourself or somone else to a special luxurious time.

Another amazing Sofitel Love Sofitels, they always get it right. Great rooms, so comfortable and clean, beautiful features. Great staff. The hotels restaurant and bar are full of life and atmosphere. Always feel right at home, the location was fine. Directly over the road from The Beverly Centre and Cedars Sinai. A short stroll down the road to lots of nice restaurants and WeHo clubs. The pool area was nice, disappointingly small pool but it was adequate. (get there early as there aren't many deck chairs)Complimentary internet use in business centre was good. Such helpful staff. Was not impressed when I bokked in at 7pm and my room was not ready, but after expressing my dissatisfaction, had a room available immediately.

The star treatment in L.A Our stay at The Sofitel was a beautiful, luxurious one! After they had accidentally lost our web booking they made up for it by upgrading our room. The service was great and the hotel itself superb.Our room and bathroom was a good size with a huge shower and a view looking out onto the hollywood hills. The room was modern and stylish! The hotel was also conveniently located, across the road was the Beverley shopping centre with every luxury store you could think of, as well as being walking distance to a few popular streets.The hotel restaurant was fantastic, with lovely decor and great food. There was also a very popular and equally lovely decorated bar/lounge which we enjoyed visiting. For those wanting a day spa experience there was a beautiful day spa located just outside, but affiliated with, the hotel.All in all it was a great stay and one we are sure to recommend to others. The only draw back was the cost for parking and having to tip the valets every time you needed you car, but hey, its LA!

Best bed in the world! We stayed in a deluxe room, with a view of the Hollywood sign. The room was spacious enough for a city hotel, with a very large bathroom. The walk-in shower could easily have accomodated 3 people and what's more, with a flick of a switch you could watch the TV in the bedroom through the window!The best thing about the room by far was the bed! Large and very comfortable due to the feather filled mattress topper, duvet and pillows (all hypo-allergenic so no sneezing!), I have not slept in a nicer bed anywhere.The hotel staff were very attentive and the concierge was excellent. The valet parking always had the car ready in no time at all, and in Formula 1 style, 5 guys would be opening doors for you!The bar was very cool and on certain nights impossible to get into, unless of course you were either the owner of a Lambourghini...or a hotel resident!The location, in West Hollywood, was perfect for seeing the main sights of LA and nowhere was more than a half an hour's drive away.I highly recommend this hotel, especially if you are looking for a little luxury. If you think it is expensive for what you get, then you clearly should be staying in a Travel Inn!
Great Location        Hotel Room

pretty close to perfect I had fallen in love with the Sofitel in Chicago so I was curious to see how the one in L.A. stacked up and once again I was blown away.The management and staff were extremely accomodating and helpful, room service was quick (get Simon's junk food selection with cotton candy and cupcakes and order in a movie one night), the pool was the warmest heated pool I had ever gone swimming in, the architecture and design of the hotel, spa, restaurant and bar was beautiful, and we even had a celebrity spotting--Ice T!The hotel is right across the street from the Beverly Center so we had plenty of choices for shopping and restaurants but it's still quite a walk to Rodeo Drive and other hot spots.And don't let cab drivers scam you from LAX! It should only be $40 and we paid $71! That was the only time I gritted my teeth during our stay but that wasn't the hotel's fault it was our own and the shady cab driver's.A soak in their suite's hot tub though did the trick. If you get a suite, the huge bathroom has a tv by the tub and I took advantage of it every day. Such a wonderful experience, I hope to return soon.

Great location, not great room My husband and I spent 4 nights at this hotel. We booked this hotel based on reviews we have read. The location is great for shopping on Robertson - the trendy boutique street, also home of the celeb dining hot spot - Ivy. I was disappointed by the rooms, although the bathrooms were nice. The size of the room was too small. The bed was extremely comfortable, though. It took forever to get our rooms made up each day - at least 3 p.m. before we got daily housekeeping service, which is disapointing.Also disappointing is the distance of the pool and spa from the hotel rooms. It is a LONG walk, no matter what room you are in. We did not try out the bar or restaurant, though the decor was quite appealing.
Wonderful Bed!       View from hotel room

Great Choice for our young family We stayed 2 nights in a SoFabSuite on a Universal Studios stopover enroute to the UK. We're both 38 and we have an 11 month old and a 3 year old and needed a room large enough to comfortably fit us all without disturbing anyone trying to sleep. The Sofitel LA looked as though it fitted the bill and indeed did.At first we thought we'd been upgraded as the room was so nice (from memory the room was AU$330 per night-ish), large SAFE balcony, two large LCD/Plasma tv's, great bathroom and furnishings etc (you'll see on the website)Our 3yo slept like a princess in the feathery mass that the sofabed became over night. Our 11month old had a PROPER cot/crib (not a travel cot) and his own toiletries, which fitted nicely into a little dark alcove away from the 3 year old. All leaving us with a room (and to DH's joy, a large TV) to ourselves.Concierge (Hector  the Team) had organised our pickups to/from the LAX and Burbank prior to us arriving . Needing 2 carseats for the kids is an issue in California as taxis etc. don't provide them. We didn't want to hire a car and argue directions for 2 days on the wrong side of the road and AirShuttle transfers with 2 kids, associated luggage for a month RTW and stroller wasn't appealing either. They found a Limo service which could provide a babyseat at the least. DH and DD(3) enjoyed the sweets and drinks provided, and we all felt like we were doing the LA experience on the 35 minute ride to the hotel.We ate breakfast twice at SimonLA in the outside courtyard, which offered good choices for us all (inc. the baby) at what seemed like reasonable prices (before taxes, tipping etc). We also had room-service after our day at Universal, which was yummy and a had a child-friendly menu.The only thing against the hotel ais: it's location - there's really nothing other than the Beverley Centre nearby. Even finding cheap evening food choices for a family was difficult. We did eventually find a wonderful Thai cafe with the BEST egg-rolls we've ever had (and in Sydney Thai restaurants are a time a dozen). The Beverley Centre was good for a bit of quick shopping which was all we had time for in a 48h stopover which included Universal Studios.Getting to Universal on public transport was EASY and took less than an hour! We took the 25c bus right outside the hotel to Hollywood/Highland then 1 stop on the redline. The shuttle up the hill came quickly. The 25c bus took us through West Hollywood, up the strip etc so was a good little sightsee!The only other hotels we considered were the Hilton Universal (a Club room) and the Beverley Garland. Overall we feel that staying at Sofitel LA was a better choice for a such a short stay, we really felt like we were in LA!

Great service but not worth the price I stayed in a one bedroom suite a few weeks ago (May 2008). The service in the hotel is impeccable, they do try very hard to make you feel as if you are in a 5 star hotel. The suites, however, are not worth the exhorbitant price. Noise is a problem if you're sensitive to it. My first room was very pretty (with a deep tub), but there was a persistent (24 hours a day) humming noise rising from the fans at the restaurant below. I was moved to another suite without the tub, and for the same price, but no fan noise. The busses start roaring up La Cienega at about 6am, so I was not at my best for meetings all day. En suite dining is limited but pretty well prepared (nouvelle, not a lot on the plate, but well cooked.). There are better hotels for this price.

Overrated for the price The Sofitel Los Angeles is a nice hotel. The service staff are friendly and efficient and the hotel and rooms are very clean. In my opinion, the double-bed room was surprisingly small. I guess for the price per night, I expected it to be bigger. I am a Sofitel rewards member; however, they neglected to provide me with the membership benefits even though my rewards status was clearly provided on the reservation. The bedroom windows open out to a main street and the Beverly Center is directly across the street, so great shopping is close. I didn't like the fact that the window looks like it has a balcony, but it doesn't, and one misstep could land you on your face in the street below. There's a Rande Gerber bar/lounge in the lobby that is frequented by the young and beautiful Los Angelenos. If you stay at the hotel you cross the velvet rope hassle-free. They also have a really nice restaurant with an outdoor patio which is perfect for brunch. Overall, the hotel was nice. Definitely not the best hotel I've stayed in, but certainly not the worst - just pricey. If it had cost less, my review would be more positive.
Great value A great location I think that the comments about noise are unfair but would advise that you ask them at check in. The bed was incredibly comfy, the room OK.

Great place to stay in a great country loved it :) The Sofitel Los Angeles was great.The location was perfect right opposite The Beverly Centre for all your shopping needs under one roof. The hotel is very clean and tidy and all the staff were there to help you in any way possible. The rooms were always kept clean and there was never a shortage of towels. I must say i have never slept as well as i did in their beds they were to die for!!! The Valet car parking service was really good as you only had to make one call and the car was parked outside ready to go on a short journey to Santa Monica and Malibu. Overall it was fantastic and couldn't fault it at all well done to everyone who made my stay fantastic

Welcome Luxury A very professional service extended throughout the hotel. We arrived late after a delayed flight and it was a relief to check into such a luxurious room with delightfully comfy beds!Breakfast was superb with the waiter actually amending the order for a cheaper option - whilst I still received what I had ordered!The concierge was very helpful and nothing was too much trouble when it came to getting directions and just locating certain shops.

Good but not great ! The screened off drinks terrace gives the exterior a bit of an unfinished look.Thats the front wall.Our room on the back had the hills view and that Hollwood sign in the distance,and the unfortunate school yard below.To compensate the noise double glazing should be in place of the strange opening french doors windows.The staff are good,but an upgrade was denied against my expensive Accor Favorite Guest loyalty card.Thats OK,except that the two of us and four bags and a room service trolley were more than our little triangular room space could hold.The shower was large but we chose not to eat in there.Exceptionally good air condition unit.LED bed lights,and some other toys,but where's the space and quiet?The bar and restaurant are fab designs,the locals know how to party,dont go looking for any quiet corners here.You pay for the style too.I did not see any good near by restaurants , I should have asked the friendly concierge.The fastest check out in the West.I would stay in another district , if I return .

A Modern Gem in L.A.! I just attended a work meeting at the Sofitel in L.A. Let me start by saying that I live in L.A. all my life (37 years) and have seen many hotel both in L.A. and around the country. The Sofitel is a very modern, upscale hotel since the remodel. Everything from the lobby accents to the rooms are polished to a high sheen. Check in was easy as was check out. We used several meeting rooms while there and the catering service was outstanding. Food was top notch and the service always came with a smile. Actually, that theme spread throughout the hotel. I have to say I was not expecting a hotel in this area to have such a friendly, outgoing staff. Everyone who worked there greeted me as I walked by. They really made you feel welcome. We had over 50 people in town for our meetings from around the country and those I spoke to gave grand reviews. I think the location is very good. You have the Beverly Center just South for shopping and a lot of food and entertainment within walking distance. You're close enough to the Sunset Strip to jump a short cab ride to get there but far enough to stay away from it if you don't want to be right in the thick of Hollywood.It's L.A. so things are a little pricey but you do get the best. Room service was delicious. The bar/lounge is very cool. Wed night is the big night at the Stone Rose lounge. It gets BEYOND packed.The only note I would make if I returned would be to get a room on the South side of the hotel. There is a school as other reviewers have mentioned. It's located on the North side of the hotel where my room was. I had to be up early for meetings anyway but the noise from the school on weekday mornings could be an issue for anyone who wished to sleep in.A fantastic place with great customer service!

A great choice for limited shopping time We picked this hotel due to its location opposite the Beverly Centre after completing our travels and allowing for limited shopping time in LA before the trip home. The staff could not do enough for us despite only staying one evening and needing plenty of support regarding late checkout, baggage hold, etc. Our room was every bit as good as it looked on the web. Will definitely stay here next time. All staff were friendly and polite. The inhouse restaurant serves an awesome breakfast with many healthy and innovative choices at very reasonable prices and either indoor or outdoor dining options. Highly recommended.

Don't stay here I know this hotel has a great reputation - and the service was top notch and very professional, but this property is not that good. The biggest problem is the location - right next to a major hospital so that you'll be up all night with the sound of sirens on the street below. Maybe there are quieter rooms in the hotel? Also, the rooms are really small-ish and the beds not very comfortable. This place can be a bargain - especially since it is outside of Beverly Hills - but you get what you pay for. Would not recommend.
A wonderful stay at Sofitel Los Angeles       spacious walk-in closet with safe, bath robe and slippers

Fun, Stylish Hotel I have stayed at this hotel a few times while traveling on business to LA, most recently in Jan. 2008. I very much enjoyed my stays at the Softel LA and would welcome the opportunity to return. The rooms are stylishly decorated, the beds are as comfortable as they come, and the flatscreen TVs are a nice touch. The bathrooms are very modern and have large rainfall showers. The gym is well equiped compared to most hotel gyms. The staff was consistenly friendly and helpful. I had only good experiences at the restaurant and bar. The hotel is centrally located and convenient to the Beverly Center (right across the street), West Hollywood (a short walk or cab ride), Beverly Hills, and Hollywood, as well as many other parts of LA that tourists might find interesting.

Noisy and Dark I'd read all the great reviews on Tripadvisor before we went to the Los Angeles Sofitel in March this year and was excited about our visit, but found the reality didn't quite live up to its billing. It is a nice hotel, but the rooms on the mall side of the building are loud (no noise glass, french doors that didn't even close all the way) , small and not very special. The lobby is very dark and pretentious. The surrounding immediate area offers nothing except a mall, nothing of interest or charm is walkable from the hotel (I know it is LA, but still...). Though expensive, the restaurant does do a delicious breakfast. The concierge gave excellent directions and was very helpful in general. It wasn't a bad place, but it lacked charm, quiet and distinction. I would not stay there again.

Decent hotel, good service I only had a short stay in LA for business and decided to stay at the Sofitel as l had never stayed at this hotel previously. It is located directly across the road from Beverly Shopping Centre so it is definately a convenient location for some shopping. l believe there are other hotels in better locations(ie Santa Monica) with better views(the view from my room was basically the shopping centre). I stayed in an executive suite and the room was decent. It was slightly smaller than l expected..the suite photos shown on the internet show a larger lounge room however my lounge area was quite small. The balcony was overlooking the street and the Beverly Centre. The bedroom was large, clean, comfortable and nicely decorated. The bathrooms were decent sized with a tv above the bath - very nice. The room service was very prompt and the food was delicious. The staff are very professional and very eager to please - great service!I would not stay at this hotel again as l prefer to try new hotels in different locations however l would recommend it to others.

I'll be back!! We were overbooked by the Hyatt Regency Plaza and they put us in the Sofitel. It turned out to be a blessing in disguise as the Sofitel was perfect for our 1st trip to LA. The location couldnt be better as all the best West Hollywood shops were within a few minutes walk.... Melrose, Sunset and Hollywood Blvd etc. Santa Monica is 10 mins drive and the valet parking was seamless. The room was briliiant. Great bed with all the usual amenities and a superb view of downtown LA. A little strange that there was a window in the bathroom looking out into the sleeping area?? But this is LA right?? The food in the Simon LA restaurant was top class. Try the ahi tuna if you like that sort of thing!!

Great Service and Family Friendly I was traveling to Los Angeles for business and needed a place to stay with my family the night before a conference. I booked a hotel using hotwire and got the Hotel Sofitel. Upon arriving, I explained to the front desk that I had infant twin sons and that I needed a two cribs. The gentleman manning the desk informed me that the room I had been assigned would not accommodate the cribs, but that he would be happy to change my room. The room was gorgeous and had a large shower and a great view of the hills behind the hotel. The cribs arrived shortly after we made it to our room and came loaded with baby shampoos, lotions and powder. We made use of the valet parking $23 a night, and met some of the nicest valets ever. They even did the best job of loading our five bags and two strollers into the car that I have ever seen. I praised the front desk for the excellent service when I checked out.

Could be nicer! This is a very nicely decorated hotel with modern upgrades. It is a half hour walk to Rodeo Drive, and half hour taxi to Hollywood Blvd. It is next to CedarsSinai Hospital.The decor is amazing. The view of the Hollywood hills is mediocre. The shower is good.The bed is definitely four star--very comfortable.They really need to improve on:1. Their doors slam so even at 2am, some idiots will not close their door gently, you can be woken up by them. Considering how much I paid for this hotel, they really should get better hinges.2. The restaurant is good but not super. Everything seems to be full of salt... Not worth spending that kind of money there.3. The pool is no where to be found even though the signs point to it...

Overly SO-SO Sofitel Overrated and overpriced, the rooms are not extraordinary, but admittedly stylish and well-equipped, dimensions notwithstanding. The art is great, especially in the lobby. On weekend nights it seems to be a hopping place for Hollywood wannabes and other LA types. The morning-after breakfast/brunch scene in the restaurant was a hangover gone bad, with too loud music (DJ brunch? Obnoxious.), pretentious and pricey menu, and staff attitude. With so many hotel choices in this area, this one can be overlooked.

Goos times at the Sofitel Good staff. Attentive and sorted out a housekeeping oversight quickly and with a free breakfast. It was a bad oversight.Look/Feel. It's modern and refurbished. Like any hotel its worn but overall very nice. The beds are to die for. The shower heads (rain type) all need to be replaced due to shoddy manufacturing. They spray the roof causing bubbling paint and cold water to drip. Ask for the side with the view of the hills.The location is good. Easy to get cabs, away from the noise of the strip, close to the fun places you want to go.The Gerber Bar is cool. Would be fantastic in summer outside. Cody behind the bar is sweet and fun.We were three single guys with friends in LA. We found Sofitel to be just right. New, coolish, close w a good bar. We'll be back.
No individual treatment       Bath with TV

A great stay for LA shopping! This is a great hotel, right next to the Beverly Centre for shopping, and a few blocks from Melrose Ave (my preferred shopping area). We arrived late, checked-in swiftly and loved our comfy room and great view of the West Hollywood Hills. Has a great bar and outdoor patio area with canopy seating and an open fireplace. Great Sushi place on the same block as hotel that I can't now remember the name. Its on the corner of West 3rd Street and S La Cienega Blvd.Overall a lovely hotel with swift service and great amenities and location.

Absolutely loved this place! Apparently this place has recently undergone a refurb, and it looks great. We got a great internet rate on a basic level room. We requested a view of the Hollywood sign and got that too. From the moment we walked through the lobby, we knew this place would be great. The reception staff were great. And a special thank you to Claudia on the Concierge desk - her recommendations were spot on, could get us bookings at short notice for good restaurants, and was always happy to help us out.The room had a really comfortable bed, and modern appliances. It also had a great bathroom with one of those huge shower roses which had fantastic water pressure. The gym is also the best equipped I've seen at a hotel.A great stay!

Magnificent! This hotel lived up to all my expectations and exceeded most of them. The room was exquisite and nicely-appointed. The staff were friendly and courteous. Simon LA was wonderful and celebrity chef, Kerry Simon has designed the in-room dining selection.I definitely recommend this hotel for leisure or business.

Loved the Hyatt, stylish and functional Just returned from a long day at the Hyatt, and really loved it. I primarily chose it because of its location (across the street from where I was going), but from the second I pulled up to the entrance I was impressed with the service, style and functionality of the hotel.Staff was efficient and friendly in an understated sort of way. They generally left you alone (I think they primarily cater to people there on business), but were always friendly and provided useful advice. Yes, valet is $33 a day (there is self-park a 2 minute walk away for $20 each time you go in or out), but that is pretty typical for this kind of a location. The valet guys were helpful with local area advice, and they got my car super fast.I stayed in a Regency Club room and loved it. I actually don't know if the rooms are any different than normal rooms, but you get access to the Regency Club in the lobby that has free breakfast in the morning, drinks throughout the day, and appetizers in the evening. It also has free Wi-Fi access and 2 computers with a printer - very handy. It's a very functional room, affording a surprising amount of privacy for business conversations. I LOVED the room. I was on the 18th floor - not sure if this is a special Regency floor or not, but it was great. Very wide and stylishly appointed hallway that slightly curves so it feels smaller and more personable.I had an even numbered room, and those look out west towards the ocean and the sunset. Checked in around 3pm as the sun was starting to set, and the whole room was just washed in glorious sunlight. Great views towards the pool area and then all the way to Santa Monica. Had no trouble seeing Catalina, even though it wasn't a particularly clear day. Very expansive view. Loved the balcony, which they call the lanai. It is very large and has a carpet, feels very cozy.Room is huge, tons of space, everything very functional and fresh looking. Nice big plasma TV (which I didn't even turn on). Big, luxurious and modern bathroom. Only two complaints about the room are that (1) the water pressure in the sink (but not the shower) was very low, and (2) the mp3 attachment for the clock radio was crappy and there was interference when I tried to play my Zune.Very convenient location - there is a fancy open air mall a 5 minute walk away that has a ton of dining options, from food court to very fancy. UCLA, Beverly Hills, Hollywood - all are only minutes away.The pool area looked fabulous. I only got to relax out there for a little bit. It had that old-Europe beach club feel to it. Pool was seriously heated - I was there Dec 22 and people were swimming in it at 9pm. Also has a nice big outdoor Jacuzzi.Overall, I really loved everything about the hotel and will definitely be back.
Mixed feelings are unavoidable. Many ups but many downs       The bathroom

satisfactory Bid on a 3 Star hotel via Priceline for a LA vacation and ended up upgraded to the Hyatt ( 105.00 a nite!)The good: Great looking rooms and grounds-friendly enough staff-responsive.The bad: 33.00 a day to valet park! Ouch!! Location is OK for Beverly Hills tourists but less so if your events are more Hollywood or Downtown.Tips-stay away from the rooms facing Ave of Stars and the CAA offices-VERY noisy. However, if you do get put on that side feel free to piggyback on the CAA guest wi-fi network as oppsed to the 7.95 a day they charge at the Hyatt.

Impersonal but grows on you A functional hotel for the business community, it can easily make the tourist who is not dressed for the office or in a noisy group feel they are not in the right place. It seemed that any small talk by the reception staff would be a dismissible offence and even after five days there was no sign of our being recognised. This approach however may be preferred by others, the hotel being sited between the MGM tower and Fox studios. A report of a dud bulb in the bathroom was dealt with promptly and when we brought a bottle of wine into the room, glasses appeared without request.Once we persuaded the concierge that we really did not want to hire a car and pay the exorbitant hotel parking fees he was very helpful in showing us how to walk to Rodeo Drive (10-15minutes away) where you can get a 45 minute tour of the stars homes on a tram for a fraction of the cost of the coach tours that collect you from the hotel. Outside the hotel are regular buses to Santa Monica (cost 75cents), the Farmers Market ($1.25), and Hollywood ($1.25). The bus guide tells you to catch two buses to Hollywood but if you are willing to take a ten minute walk at the Hollywood end you save time and money.The garden; outside swimming pool and Jacuzzi are all one would expect of a good hotel but they need to sort out their catering facilities with e.g. the coffee shop run by Starbucks closing at 3.00pm. It feels like the management is dominated by accountants, but for all its faults, what the hotel did provide, was provided very well. By mixing what the hotel did well with the food hall And supermarket at Century Plaza shopping centre on the other side of the road our satisfaction with the hotel grew through our stay.St8sman Essex

Stylish Hotel, but Unfriendly Service We booked this hotel, after seeing the rooms and amenities on the website. There are good and bad with the hotel.The Good:- Stylish hotel. Modern decor and clean rooms. We were on the Regency Club floor and had a beautiful view of Los Angeles. It got noisy though, with the large buses that park outside of the hotel.- Drinks in the Lobby bar were good. The dessert was mediocre, but the service was good.- Fitness center is well equipped with plenty of cardio machines. If you are a Diamon member, it's free. Otherwise, it's a pricey $20/day.- Lobby is bustling and busy. Active area.- Westfield Mall is 2 blocks away - incredibly convenient.The Bad:- Service, Service, and more Service. The front desk reception was rude and cold. We asked for other options outside of the Regency Club, and they said there were none. We went to the Concierge and asked for other options, and they said there's no other options -- even though the sign outside of the Regency Club specifically says to see Concierge for other options. (This was Thanksgiving Day, and the Club was closed.)We asked the hostess at Breeze Restaurant if we can just have dessert, and her immediate answer was No. She just looked at us, and didn't offer any other option. All in all, it was a rude reception.- The Hyatt charged us for drinks and food that were delivered to our room, even though it was free for Diamond Club Members. We had to go to the front desk to remove the charges.- No car parking. There is valet, but they charge $31/day. (We parked next door, which is $20/day.)The next day, the staff was much friendlier. However, we've already had a foul experience.I recommend the hotel for location and decor, but not for service.

Great rooms! great redo of rooms and lovely pool area. We parked at mall across the street and worked out fine. Great mall with great restaurants. Nice location to in LA. no complaints but there is construction next door, which could get noisy in certain rooms I am sure.
Loved it!!!       Night view of LA from balcony

Great Hotel! I stayed at this hotel recently for a conference. It was my second time here. I love this hotel. The staff is super friendly and accommodating and the hotel itself is beautiful. The pool is nice and relaxing and the hotel is only about a 10 minute walk or so from Rodeo drive in Beverly Hills.
I LOVE THIS HOTEL       The Bathroom
Good Hyatt standard       Hyatt Regency Plaza facade

Car Park feel and soul My stay was as part of the hotel's reward scheme, so I've stayed in many of their hotels throughout the US and world. Whilst the rooms  facilties of this hotel look standard the reality is somewhat different. Much has been outsourced and is not integrated well for guests and is 'user-pay'.The fitness centre and spa, widely advertised by Hyatt, both in their hotel description and Concierge email service, is a completely seperate business and hotel guests are treated no differently from the general public. In fact you can't even transit the facility, the easiest way to the nearby mall and hotel grounds, as the spa staff actively 'police' the entrance and send you round the street. This is false advertising by Hyatt and they should be held to task. The gym which is good is a $15 charge per visit - $30 a day for our room. I consider that expensive.The pool has the landscaping of the local carpark, inadequate  poor pool service and again the cafe, which serves the best range of juices and food, is a seperate business and only takes cash , not charge. None of this is clearly explained and you are left to 'stumble' around finding things out for your self.Request for extra towels went unanswered 3 times, taking a trip to the ever-helpful front desk staff to resolve the issue. Worth pointing out that the service here is exemplary.Car parking is $27 per day, again amongst the total additional charges, adding to the daily bill as a car is a necessity for this location.No in-room coffee/tea means that the 'in-house' Starbucks is an additional charge.This is an expensive hotel, with poor service requiring many additional charges for the average stay - wouldn't stay here again as there are many options more worthy in the local area.

More dodgy mini bar charges Reception staff were nice at check-in. The room was comfortable and quiet with a decent view. Concierge was attentive and helpful.Housekeeping Dept. was poor, with no respect for privacy and mini bar items disappearing.This is unacceptable for a higher caliber hotel like the Hyatt. When I reported the incorrect charges to the front desk I was advised my account would be corrected, however when I subsiquently checked my credit card I was disappointed to see the charges were still there. I then took the time to write to Hyatt guest relations in mid Sept and am still awaiting a response nearly 1 month later. Disappointing how such a small thing can leave a sour taste!
Top Notch Quality and Service. Location Location       Exteiror

Excellant Hotel We stayed here for the final 3 nights of our round the world honeymoon.We were both a little aprehensive about our stay in LA. We need not have been! It turned out to be a fantastic hotel. The beds were by far the best that i have ever slept in! If you're staying at the Hyatt Century City you need a car! infact if you want explore LA properly you'll need a car, even if you're right in Hollywood. At least if you're staying in Century City you are midway between most places!Valet parking was $30 per entry which maybe a little steep but it was very efficient and we normally went out for the whole day so we only paid once per day.All in all an excellant stay and a great end to our honeymoon!

BEWARE: Houskeeping Staff Stole $30 from mini-bar and charged it my account! Reception staff was nice at check-in. The room was comfortable and quiet with a decent view. Room service was just fine.Housekeeping Dept. is another story. My company does not pay for tips. And since I don't think it's nice to make people do the work and not give them anything for it, I put the privacy sign up to let them know I didn't need my bed made, towels replaced. Because I didn't leave a tip, the housekeeping staff racked up almost $30 worth of mini-bar charges to my room as retribution. This is despicable for a higher caliber hotel like the Hyatt. Such employees should not be tolerated. Of course I reported this to the manager and suggested such staff be fired.

The More You Spend, The Less You Get... I have found my aforementioned title, The More You Spend, The Less You Get to be painfully true in my last week of travels.We stayed here on Thursday, September 4th. The hotel is very impressive. The lobby is beautiful, and the rooms are awesome (We stayed on the 18th floor). It is the little things that peeved me.Internet cost ya, no coffee make in your room, no business center, room service is highway robbery, in room items are highway robbery, and valet is a joke.People pay all this money to stay here and yet the most basic creature comforts are not included or cost a ridiculous price. I needed to use a computer with a printer to print Dodger tickets... I was sent down to the business center (After paying $10 bucks for internet in my room) and was charged $7 for using their internet for about 40 seconds, and printing three pages (my tickets). No one thought it would be nice to help a customer out. The concierge blew me off when I asked, and the front desk had no idea.If there is a lesson to be learned it is this. If you want to pay a lot of money to stay at a cool hotel that is fine. But don't expect nearly the same service, amenities you will get at a Holiday Inn or Comfort Inn. Sad this is the case, but hands down the smaller guy on the block offers a lot more for the buck then the big dog. For me and my girlfriend it is a lesson learned. Hope this guides you in the right direction.-Mike

nice hotel, ripoff extras This is a very nice hotel - there is no question about that. The elevators are very fast and rooms are comfortable. The lobby is nice and it's cool having a real Starbucks right in the hotel, though I though it odd that it was not open when we checked in at 4:00 p.m.However, I have to warn you that the Hyatt (and similar hotels) have designed ways to get as much money out of you from the moment you check in until the moment you leave. As others have mentioned, valet parking is $31. When you drive in, the sign says valet and grayed out are the words self park. In other words, they have removed that option from the front of the hotel. You can drive around the block and find the garage and park there at $10 a day but you will pay $10 each time you come and go (the hourly rate reverts to a daily rate after two hours). Anyway, the process is by design to get you to valet park and pay $31 (+ tips).Next, there is a hi-tech mini bar in the room but there are no prices on the snacks. If you pick up a bag of potato chips looking for the price, you might be charged for them because the minibar detects removal of an item and automatically bills your room for it. It says that on the glass door, but you might not notice that (as we didn't).I didn't get internet access, though I normally do. However, I'm sure they charge it. I wish organizations such as the Hyatt looked at their customers as customers rather than simply revenue sources. You can have such a wonderful stay in such a wonderful hotel but what sticks in your craw are the various scenarios where the hotel is seeking to take more of your money at outrageous rates compared to the rendered service.

Loved it!! We stayed at the Hyatt Regency only for one night unfortunately!!Our room was spacious, clean, with a fantastic lanai. The bed are superb! We never sleept so well in any other hotel before. We rent a car at Hertz and we picked it up just outside the hotel.

Bad attitude; I would not go here again. I have a really sour view of this hotel. We planned ONE YEAR in advance for a wedding. Here were the problems:- Repeatedly lost and mixed up reservations, up to the day of the event;- Were promised one year in advance pool view rooms for several of the wedding party. On check in, sorry, they have been booked;- A gouging attitude everywhere you go. Overnight parking $31 per night. Each visit to the gym $20. Note in room: If you require a personal coffee maker, please touch 0. Nice touch is require- The people we'd dealt with over the past year were all unavailble on arrival, leaving to a not my problem / sorry, I didn't do that attitude.For the money......

Highly Recommended Wonderful hotel, everything seems clean and new, rooms are spacious with carpeted terrace, only downside is the expensive valet parking ($ 31), if you don't mind walking 5-7 minutes, there is a public parking on East Century (parallel to Ave of Stars) for $ 16 weekdays and $ 10 on weekends

Cool Rooms, Great Pool, Fun Atmosphere The building's exterior is nothing to marvel at, but the interior certainly is! This place rocks. The room was spacious and well decorated. The lighting in the bathroom was perfect. The pool was very cool, and if you want to stay somewhere that will let you have easy access to Santa Monica, Westwood, and Beverly Hills, this hotel is a great place to stay. I did not find the parking fee ($31 a night) to be completely unreasonable, but I went in and out several times during my stay. The walls could be thicker, but that's true of many hotels. I would stay here again in a heartbeat, especially at the rate of $115 a night I secured on priceline. Beware that the gym costs $20 a day if you want to use it. Seems like the nicer the property, the more you get nickeled and dimed, but such is life.

Great Choice Stayed 3 nights for a family reunion - large rooms, contemporary decor  great service. Can't think of any misses during the stay. Starbucks on premesis was a nice option for a quick  inexpensive breakfast.

nice hotel, expensive valet parking Quite pricey even bid from priceline, very nice hotel and excellent service. Valet parking is way too expensive. Good location, next to westfield. Wake up at mid-night and hear next door guy's laughing, sound isolation needs improvement.

Not so great We booked the room in January 2008 for a stay in July 08. There are four of us. We booked a room with two double beds. We get there and everyone on line to check in was mad. The hotel staff kept apologizing to people. I knew I was in for something. They apparently booked all of the double bed rooms for some cheerleading competition that was going on at their hotel. Because they have a contract with them, they had to bump everyone even though we booked it in January. They told me they could give us a room with one king size bed and send up a cot. We are four adults! Three of us had to squeeze on one bed?? Not going to happen. So one of us slept on the cot, another on a chair and ottoman. They couldn't give us another cot because it was a fire hazard. They also explained to me that the hotel does not guarantee a bed type, the only guarantee a room type. I never heard of that before. Then, when we got to the room and there were no towels at all! Luckily, I was nosey and opened up the doors to a cabinet in the middle of the hallway and saw a bunch of towels. so we took them from there. Then the thick curtain that keeps the sun out was missing! Luckily we were on the side of the building that the sun sets on. They ended up comping us that entire night but still, that was wrong. They only comped us for the night AFTER we called to complain about the curtain.
Great Hotel       Pool

Hyatt Disappoints This Time This was my third stay at the Hyatt in the last year, and while I like the hotel , it disappointed me this time. It is extremely convenient to my firm's LA office which is why I've stayed there, but I think this time was the last.As has been mentioned before, the rooms are very nice: the finishes are high-end, with granite countertops and gorgeous flat screen TVs. The rooms have very nice balconies and no matter which way your room faces, it's nice to be able to sit outside. The beds are also very comfortable. However, all this is negated by bad housekeeping. My bathroom floor this time was covered in hair. Not just little stray hairs, but lots of long, black hair which was impossible to miss. I did not arrive until really late, so I just took a towel and wiped them up myself, which I immediately regretting doing. When I lifted the towel, it was clear that the floor had not been washed in a while. UGH. The next morning, as I was getting ready to take my shower, I looked for the first time at the towel rack in the tub area, and realized that both towels there were used. DOUBLE UGH. I called housekeeping and while they were up in a flash with clean towels, I was disgusted beyond belief. As I left for the day, I reported all of this to the front desk, and when I got back, there was a message from housekeeping apologizing - sort of. It said they were sorry *if* their housekeeping did not meet my standards. I am pretty sure this doesn't meet anyone's standards, and the if in the apology sounded hedgey to me. Anyway, I was leaving at 5 the next morning and did not have the time or inclination to pursue it further. Unfortunately, the worst was yet to come, when at 4:30 that next morning I tried to take a shower only to find that there was no hot water. I got a tepid shower, but my colleague could not even get tepid water on her floor. She reported it and the hotel accomodated her with a credit, but still - it was a lousy way to start a long travel day. In any case, the long and short of it is that I've had 2 nice stays at this hotel and 1 pretty bad one, so I am giving it an Average rating. Any hotel can be off on occasion, but the cleanliness issue probably pushes me to try the Intercontintal up the street next time.

Beautiful, but pricey The room was just absolutely breathtaking. We had a poolside view on the 10th floor that enabled a wonderful scope of LA, as well as, the sunset (not to be confused with Sunset Blvd.). The bed was amazingly comfortable. The flat screen TV and granite countertops on all the surfaces gave the room quite a luxurious feel. Our room did not include a bathrobe, coffeepot, or glassware. I think it's weird that the more you pay, the less amenities you get. I guess they make up for it in the furniture and environment. I do prefer a non-odorous, luxurious room without coffee over a malodorous room with hair on the bathroom countertops with a coffeepot that you would prefer to keep away from anyhow.
Great location       lobby area

Beautiful hotel, great stay Even though we only stayed one night out of our 9 day trip to California, I would say it was one of the more beautifully decorated ones. We wish we would have stayed here longer.The hotel lobby is breathtaking with the rich warm colors. There were many chairs, couches and places to hang out. My husband used the wireless internet here, while the kids and I chilled and watched on of the tv's. Our check in was great, we were able to check in at noon, when check in is normally 3pm!The parking is a pain, but what are you going to do, it's LA. We paid the $31 with in and out privilages. The valet service is very fast and friendly.The pool area is amazing. There is a covered lounge area with a bar. They have a fireplace they lite a night. The pool was an infinity edge pool, and the hot tub was large enough to fit 12. The tanning pools were really cool! They provide towels by the pool and it was open until 10pm, but we were there longer the night we stayed and no one told us to leave.Our room was on the 15th floor and faced the street with an office building and fountain across the street. This view was fine for us, the kids just liked sitting out on the balcony. The beds were very confortable, not too soft, like most hotels lately. The room was decorated very nicely and was confortable. We did not eat at the hotel after reading all the other review about how pricey it was. This hotel was very easy to get to from LAX and convenient enough to all the touristy things to do in LA.Overall, our stay was a pleasant one and we would most certainly stay again if in LA.

Not bad, not great Have you ever noticed, the higher the star ranking, the fewer the included services. This hotel is no exception. Parking is extra. Internet is extra. There are no coffee pots in the rooms. I'll give you a little secret---you can call and ask for one. It will come with 2 coffee pods and then you can buy more. For my $1000 3 night bill, I expect free coffee. I did not see a hair dryer in my room. Perhaps that is another appliance upon request. My room had a nice balcony and view overlooking the pool. The staff was helpful and pleasant. The mall is across the street and Rodeo drive appeared to be within walking distance on the map. Otherwise you will be driving to other destinations. All in all, not great, but not bad. I really prefer more value for my $$$$$.

Hyatt was great with some limitations Great hotel. Perfect location. Rooms recently updated with flat screen TV's and furnishings. Wired and wireless Internet for $9.95 a day. Must go to the Equinox behind the hotel for $20/day to work out. Valet parking was $31/day or a long walk to self park.

Great hotel This hotel was in a great location- close to Beverly Hills, UCLA, Santa Monica, etc. Self parking is a little far but $20 compared to $31 valet. Although, there are no in and out privileges. The outside of the hotel is not that spectacular but the rooms and hallways are almost comparable to a Grand Hyatt. Very nice and very clean. Each room has a balcony too. The ONLY downside was that I asked the front desk for a remote control (missing from the room) and never got one until I had to call again and the same happened when I asked for a toothbrush. Besides that, I would definitely stay here again.

Nice hotel, good location, good price This is a well located, nice hotel with friendly staff. The room we stayed in was large and modern. The location is central and the price is very reasonable. We were able to walk to and from the mall which has a movie theatre and some nice shopping. I would stay here again.

Valet parking disaster Room are great clean well appointed renovated.Valet parking is great for $31.00 a day. Let me be clear I don't mind the charge. Some people are so shocked that hotels charge for parking. The valet attendants are lazy. Let me explain how it works. You call down x 2500 for your car. The valets get the car We never had an issue with getting our car. The probem occurs when you drop it off. The Valets never come over to your car they make you get out in the middle of the driveway. They never seem to move the car. The other cars try to squeeze by . This causes traffic jams for other guests as there are 750 room. I can't prove but there ws a slight dent on the driver door of my rental. Luckily I had the rental ins otherwise they would have charged my cc until i contacted my insurance at home.
Great Hotel The staff was excellent and the rooms luxurious. It is a quick walk (yes walk) to the Century City mall and about a 15 min drive to UCLA, WeHo and Beverly Hills. It was a great stay.

Great hotel - you should stay here! You may wonder why you should stay in Century City. Firstly, it's a minute or two, literally, from Beverly Hills and it is convenient to Hollywood and Santa Monica. Secondly, it is a two minute walk (yes, I said walk, although you never walk when in LA) from a wonderful shopping mall. Finally, Century City provides you the luxury of Beverly Hills, the safety you need and proximity to major freeways.The rooms are beautiful and spacious 鈥?huge closets, deluxe bathrooms, really comfortable beds, state of the art technology. The staff jump to please you. Their answer is always yes, immediately. The gym and outdoor pool are excellent.I got this hotel on Priceline twice. I was thrilled to return to this magnificent place. You won鈥檛 be disappointed. Unless you want to pay $500 or more for a swanky Beverly Hills hotel, you should stay here.

Overpriced in the middle of nowhere First of all, unless you need to be in Century city, there is no reason to stay here. Far from everything, hardly any place of interest within walking distance. Check in went well. When we got to the room, there was a coffee maker on the floor right outside the door. The rooms do not have coffee makers, but you can ask for one. This one was however used, and the staff had forgotten to take it. Well into the room I found that the beds were double, not queens, and that does make a dfference (of 6 inches, to be exact!) when travelling with a husband and two children. The minibar has sensors that charge for every movement of its contents, so you can not use it to keep milk or yogurt for the children, for instance.Went down to the pool to find it in need of renovation (and cleaning!). The pool is not very large, considering the size of the hotel. There are some wading pools, but they were constantly used by ducks!! Good thing my children are past that age!The food at the restaurant was good, but somewhat overpriced. The coffee maker found outside the door when we arrived was still there 24 hours later! Called housekeeping and asked them to remove it, which took an extra couple of hours... Service was in general rather poor.

solid hotel in good location near Beverly Hills Arrived at LAX from Paris and needed a hotel for the night... fortunately my laptop had just enough power left in it to get me a room on Priceline at the Hyatt Regency Century Plaza for half the rack rate. I was impressed with the hotel upon arrival-- cool 60s architecture and glamorous lobby. My room felt huge compared to the small European hotel rooms I'd been staying in previously. I had a high floor with a nice view of LA. Balcony is a bonus. The whole hotel has a very 60s Watergate feel to it, which is cool in my book. Bathroom is spacious and well-appointed. My only complaint arises out of my treatment in the morning, when I went out to buy some drugstore items and planned on returning to the room to conduct some business before checking out at 11. I had put my suitcase in the car, and when I returned to the room at 9 AM the maids were busy cleaning the room. I told them that I had not checked out yet, and they were quite uppity with me, acting as though I had no right to be there and that I was disrupting their cleaning routine. It seemed to me that they were overly aggressive with me, and at the least, should have respected my right to return when I re-entered. Next time I'll make sure to keep the Do Not Disturb sign on the door until the last moment.

A terrible hotel! I stayed 6 nights at this hotel recently. It was one of the worst experiences I have had. The hotel is, at best, a 4 star hotel, although its prices suggest otherwise. Check-in (at 11.30am) was very slow, with only 2 personnel despite a queue of 10 people. I was then given a very small room. When I called the front desk to ask why, I was put on hold for 25 minutes. I was then told that there were in fact much larger rooms available, and I was moved to one of these rooms. I was not however told that the larger rooms were very warm as the air-conditioning units were small and old (I was helpfully told this by the engineering personnel later). It took 3 complaints for engineering to finally come and let me know that they could not do anything. Having already settled in by then, and with numerous meetings to attend, I reluctantly opted to stay in the room. Service throughout the hotel was uniformally slow, and it was clear that the hotel is under-staffed. At the outdoor areas of the lobby bar and the X-bar, it was not uncommon to wait 25 minutes before getting served; this is unacceptable by any standards. Breakfast was also mediocre and was certainly not commensurate with the prices charged. The door personnel generally tended to ignore people waiting for taxis unless it was brought to their attention that taxis were required. Most suprisingly, considering that this hotel is predominantly a business hotel, the business centre (which was basically a small shop offering limited facilities rather than a proper business centre) was only open limited hours on weekdays, half a day on Saturday and closed on Sunday. On the last day, I checked out at 12pm as required. Since my flight was only at midninght, I asked wheher it would be possible to have shower facilities provided before I left later in the evening (which is a common practice at good business hotels in various countries), but unsurprisingly I was told that they could not offer these facilities.I think that the hotel is a rip-off, and is definitely inadequate for the needs of business travellers. I will never stay here again.

Totally fine hotel I stayed at the Hyatt Regency Century Plaza for a week this past February. The lobby and main areas are very clean and well kept. We initially had a room on a lower floor but requested, and were promptly moved, to an upper floor facing the pool. I would not recommend the street side, as this faces a somewhat noisy main road with a view of the office building across the street. The room itself was a decent size and well maintained. The bath products were above average. The shower was fine, nothing special or bad. The staff at this hotel was very nice and helpful.The pool and hot tub area was very nice, and there were always plenty of clean towels on hand. The reflecting pools were cool, especially if you are into tanning.The location of this hotel is well situated for getting around L.A. You would definitely need a car, but I think this would be true for anywhere in this city. There is a decent shopping mall with a good grocery store on the lower level two blocks away. This is a good place to buy water and things that are priced much much higher at the hotel convenience store (which seemed to be closed fairly often anyhow).All in all, a fine, but not extraordinary, place to stay.

Good Place to Stay Stayed at the Hyatt Century Plaza on a weekend. We booked through Priceline and got a good rate. Hotel was really nice and clean and relatively close to local amenities. You are on the edge of Beverly Hills and not more than 20-30 minutes to most Hollywood/LA attractions. Don't know that I would pay the regular rate for this hotel which is about $300+ per night. We paid about 1/2 the regular rate on Priceline so it was worth it for that money. The bed was comfortable with a balcony, flat panel TV and was well appointed with nice finishes in the bath. Beautiful lobby and from what I understand, celebs occasionally meet there for business. Unfortunately, it was a little cool outside so we did not have occasion to utilize the pool or outdoor amenities. Valet parking is a little pricey at $30 per day but is convenient. They bring the car in and out and you just get out at the front. We stayed there on a weeked. Century City is a little bit of a business district so on the weekends its kind of a ghost town. However, there is a large mall right next door for shopping, eating, etc, which is open on the weekends. When we left on Monday morning, there was quite a bit of activity as business resumed. All in all, a good experience and for a discounted rate, I would stay again.

Pamper With Paper We stayed there the weekend of March 21/22. They now have automated check-in at a kiosk, which I found quite impersonal and unwelcoming.Our room was fine, yet they use paper cups in the baths and no other glasses are available in the room. On our second day, the maid threw away our papercups and did not replace them. Maybe she was mad because we had to call at 5pm since our room had not yet been cleaned.The towels are not the kind you would expect with this level of a hotel. No thick, plush stuff here, just serviceable K-Mart towels.We wanted to use the pool on Saturday, but all seats were filled. There was no shade anyway, so it wouldn't have mattered.Saturday night we had to wait a good 20 minutes for the valet line as they seemed quite understaffed. Valet parking is now $31 a night and self-parking is so inconvenient as not to be a choice.It's still a nice hotel, the rooms well-furnished except for the cups and towels. We did see a bill left by someone who had just checked out...they paid more than $25 a night than we did, so all is not bad!

Bed Bugs and a little Dirty We had a corner suite with a separate bedroom and wrap around balcony. The furnishings were well appointed and the bathroom was all marble, but the entire suite really needed a good cleaning and that doesn't include the housekeeper that just walked into the suite while I was undressing. I would have enjoyed this suite a little more if it hadn't been for the BED BUGS! Was really difficult to try and sleep. Also, you feel imprisoned on the property, it is difficult to just walk off the property the way it is situated and there is no self-park you must valet and that gets to be a little too much everytime you need to leave and have to wait for your car. I wish I could recommend this property, but I found it to be a real turn off!

A little slice of Hollywood Stayed for three nights in March in a Concierge room, view at the front of the hotel with Hollywood in one direction and Beverly Hills greenery in the other.Unspectacular and very crowded pool (with ducks in the smaller pool!) which was perfectly adequate for a couple of hours of sunshine but would not have kept me entertained for a week. However they were hosting a huge wedding on the first day, and then closed the pool for a film crew on the second day. This didnt matter to us as we were going to Universal, and they did make arrangements for guests to use a nearby hotel. Actually we quite liked coming downstairs on our first morning and finding a film set! Concierge facilities were good, with complimentary breakfast, snacks, internet etc. Rooms were lovely - very comfortable beds, nice furnishings, LCD TVs. Location about 10 mins drive from Rodeo Drive, 20-25 mins from Chinese Theatre. Note that the sushi restaurant, Breeze, doesn't do sushi on a Sunday, which caught us out. However, when we complained (as the regular menu was far from satisfactory - food was over seasoned and tepid) they refunded our meal. This was appreciated! Also, the general manager was absolutely charming and very helpful.

Not worth the money Valet Parking costs $30/day, Self Parking costs $20/day +long walk +stairs to the front deskCoffee maker and glasses are available only by request! All that is provided is tiny styrofoam.Rooms with double beds are tiny beds - not full or queen size

Nice hotel ... but you'll pay $$$ for it Overall, the hotel is very nice and has all the amenities of a 4-star hotel ... although the price per night the seemed a little high for what you got ... I guess you're paying for location. I stayed at the Century Plaza for a business trip, so I didn't pay out of my pocket or else I couldn't afford it.The hotel is located in a business section of Century City. There is a Westfield Mall right next door that offers a variety of eating options and shopping. I chose to eat there rather than hopping in a cab and venturing out somewhere.Pros: Comfy beds, modern decor, fairly large room, patios are nice, Starbucks onsite, huge flat screen TVs.Cons: No free exercise facility (need to pay $20 per day to use Equinox next door), very expensive onsite restaurants, no free Wi-Fi, noisy AC in room, a bit of a ride from LAX

Nice Hotel For Business Stayed here for business - attended a conference held at the hotel. The ballroom/converntion area of the hotel is pretty big and they seemed to service it well. Hotel was overbooked so I got upgraded to a suite on the top floor - level called Penthouse.Great, great views of the city and mountains in the distance. Room was nice but nothing extraordinary. Very roomy, alot of open space in the suite area and bedroom. I used the online concierge service to make special requests and received a confirmation letter of those requests being fulfilled when I checked in.Nice, large pool area - was closed off the day I was there for a private photshoot/commercial. Lobby is large and open with a starbucks, 2 bar areas and a restaurant. Had dinner in restaurant - food and service were good - but menu is limited. (have sushi bar too) Really nice outdoor area with firepit for drinks adjacent to pool - good for evening cocktails/appetizers.Overall, was fine for the purpose of a business trip but not sure if its an ideal location for a vacation with family/firends.

Good hotel This hotel is a nice 4 star property. The lobby area has the wow factor with a very cool, contemporary look. The room are all a decent size with lots and lots of granite in the bathroom. The room are clean and have all of the amenitiers you would expect from a four star hotel. All of the rooms have balconies which is a nice touch. I did not eat in the restaurant or frequent the bar because of the prices. In one word . . .REDICULOUS. Other than that I would recommend the hotel.

Very Nice Mid-Century Styled Hotel The Century Plaza Hotel in the Century City area of L.A. is a landmark hotel that has been home to some of Hollywood's glitz and glamour for decades. The hotel's sweeping arc design has set it apart from other hotels in the area and made it an easily recognizable icon for some time. This hotel has been the choice of presidents, stars, and general business travelers and tourists alike for quite some time. So booking at this property, one should understand that it was designed and built in the 60s. Rooms are of a typical size from that era ... not very big. The bathrooms, too, are on the smallish side when compared to today's hotels. It kind of irks me when I read reviews where people moan and groan about this ... as if this was a hotel that had been built to today's standards. In all, I found my room to be superb. It wasn't huge, but it did have a lounge chair, a desk/table with two chairs, and a king size bed. The bathroom is compact, but nicely updated and clean. The room's patio was carpeted with all-weather carpeting and had two patio chairs with seat cushions. A widescreen LCD TV was provided, as was an iPod docking station.The room's decor was quite nice. It hearkened back to the mid-century roots of this hotel without being kitschy or over-done. The room appeared to be well maintained and clean ... and my standards for cleanliness are high. The staff at the hotel are well-trained in taking care of their guests. Valets were prompt and courteous (and they didn't change my radio station or move my driver's seat, thankfully). The housekeeping staff was pleasant and efficient. The front desk staff were always friendly and professional ... making good eye contact and resolving issues.The issues we had were minor. We put some items of our own into the room's mini-bar fridge ... and then saw a placard stating that if you do so, your folio will be automatically charged for the items removed. I'm not quite sure how this high-tech fridge does that ... but it does ... and the charges did show up right away. We reported that to the front desk staff on our way to dinner that night and it was taken care of promptly and even with an apology (even though it was our mistake). I was disappointed that the room didn't have a DVD player, but I phoned the hotel's concierge service and asked if one could be provided. Absolutely! We'll have it brought up right away. And it was ... within 5 minutes ... all hooked up and ready to use for our entire stay. That's service. You will read in other reviews about the location. Some will like it, others will say it isn't in the heart of anything. We enjoyed it and found the shopping and dining nearby to be just fine. There are a couple great choices in Century City ... this hotel definitely being one of them. Enjoy your trip!

Wouldn't hesitate in staying here again We stayed here for 10 days late August /early September for our honeymoon. Researched the area for quite a while before booking it and im really glad that we chose this hotel. The room was fantastic, we had a view over the pool, the bed was comfy and the cleaners did a fantastic job. I loved the fact that there is a shopping center across the road which was great on a lunch time. It had Macys, bloomindales, victoria secrets and tiffanys to name a few. There is also a supermarket there which was ideal for buying magazines, water and snacks to have by the hotel pool. The pool area was nice and clean, although at the weekend they could have done with a few more sun chairs, on a week day there would only been a few people by the pool. I used the room phone once to call my mum and dad and tell them we had arrived ok and when we checked out i think they had charged us about thirty pounds for the pleaseure!! Thats the only gripe i have to be honest

OK - Just Don't Eat in the Restaurant We stayed there for 2 nights, and had 3 rooms for the 6 in our family. Here's the rundown:The good:1. We're from Illinois and the Fighting Illini were staying there for the Rose Bowl. You can't beat that when you're travelling with teen boys!2. The hotel has been redone, and it's really beautiful. The lobby, the grounds (were about to be finished when we were there), the rooms.3. Beds are great.4. Location is great if you want to be near Century City, or if you're driving all the time anyhow.5. I forgot to pack a pair of pants the day we left, and they were terrific about finding them and holding them until we returned later that day. This should be a matter of course for all hotels, but still their professionalism should be mentioned.6. The front desk help was generally very good.7. Free wi fi in the lobby.The bad:1. We foolishly had breakfast at the hotel, because we had a food and beverage credit as part of our rate. Service was beyond bad, and when we checked out about 1 hour later, they still hadn't charged the bill to our room. That took another hour of waiting, which made no sense at all.2. One of the rooms was boiling hot (it faced the setting sun, and when we checked in the drapes were open). Another room was freezing. Eventually this got straightened out, but it's not pleasant to check into a room that's unbearably warm.3. Location is lousy if you like to walk (other than to the mall or office buildings at Century City).4. No free wifi in the rooms.

Nice location, ok hotel The Hyatt Regency I would say is a 3.5 star hotel which is getting a little tired and this has also been recognised by Management as it is currently being revamped.The location:The hotel is located on Avenue of the Stars within 10 minute drive of Beverly Hills, West Hollywood and Santa Monica. It is also across the road from the Century Plaza mall owned by Westfield which had nice restaurants, foodcourt (upmarket), cinema, boutiques and department stores.The room:The rooms were old and tired, No coffee and tea making facilities were available. The ammenties were extremely limited and the bath was very low and old. The beds however were comfortable and the rooms were quiet. Good selection of TV channels.The food:The room service menu was very basic however the Starbucks in the hotel was a plus.Overall I would try somewhere else next time, not a bad experience I just think better can be found for the price.

I expected better service... ...but didn't get it. We were with an extremely large group of travelers so perhaps the staff was overwhelmed? My biggest complaints: - It took several calls and many hours to get the refrigerator we had requested in advance (it came at 1 am). - Housekeeping really shorted us on towels and toiletries and ignored our repeated requests to change the sheets. - Two different concierges were very condescending to me - Even though I did my Internet research and knew what I was talking about. - The valet service, which is really slow BTW, was at times so rude to us! Perhaps because our rental was a Ford minivan and not a BMW or Lexus. The noise from the construction site did not really bother me, but I certainly understand how it would disturb others and it did intrude on my peaceful lanai reading time. It looks like that building will be going up for a long while, FYI.Other than these problems, the rooms were very comfortable and the hotel decor is great. The location is fabulous, given the close proximity to Beverly Hills and the freeways. Also it's across the street from the fabulous Century City Westfield Mall, which has a really nice food court and great shops. Overall I enjoyed our stay, I just wish we had been treated a little better.

Good hotel/location but needs some improvement This hotel is now a Hyatt Regency although it's unlike most impeccable Hyatts. The hotel location is great as it is minutes from Beverly Hills and across the street from the Century City Shopping Center. The rooms have LCD TVs , the bed is comfortable and for the most part clean (sheets need to replaced, some are worn out). I had a room facing the back of the hotel with a view of the (very, very distant) ocean. I didn't rate this a 4 Star because the front desk staff is not very knowledgeable (didn't even know how to print out a folio!) and when you ask them for anything they just didn't know or had to always ask someone else for the answer. The Club room's continental breakfast is a joke (muffins and juice) so I wouldn't pay extra to include that in the stay and the staff is not very good about replinishing the food/drinks/plates/napkins. Often times I would go in the room to find only muffin crumbs and no plates. The bellmen and valet staff however were very efficient and consistent in providing good service. I think if they train the front staff and revamped the Club room the hotel would get higher marks.
ottimo!!!!   showReview(22162351, 'full');
Un s茅jour agr茅able   showReview(19974703, 'full');
eccellente   showReview(19405912, 'full');
Hotel bueno pero mala situaci贸n   showReview(16110539, 'full');

Godd location, affordable price, one bad surprise.. We were looking for an affordable place to stay in Boston and we got an amazing deal at the Best Western through a Travel Agency. For 130$/night, free parking and breakfast included, this 3-star hotel was more than what we expected.Check-in was very easy. Reception staff was very helpful. Manager was friendly. Breakfast was acceptable. Room was clean and of decent size. Bathroom was very clean.No complaints until the last morning when, right before checkout, we realized that we had shared the room with a mouse or some other rodent!!! A chocolate bar had small bite marks all over it as if some animal had tried to eat it through the wrapper!! As we were leaving anyway, we did not make a big fuss out of it. The employee at the reception made a note of it, and told us that they have had a rodent problem in the past!! It might just be bad luck. We might even go back to this hotel as the location and price are unbeatable. But we will definitely never leave any food or candies in our room again!

Way Out in Boston Best Western Terrace Inn, 1650 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, MA, USAStayed: Sep 2008, one night double room.Location: Actually on Mount Hood Road off Commonwealth Avenue, between Washington Street and Sutherland Street Boston MBTA Green Line B tram stops. The tram journey is roughly 40-50 mins from Park Street and Government Centre Downtown stations, so the hotel is not very handy for doing things in the centre of the city. There are few facilities near the hotel (The hotel staff said: one Thai, one Italian restaurant, a 7-11 shop and a pharmacy-cum-US mail office-we found them very near).The Hotel is more of a Motel, with three separate blocks: reception and two separate bedroom blocks, which have no covered ways between them, so if it is raining 鈥?There are steps to reception but there is access by ramp via dining area for wheel-chairs. Bedroom block 1xx (ground)-2xx has no lift to upper floor. Did not assess block with rooms 3xx-5xx. Being just off Commonwealth Avenue saves it from traffic noise, so it is quieter than one may anticipate. The room we had was plain, but very spacious and clean鈥攏o criticism of that.The welcome was pleasant and helpful but the 鈥楥ontinental breakfast鈥?was at the poorer end of the scale: cereals, yoghourt, fresh fruit, bread and rolls / bagels but no meats or cheeses. The fruit juices were really diluted fruit 鈥檇rinks鈥?rather than fresh or 100% reconstituted. The 鈥榗rockery鈥?is of the plasticised paper variety plus plastic 鈥榞lasses鈥?and polystyrene-foam tea/coffee containers (鈥榗ups鈥?. Similarly, the cutlery is plastic, with no large spoon.The hotel was willing to extend check-out time by one hour (to noon) and to safe-keep luggage after check-out until later in the day.Is this the Boston location or quality you want for $171 ($192 incl. taxes)?

Some very good points First of all, it was well situated for us. We took the tram/subway to visit downtown. We felt quite safe in the neighborhood where the hotel is situated.The hotel itself has been semi-renovated and is clean and acceptably furnished. We were pleasantly surprised by the breakfast, it's self-serve but they have eggs, waffles, cereal, fruit, and toast.We found the staff to be very courteous and pleasant. Also, there was an error in our reservation (our fault), but they were able to accommodate the dates change at no cost, which we very much appreciated. We found the rate a bit expensive at $184, but be aware that Boston is very expensive compared to other cities.

WOW! We found this hotel on Priceline, and we were looking for a Fenway weekend. The hotel was obvious, because it really is in the back of a gas station parking lot. Check-in at the front desk was super easy, and the front desk clerk was so friendly, helpful and polite! Check-in literally took less than 30 seconds, including when he asked if we wanted 1st or 2nd floor. The rooms are set up like they might be in warmer climates - instead of everything in one building, there were several groups of 2-story buildings with maybe 10 or so rooms in each group. There's parking on site (and it's FREE - a total luxury in Boston) and the whole time I felt safe, even parking my new car out there.The room was nothing special - not huge or anything, but it was absolutely spotless. Fridge, microwave, desk, wireless internet all right there. Even the bathroom didn't have one speck of mold or dirt. It's even environmentally friendly, with those signs you can leave out if you can handle using the towels and sheets more than once. We got directions to both walk to Fenway (it's about 1.5 miles) or take the train (T is about a 4 minute walk) and how to get back after a night of baseball and drinking. :) I would definitely stay at this hotel again, and recommend it to anyone who asked. It's in a quiet neighborhood, only a short distance to the T, and the price wasn't bad at all for Boston area. A+

Comfy and clean. Stayed with wife and 2 teenage kids for 5 nights. Paid about $175/night. Half a block from the Washington St T stop; Green Line. Free parking. Wireless. Pretty good breakfast. Very good service. Fritz ran the front desk and he was great. Rooms aren't very big but very clean. Location is very good and you can save a few bucks by using the T. No pool. They don't change towels or sheets unless you ask. Knowledgable staff and helpful. Recommended, especially given the prices in Boston. It's no great bargin but affordable. Some very good places to eat close by.

Pleasantly surprised I've been by this hotel many times, since I live in the area.I always thought it looked kind of sketchy, situated as it is, immediaely behind a gas station on Commonwealth Avenue (which could also be convenient too, I guess).But one night I got locked out of my apartment, and so needed a quick, easy, inexpensive place to stay. This place worked out great, and is fine if you are looking for a safe, clean, reasonably priced, no-frills option in Boston--which is hard to find!The room itself was larger and nicer than I expected--although the blaze orange bedspreads need to be updated.The price was fair--you could easily pay double the amount in downtown Boston.The location is in the Allston-Brighton neighborhood, just west of Kenmore Square and Fenway Park.
