No apologies from the staff - wonder if they are all well acquinted?We had booked two rooms - one was okay, a little scuffed here and there and some odd stains in the bathroom ... the other room's air conditioner was on the blink. Miserable. They offered us another room on a different floor, it was very small and quite dank smelling. Luckily, the air conditioner by some miracle got fixed in the original room. We also had weird unauthorized charges show up after check out. What used to be a charming offbeat hotel with small personal touches, now seems to need a good steam cleaning, higher wattage bulbs and maybe they will regain the clientele they had originally targeted and stave off the SWAT team visits.

Love the International House!! I stayed during the Voodoo Fest and the hotel was the best part of the visit! Great staff, lovely room, fun bar. Amy, the GM, was super. I look forward to staying again!!

Nice hotel, but their parking rates are outrageous I have stayed here many times, it is a very nice hotel. However, the last time I stayed here, they charged me $60/night for parking. I was told that they double (or more) the parking fee for SUVs and they would not change their policy. It was quite a disappointment. So, please be careful of their 'low' rates because they will really stick it to you on the parking.

Extremely nice upscale hotel in terrific location The good:Very tastefully decorated rooms with extremely comfortable bedsNicely remodeled bathrooms with 6' tubsExtremely well located --5-10 minute walk to French QuarterOn a quiet side street (see note below re:construction nearby)Very pleasant upscale bar in the lobby.Excellent attitude and helpfulness of staffVery high quality first class hotel.The bad:Rooms are quite smallGenerator noise in some rooms from construction next doorI just spent a week at the International House and enjoyed it immensely. The room was very nice, very well appointed, though small. Small bathroom with huge tub and all the usual upscale amenities you expect. Best of all, the staff is very friendly, welcoming and willing to do whatever it takes to make your stay pleasant. As I mentioned, there is generator noise from building remodeling next door. I thought it was just louder than normal room air conditioning, so it didn't bother me, but my son and his fiance in another part of the hotel objected. The hotel moved them to a huge penthouse suite at no extra charge. BTW I picked up a last minute deal on this hotel on hotels.com $69 a night, which was an incredible bargain considering my son reserved on their website and was paying $250 a night. The hotel is a few steps from canal street and about a 5 or 10 minute walk to the French Quarter. To help you locate it on a map, it is just down Camp Street, about half a block from the Sheraton. Loved the International House!

Call ahead My husband and I were stunned to be put in a small room with no windows and a creepy door in the ceiling above the bed. We had booked a deluxe king room. Luckily there was a room with two full-size beds available that we were able to move to. We would have preferred a king, of course, since that is what we booked. But had the hotel been fully booked, we would have spent our weekend in what felt like a jail cell with a door above the bed! If you book a room here, you need to call the hotel directly and be sure that you are not the unlucky people stuck in these rooms, which, in my opinion should not be used as guest rooms at all. Apparently there are 5 of them. There is nothing on the International House website or the third party websites that indicate that these rooms exist... plus there is no price difference.On a positive note, the staff was nice, the hotel was well located, and the lobby was beautiful.

The Best Hotel I've Ever Stayed In (Really!) We stayed here for 4 nights and loved it. The staff was extremely friendly and gave us directions and info on the street car system. They even told us where not to shop so we wouldn鈥檛 get ripped off. Also when we asked that a cab be called for us the next morning at 5:30 AM it was waiting for us when we got there! Never has a hotel followed up on a request of ours before.In response to other reviews the room was small in that it didn鈥檛 have a sitting area with couch/coffee table but there was plenty of room to move around. There was a closet and an armoire for your clothing. I didn鈥檛 find the room dark 鈥?the bathroom seemed dark but turns out there was a tiny intensity control on the light switch which we didn鈥檛 find until the last day. The bed was extremely comfortable and room was clean. The furniture was in good condition as well. The only drawback was the lack of a safe in the room. There were no issues with noise at all and the rooms next to us were occupied. I, personally, liked the d茅cor and ambiance in the lobby. We didn鈥檛 use the bar and the restaurant was not yet open. The gym was very small 鈥?1 treadmill, 1 elliptical and 2 bikes. I would not hesitate to stay here again.

Not at all worth it My partner and I stayed at the International House for 5 nights for Jazz Fest in 2007. It was an awful experience for the following reasons:1. The room was filthy, dark and depressing. In particular, the decor wasn't at all what you would expect for a boutique hotel. Even though it had been recently remodeled, everything looked really dated and worn. The carpet had tears in it. The furniture was dinged up. The linens looked like they came from a thrift shop. And, to boot, the room was dirty and smelled of smoke (even though it was a non-smoking room). Worst of all, there was almost no natural light in the room, which, when combined with the dreary decor, made it feel like a prison cell.2. The walls were paper thin. We could hear all the noise from the hallway, as if those making it were standing in our room. During Jazz Fest, people are coming and going at all times of the night. If you're trying to sleep, watch out, as you will hear all the drunken wails from those returning from the bars.3. The lobby, while very chic, is usually crowded with those patronizing the bar they have there. It is loud and smells of alcohol. I know it is New Orleans, and one should expect some of this...but, I would have liked a little peace in the hotel after a day of craziness outside. Hard to get given that lobby.4. Front desk staff wasn't particularly helpful. In fact, one of them was downright rude if you ever asked for advice. We tried to get them to tell us the best way to get to the Fairgrounds, and for recommendations on places to eat. You would have thought we were asking for their left arm. I think the issue is that they are under-staffed, and were stressed because they couldn't get people checked in in a timely fashion...much less answer their questions.5. Not the best location. You aren't in the French Quarter. You aren't far from it, but you do have to walk several blocks. In the hot sun, it wasn't always a pleasant experience to do the walking. There are many hotel options in the French Quarter; in the future, I would choose one of these. And, the neighborhood in which the International House is in still hasn't undergone post-Katrina refurbishment, so is pretty run down (unlike the French Quarter).6. Rates were exorbitantly high for what you get. All in all, we would definitely stay somewhere else next time.

Beware of Parking I went to visit a guest at the International House this past week and valet parked. When I left the room 30 mins. later, we were told it was $30.00. I spoke to the parking manager, the front desk and the hotel manager and was told the same thing. The hotel manager said they do not park visiting guests and therefore you are treated as if you'd checked into the hotel. This was an outrage and unbelievable. The hotel patron we were visiting was so humiliated, he paid for our parking being that it was a business visit and there were 2 of us in 2 different cars! It doesn't matter if you are staying over night or there for 5 minutes, you will pay the same rate of $30.00. The front desk personnel all the way to the manager were not the least bit accommodating or willing to see the ridiculousness of 30.00 for parking, that is more expensive at the Ritz Carlton, New Orleans premier hotel!Be careful of Parking

Perfect spot, gracious host and staff at The International House Hotel We had a very pleasant stay for a week at the International House Hotel in New Orleans. It was very convenient to the French quarter, CBD and the Warehouse district. Plus easy access to the Street Car. We booked a room for the weekend before Jazz Fest through the first weekend of Jazz Fest. Very nice bathroom, though the room was small , but very nicely appointed. No view. Quiet, very comfortable bed and lovely linen. This hotel has a most helpful staff. Available, knowledgeable but never intrusive. Great door men. A computer was available in the small comfortable and luxurious lobby. Charming bar that was very much a place to gather away from the hordes of tourist. My 93 year old exceptionally well traveled Mom thought it was a tad dark, but loved it none the less. Our only complaint was that there was no restaurant in the hotel, but I was told that a new one would be opening this fall. Not that we needed more food. Oh my! Great food nearby. We loved the art opening by a fine photographer of some works taken of a few of Nola's great musicians with complimentary wine served in the lobby one afternoon. Nice touch. We will be back again to this special hotel.

Good enough Stayed there at the rate of USD 79.37 - very good value for money. Normal-sized room, but the bathroom was pretty spacious. LOVED the oversized tub, the shower head though was a little shady. Not sure if it was lowflow or if the pressure was just weak, but I hated that shower head.Front Desk staff professional and friendly. Room was clean enough. Had a small gym and a nice bar. It was really really good value for money at that rate. I've stayed in USD 100 hotels that look like a dump. I recommend this place.
Great Location       Seating area in bar

Mixed bag This is NEARLY a really nice place to stay -- on the plus side, the room was very clean, nice quality linens, Aveda products in the bath, and a very attractive lobby. Also a fine location, quiet but easy walk to French Quarter or Warehouse district. But it is NOT anywhere near a luxury hotel as per their claim, at least in the standard rooms - our so-called Queen deluxe room was tiny, with a soft and lumpy double bed. I called to ask for another room, and was told that all the beds are the same. The upgrade to King would have cost another $100! (I'm not a large person, just don't like to roll into my husband in the middle of a sagging mattress). breakfast involved granola bars, a few apples and oranges, and terrible coffee. Shower only, no bathtub, no pool on premises, efficient but unenthused staff. Kind of disappointing all in all - it's such a fun city that you can easily get exhausted! -- it would be great to have a better room to relax in.

Loved the International House I was in town for the Essence Music Festival, but I now know I don't need a special reason to visit New Orleans. The room was great, the staff was courteous (really enjoyed chatting with the doorman, although I didn't get his name) and I now know where I'll be staying any time I'm in New Orleans.

Not Impressed Hotel is not for the business traveler. No desk in room, lighting is poor. There was a fire alarm, maybe its all the candels burning in the lobby, and a fire door closed off my room and no one could open it for almost two hours. Gave me three drink tickets for my inconvenience. No restaurant a minus. Coffee and fruit available, coffee is awful. My toilet ran every time it was flushed, call the desk numerous times, no one fixed it. Wasting water on their dime not mine.

Extremely Dissappointed Repeat Customer Stayed at International House pre-Katrina and it was FABULOUS. Stayed for 5 nights for a conference which included the last weekend of Jazz Fest 2008 and was down-right disgusted. Mod hotels (worth $359/night - yes, that's right, was Jazz Fest) should be impeccably clean- it was NOT. Tiles cracked in elevators and foyer, walls need painting, one handle missing on hotel's entry doors (for the whole week?), stains on carpets in the room, no minibar, etc, etc.... The first night I arrived, I got my own luggage out of the trunk of the cab (while the bellman with attitude watched me), then was given a room with no windows and a metal roof escape door in the ceiling. It rained and I got no sleep at all. The second night they moved me to LOFT 523 (sister property) across the street and put me in another dirty room over the bar. Again (although I am coming in at 1-2 AM), got no sleep due to people shouting at each other outside the bar all night! The third night, they moved me back to International House (after Jazz Fester's left) and I finally got some sleep. Friends stayed at Loew's - had great views, superclean rooms, great service, CHEAPER price. Pluses: the manager (although the rest of staff cannot make a decision without him), the bar drinks (although really slow in coming), ran into Tommy Lee at the bar and got a great photo with him. ROCK ON! but stay somewhere else.

Great! Would stay there again! I got a great deal on this hotel - $79 a night, so I gave it a try - why not! I was very impressed by the quality of the hotel, especially for the price I got. It is literally about a minute or two walk and you're in the heart of the French Quarter area - GREAT!As for not having a restaurant, that was not a problem for me. There are SOOOO many great places to eat and try in New Orleans, I would be very surprised that anyone would want to eat a meal in their hotel. You are in New Orleans - get out and experience the cuisine of New Orleans! There are more places to eat than we had time for, so there's plenty of new places to eat when we return.And, you are in the party capital of the U.S., so why would you want to spend your time in a hotel room? I was looking for something reasonable in price and decent enough to sleep in - I got a lot more, considering some of the places I've stayed at that price. It is very, very nice.
Fine International House's best asset is its location. Very central, but also off the main streets, so the rooms are relatively quiet. The big disadvantage is the lack of restaurant.

Nice Location, Cute Decor I stayed here for a business covention. The property is unique, cute and trendy. The rooms are little dark, but other than that it was a nice stay. It was centrally located so we could walk to everywhere we needed to get to. I would definitely stay here again on a return trip. Try Le Phare bar down the street, nice spot for drinks.

I'd stay there again. I called the hotel and got a rate of $119 (Plus $30 a night parking fee) for that price I would say the hotel was above average. I didn't have any problems checking in. The valet serviece was a little slow for the price, but its a busy street so you can't expect too much. The French Quarter is just a 10 minute walk and the Hotel is a safe and quieter neighborhood. The Queen Deluxe room was clean and modern, maybe a little small but ok for two people. The bathroom and shower and were nice, and we were restocked with aveda products everyday. The halls were very dark, and the room was somewhat dark too. The bathroom has a dimmer switch which we didn't find until the 2nd day, as the bathroom was getting darker and darker and darker...

Small modest rooms, neutral review The room was not ready for check in when I arrived around 12:30pm--I had specifically requested for this several days in advance and the response was confirmatory. I was relegated to freshen up in the lobby restroom before heading out. While I appreciate the personal messages welcoming me later on, the first impression is important. They were prompt about unclogging the shower drain. On that note, there is little/no water pressure in the shower.

Very satisfied I had to stay in New Orleans for 3 nights during a conference, held at the Sheraton, which is just 50 yards away on Canal St. The Sheraton was almost twice as expensive, so I decided for the this one, and I am happy with my choice. The room was clean and perfectly adequate. I asked for a quiet room and I got it. The lobby is very nice and it has a small but very lively and trendy bar which I never went to, but was clearly popular among a nice crowd every night. The hotel is 5-10 minutes away from the French Quarter and the service was friendly and cooperative. My room was not cleaned the last night I stayed but I didn't care that much. Overall a very good choice. The only problem is that Canal street has very poor dining options but, again, the French Quarter is very nearby.

Good location, largely unremarkable This is an unremarkable hotel that didn't really make an impression on me. The location is great -- just five minutes from the French Quarter. The room was all right, although there was some noise from the air conditioning, the large fan above the bed and the toilets/showers/baths being used by other guests. The bathroom lights were on the lowest setting possible which meant I had to have my own shower pretty much in the dark. Only once I'd left did a colleague point out that there was a small lever next to the bathroom light switch which you could use to control the lighting.

Perfect location, perfect staff My husband and I just took our first trip to New Orleans. Having read many of the reviews on this site, I decided to book the International House. It was the best decision I could have made. The hotel is located across the street from the French Quarter, and a short block to the St. Charles trolley. The hotel is very quiet, clean, and the staff was very knowledgeable. We berated the front desk with questions about restaurants, tours, and live music venues- they were spot on about everything. The only downside is that their breakfast consists of granola bars and cold coffee. I would stay there again on my next trip.

a fun and friendly change from the cookie cutter hotels If you are familiar with hotels in europe, this one compares with more perks and better service.The hotel was MOST accomodating. We booked a four night weekend (Thursday thru Monday) through a third party website. After reading reviews here, I began to be concerned, because we were traveling as three...my daughter, my husband and I, in viewing her chosen new university Loyola. I did not want to be cramped in a small room or disappointed as we showed off the city to our daughter. I emailed them our information and asking for a larger room if possible and they wrote right back. The hotel could not have been nicer. They confirmed we were in a large superior double. They even offered to arrange a car service to pick us up at the airport, as we were arriving late on a Thursday evening. We had already gone ahead and booked a service, which the hotel confirmed was very reputable when I asked them for a reference.We arrived at about 11PM on Thursday evening. What a comfort to have low lighting, luscious smelling candles in the foyer and friendly faces to greet us after a long day. A group of guests, gathered around the large ottoman in the foyer, listening to a young girl and her guitar, gestured for us to join them. We would have loved to, had we not wanted so very much to change, unpack and find a nice corner in the inviting bar, Loa, in the lobby to unwind.Check in was a breeze. The doorman/security/bell captain, had our bags out of the sedan and into the hands of a very polite, friendly and capable bell service man, who carried them to our room, before we could even give direction. Our doorman/security was a kind gentlemen, friendly and truly happy to share a chat. My husband spent most of the four mornings enjoying his coffee on the hotels front steps chatting with the doormen, as he waited for the girls to get ready!After changing, we wandered back to the lobby and the bar for a drink. We found a cozy calming niche and my daughter, my husband and I enjoyed a cocktail and a glass of soda before retiring.The room itself was very large, as hotels go. It was room 305. A nice touch to have jazz playing when we walked in, We only experienced that once before, in a little inn in Newport RI. It spoke volumes to us about the hotel and their respect for our arrival. The window to the bedroom sat above the archway entry to the hotel. The attached full bath was enormous. It rivaled my home master suite. I have new plans for my home bath now :) The bathroom had an expansive glass picture window with dramatic sweeping ceiling to floor curtains, Italian travertine tile and a extra large glass walled walkin shower.Yes the lighting is low in the room. But after a day in the heat and humidity of New Orleans or an evening in the noise and smoke of a french quarter jazz bistro, we always found it soothing to come home to.Breakfast is a gracious offering of coffee, teas, large bowls of fresh whole fruits (apples, oranges and bananas when we were there) and granola bars. This is served in an intimate room off the lobby, with a couch, two extremely comfortable settee chairs and a flat screeen TV. It was a nice place to meet people. One morning I shared some time with Ann, who was in New Orleans for her sons wedding that evening. Runnning into her again the next day we shared details of our experiences- her wedding, my college tour. This I cannot find in the larger hotel settings. Another morning we exchanged breakfast banter with a young man who had close ties to where we live, although he now lives in California. This room was nice, but it does close after breakfast is through, which is disappointing, because it was quite relaxing. Maybe cold teas later in the day for the road weary could be worked into the schedule?The front desk was always eager to help. They made recommendations and reservations for us for dinners and brunches. On the morning we left (catching a 6AM flight!) They cheerily placed a wake up call to our room at 3:30am as we requested, then called back at 4am to see if we needed assistance with our bags. They arranged our taxi the night before and made sure the driver was on time. It seems they work with him often.Our time away and my daughters intro to New Orleans was made so much more special by the hotel. The bar was a quiet place for all three of us to relax on Saturday at 5PM..The room was relatively empty at that time and we were able to capture great window seats, on the comfortable settee and chairs, for some good people watching, scotch sipping chatter and debreifing. We felt revived in no time. Yet another night, upon returning from a days activities, we found a huge party going on in the foyer/lobby! What fun! Even the New Orleans fire department was there, as only can happen in NOLA, in their trucks and uniforms to enjoy the fete! It turns out it was a thank you party for a fundaiser which had been held earlier in the year. We were honored to be able to be a part of it- Had we known we would have made a donation!Yes the noise on the street can be heard, as in any city. I have stayed in NYC often and did not expect otherwise here. The Omni across the street has speakers on the otuside of their building. Light blues can be heard very faintly throughout the night. To those who love having a soundtrack to life, this was bliss for me.The beds are extremely inviting and decadent. I had a hard time getting out of them. Plenty of towels everyday. Facility staff who honor the privacy signs. A large walkin closet for hanging garments and a very charming armoire for drawer items and a small TV.The hotel sits on a small side street one block from Canal and one block from the St Charles Trolley. Could not be more convenient for walking to Vieux Carre, the Riverwalk and the Casino.We truly enjoyed our stay and will book again, as we return often for the next four years of my daughters college experience! If you want to capture the true spirit of New Orleans, this is the place

Nice, but over-rated The good:Location was great. Room was spacious and nicely decorated.Bathroom was lovely - and huge.The bad:We waited an hour past check-in time (4 PM) for our room to be ready. The lobby was packed with other people waiting. No apology was offered.They vastly overestimate the luxury of the place. Lots of the amenities they advertised weren't there. Examples:- No minibar- No flowers in the room- No down comforters- No restaurant (closed for renovation)I didn't need any of those things, so I was relatively happy with the place. I thought it over-sold itself, though, and I agree with the reviewer who said it's trying to hard to be hip. It's a nice hotel - they should drop the pretension and work on the basics.

Great hotel Have stayed at The International House a couple of times. Great hotel, nice new orleans decor. I love that they swap out the sofa fabric depending on the season (white slip covers in the summer etc.).Our room had a moldy smell, so we asked for a different room and they were very accomodating. They have a nice little bar for a cocktail before your night out, and the location can't be beat. walk to the quarter and the marigny, or grab the trolley to take you uptown or to bayou st.john ( my fave). I would stay here again anytime.

Great hotel to stay in! I just came back from 3 days staying at this hotel, and I loved it because:+It was super clean+Staff was very friendly and helpful+It's a Non-Smoking hotel+Complimentary treats were very nice+Room was spacious, the bathroom had a gorgeous (read deep and big) bathtub!+Toiletries were Av*da brand+The lobby and bar are spectacular+The CD player in the room adds an extra nice touch, great music+it's SO close to EVERYTHING! we walked all over French Quarter and Warehouse districts.+The price was very reasonableTo keep in mind:~We did NOT bring our car, we knew it is a true nightmare to park in New Orleans, insanely expensive, and streets are one way and narrow. I am not sure the hotel has parking.~The entrance to the hotel has no ramp, but staff was very kind and helped with the stroller at all times. ~They don't have cribs (it艣 not a complaint, just keep it in mind)~At least in the room where we stayed ( in the 9th floor) the windows don't open, but there is a ceiling fan and ventilation/heater/ac.~Like in most hotels nowadays, they won't change your sheets unless you place a card (that they provide) on your bed.I can't really find anything bad to say about it! This hotel made our stay really comfortable.

Very good, but trying a bit too hard? Light, airy room, good design features, animated, pleasant staff and a great location a short walk (5 mins) from the Quarter, so far enough to escape the crowds and noise. Only complaint: tries to be too self-consciously hip, when it really doesn鈥檛 need to. Each evening the lobby lights are turned down and loud - and I mean loud 鈥?music is played. This is annoying in its own right 鈥?say if you鈥檙e asking the desk staff for directions or checking in 鈥?but also a bit dated 鈥?the effect is best described as 'New York boutique hotel late 90鈥檚'. Post-Katrina New Orleans is potentially much more interesting than that. IH should stick to what it does best; being a comfortable, interesting and welcoming hotel.

Very Accomodating I'm always on trip advisor but never write reviews, so here's my two cent! The hotel is chic and cozy, the bar downstairs brings a nice feel and the hotel music is like non-other. After booking with their sister hotel (Loft 523) for All-star Weekend, my friends and I were moved to IH becasue of plumbing problems in our room at the Lofts. Even though it was a little frustrating for me to convey to the hotel management that as a customer they needed to do anything and everything possible to accomodate for the incovenience me and my friends were experiencing, I'm glad they were able to provide us with a room considering almost all the hotels were at capacity for a great NBA event. PROs: We stayed in room 601! The staff was extremely nice and friendly. The location is great and far enough off canal to miss the noise and get some rest after coming in at 5am but close enough to walk to bourbon and the casino without worries. Located close to a secured atm (24 hour security officer in locked building ask front desk they'll direct you around the corner), liquor stores, restaurants, and a walgreens that came in handy due to airport restrictions which tossed all of my friends toiletries in the trash. Beds are pretty comfortable, the bathroom was newly remodeled although the sinks were built weird and the showers are huge for a hotel. Requests for towels, extra blankets, pillows were always delivered quickly. And they have a public computer downstairs to access the internet and wireless services throughout the hotel.CONs: The biggest problem we had was outlet plugs...normal hotels have more ourlets in the rooms rather than the bathroom but this hotel was reversed and frustrating when trying to charge your phone and put on make-up. Lighting is very dim in the rooms as well, the use of two lamps is not suffiecient but it was only a problem when dressing, with 5 females everyone cant be in the bathroom at once; but it was great at night, light can hurt a little when coming in late from bourbon street. The refrigerators do not cool and the mini freezer inside is worthless, but request a bucket of ice and you'll be great. I don't suggest keeping food inside, it might spoil. Overall my experience to New Orleans post-katrina was not bad at all. I've been to New Orleans plenty of times before katrina but this was the first post and its definitely worth visiting. The city is still rebuilding but the spirit is what makes New Orleans a great destination. And its not a bad option to choose International House as your hotel choice during that experience.

Style and Fashion is where its at International House is a hotel that is different than any place I have ever stayed at. I was in town in Febuary for Mardi Gras and I loved the hotel. I frequently visit New Orleans and International House is the hotel I always stay at and will always return to. When you walk into the hotel, the lobby is large with high ceilings and redish furniture. The front desk is fun and smart. They know everything about the city and they know your name. They always tell me hi when I walk by and always ask me how dinner was. I was checked in really fast and went to my room quickly as I wanted to get to the parade. My room was 508. It was large with a king size bed. It had a chandelier with a large full length mirror. I had lots of windows and a view of the city. The room was a New Orleans style but with a comtemporary twist. The hotel offers valet parking which is very convienent. There is a 24 hour fitness center and the Loa bar is hot. In the morning, the hotel serves coffee, herbal tea, gronola bars, and fruit. At night the lobby is candle lit and the music is changed to fun upbeat vibe. I will be back as I have been at International House several times. I have always been blown away by there style and fashion and they change things up from time to time so you never get bored.

Intimate Boutique Hotel that Never Disappoints I love this hotel, it's pretty much my customary lodging when I am in New Orleans (every 3-4 months or so). I was most recently there during Mardi Gras and the hotel handled the increase in foot traffic, chaos and revelry just wonderfully. I love the decor. The hotel is in a beautiful, historic building with a thoroughly stylish and modern interior. It's so unique and appealing. I also enjoy the bar - the drinks and decor. It would work in any large metro city. The front desk staff is young and they can be a little standoff-ish, but that doesn't bother me at all. The bellman, Jerry, is wonderful - he knows the town and knows just about everyone in it. He always remembers us when we return. The rooms can be a little small, but I typically am only in the rooms to sleep and get dressed. I try to always get a corner room which is a bit larger and has a nice seating area. While my room during Mardi Gras was not directly on Canal Street, it did face Canal Street and I heard a lot of the street noise. Again, though - what can you expect? It didn't bother me at all. I have had a similar room recently and was not bothered by noise whatsoever. I fully believe it was just the Mard Gras madness. The location is wonderful. It's in the CBD, but it's just a stone's throw from the Quarter (keep in mind I am someone who likes to walk). This is thoroughly a boutique hotel and may not be for some people. However, if you are looking for something stylish, ecletic, charming and not exorbitantly priced, this hotel will exceed every expectation.

Just Dreadful I stayed at this hotel for 5 nights. The experience I had at this hotel was absolutely awful and this opinion was shared by over a dozen other guests who were there for the same meeting. Myself and numerous others truly think the very stagnant uncirculated air in the hotel rooms made several people sick. The room I was given had no window--I don't mean no operable window, or no view, I mean no window, not even a window on to an internal ventilation shaft. There was no exhaust fan in the bathroom or any other type of fan in the room, as a result the air in the room never changed and remained dank and musty. Housekeeping service was a joke. They failed to service my room one day, even after I went to the front desk and politely asked them to have my room serviced. The hotel bills itself as this chic boutique sort of place, but you must get the very basics of hotel management in place first. I was at the hotel for a meeting of roughly 100 people, all occupying the hotel--we arrived on Sunday, by Tuesday, more than 10 people had moved to other local hotels. The only positive thing I can convey is that the front desk staff was polite and courteous to me, although not all guests shared the same good fortune. I am sure at one time this may have been a fine hotel, but I can not in good conscience recommend this hotel to anyone.

Average, very average We went to New Orleans on a business trip. The meeting was based at the International House. This is an OK place, not great. The rooms are small. I mean european small. No evening turn down service or fresh towels. The front desk is quite helpful and the location is good. There is nowhere to eat in the motel and you have to walk to the Sheraton or Hilton to find a place in the evening. Only one doorman who was getting kind of stressed with a bunch of people leaving on Sunday morning. The most obvious thing I would suggest is turn down the lobby music. When we checked in it was playing classic rock so loud that we could not hear the guy at the desk. If you get a good price it is ok to stay here but at the full price I am really kind of luke warm about the International House.

great little place, great location I was fortunate to tag along on a quick business trip with my husband this past weekend to New Orleans. We stayed at IHH for 2 nights. The hotel is lovely. Very posh, but very comfortable. The entire city of New Orleans is quite easy and comfortable. You can make the experience your own easily. The lobby is so beautiful and the Loa bar a great stopping point before and after dinner. The entire staff is so easy going and laid back but the atmosphere is so much more elegant!! We were upgraded to the Penthouse floor. Our room was not a PH suite, but was nice and comfortable. We had a balcony with seating - but was too cold and rainy to utilize. I am somewhat concerned with previous reviews that mention bad views from their rooms. This hotel is in the city. EVERY room will have a view of a brick wall or parking lot or alley or all these city fixtures. When in NYC - we almost always have a brick wall view - it's the city!! It was quiet on the 12th floor except for the after party that consumed the PH hallway on Sunday from 3:30 am until 6:45 am. When I called the front desk to ask them to please quiet down the neighbors, the young woman seemed somewhat taken aback by my request. However, within minutes we heard doors shut and more muffled voices than the squealing right outside our door. This is an OLD restored building. NOT very sound proof. For a light sleeper (like myself) this could possibly pose a problem. The hotel was clean and the staff very accomodating and helpful. Jason - you are great and so fun to talk with. Your knowledge of all the restaurants was in-valuable! There is NO restaruant at the hotel-which upset some-but there is NO LACK of places to eat in NO! Walk just feet in any direction and you can find great food. We walked EVERY where. It was very cold and I was in heels the entire weekend but had no problem getting around. Merchants are lovely, kind and gracious at restaurants, boutiques, eateries, souvenir shops and antique stores. All wanted to visit and chat and know where we were from. Very nice people in NO. Of course we visited Cafe de Monde and were not dissapointed. Great coffee and beinets as always. WARNING - CDM is ALWAYS crowded!!!! But they are quick and the service is good. Beinets HOT and yummy. I would also recommend MR B's - close by- for a casual dinner or Sunday brunch. Don't pass up the HUGE bar-b-Q shrimp at Mr. B's! My husband ordered the quail - very large dish and wonderful (waiter mentioned they do not have quail very often, get it if its on menu - you will not be disappointed). Cuvee was also wonderful - elegant (we dressed up) but also easy casual if you prefer. One of the BEST meals I have had on travels (we travel a LOT). We walked the 2 blocks from hotel in 25 degrees with wind (me in heels) - but no problem. Ate quick breakfast at Fleur de Lis (close-by also) which was very good. If you have time to sit and eat an omelet - they have wonderful cajun concoctions not to be missed. Overall - NO was a great weekend get-away. Wish we could have stayed another day or 2! We will be back.

Great hotel! I absolutely loved this place鈥he staff was incredibly nice, the lobby was gorgeous and the rooms were very relaxing, neat, clean and stylish. When my friend and I checked in, the manager was there and preceeded to give us a tour of the hotel, as well as telling us all the events that were going on during the week (we were there one August, a few years ago). After such a nice reception, we entered a nice, dimly lit room that had soft music playing in the background; a great touch. My only complaints would be that there was really nothing else on the street of interest, besides the hotel, and our view was nothing spectacular at all. Highly recommend!
Good location, comfortable room       Lobby

I-Hotel is perfect location for easy-in, easy-out on Bourbon Street A classic boutique hotel with a fabulous bar!! However, the best part is that it is located just blocks from Bourbon Street, and right down the road from the best Gumbo in all of New Orleans.....Evelyn's Place ([--]).The room was immaculate and the staff was terrific.
Un avis mitig茅   showReview(21823838, 'full');

great location, nice atmosphere The Maison Dupuy was just of the edge of the French Quarter to have a good night's sleep, but a comfortable walk to attractions (Bourbon Street, French Market, Jackson Square, Canal Street). The front desk staff was useless in the morning, but very helpful in the evening. There were plenty of restaurants in the area. I didn't eat at the hotel, but the drinks at the cafe bar were excellent. I will definately be staying here again next time I visit New Orleans.

Awesome beyond words! This is an awesome spot in Nola! The staff is the best in the world...and we've traveled quite a bit. Their excellent customer service extends beyond the front desk, including special events planning (I stayed here for a wedding earlier in the year, which was also held at the hotel). Their entire staff from room/ guest services, to housekeeping/ room attendants, continuously delivered exemplary service and demonstrated we were the most important guest they had staying with them! We will always stay at the Maison Dupuy and suggest you do the same! They get the importance of excellence and it is demonstrated in all that they do! I'd also like to say a special Thank you to Dana Crabtree in their Reservation Dept. She was instrumental in ensuring my husbands R  R visit from his deployment in the Middle East was the most memorable time we've had in a loooong time! You're awesome, Dana! Thank you for taking the time to read my thoughts on this hidden treasure and have an awesome remainder of the week !

A few quirks but we would definitely stay again On one of our tours the guide said that the number one problem these days is a shortage of employees and to be understanding if places are a little short staffed. Remembering that served us well throughout the City and in particular at the Maison Dupuy.The Basics: We had an amazing deal - $89/night for a king deluxe with balcony overlooking the courtyard. We stayed for five nights from Sunday to Friday. We would definitely stay here again but also have a few minor recommendations that would bring the hotel to that next level. Also, this is a great place if you like boutique hotels that aren't chains or lacking in character like we do. If you're looking for slick or predictable it may not be the place for you.The Bad: The bathroom amenities functioned; however, the drain, tub spout, and door handle seemed in need of minor repair. The bathroom itself could have been a bit cleaner with the help of a Mr. Clean Magic Eraser taken to the walls. Again, this is MINOR and the good far outweighed these issues.The Good: We loved the staff - the service was excellent and very friendly. They allowed us to check out late without penalty on our final day, which was definitely appreciated. We had a wonderful room overlooking the beautiful courtyard where we enjoyed breakfast on the balcony one morning and the hot tub several evenings. The location was terrific - within walking distance of everything in the Quarter but far enough from Bourbon to feel a bit quieter. The French Bistro, their on-site cafe, was decently priced with friendly service. We did not eat at Dominique's, the fine dining restaurant.As the hotel continues to make renovations and come back in full force a few suggestions: 1) Provide robes in room; 2) Add more art to the rooms; 3) carry the Times-Picayune rather than USA Today (as a boutique hotel rather than a chain it seemed a shame to carry USA Today over the local paper) and 4) especially in the king sized rooms, add a little bar area with a coffee maker, mini fridge, and microwave.Again though, a terrific place, friendly people, and we will very likely return again.

Maison Dupuy a Class Act Maison Dupuy was an excellent experience for a seven-day visit recently. We were treated very graciously by a professional, courteous staff. The hotel reservation person helped us plan and fit within our budget, applying appropriate AAA discounts. All the prices were as advertised over the telephone.Parking was a piece of cake. We drove into the hotel lot so we were safely off the street. Our car was presented to us very quickly whenever we wanted to use it. If we left an item in the car it was retrieved by the attendant with no hassles.The front desk staff was very accommodating, including explaining charges, credit card holds for incidentals etc. The hotel is a couple of blocks off Bourbon, so there was solitude in the evening.The courtyard is very appealing with an exquisite fountain, pool and jacuzzi. Special events such as weddings are held there and during those times the courtyard might be unavailable (which is posted at the front desk. If you request a courtyard balcony, you can listen to the music if there is an event. The bands have to cut off the music at 10pm. We requested and were granted an upgrade to a larger room with balcony (exterior) that overlooked Toulouse Street.The hotel is clean, fresh smelling with marble for the bathroom sinks and floors giving an elegant touch. The beds/sheets were extremely comfortable. The initial room could have had a few more drawers for storage. We enjoyed the larger room as it helped let us spread out a little more.We ran out of kleenex one day and housekeeping promptly brought another box--refusing the tip that we offered. A small grocery is just a couple of blocks toward Bourbon Street. A free morning coffee service in the lobby serves a house blend that is one of the best i've ever tasted. The bar in the bistro had a friendly, helpful staff. Dominiques restaurant seemed elegant with friendly staff, although we didn't dine there. They had an interesting new menu that would appeal to many.From our courtyard room, we witnessed a wedding on Saturday night and soaked in the music from the reception. Maison Dupuy is well-situated and within a couple of minutes, you can experience the nightlife of bourbon street or walk the shops/museums of Royal Street. Jackson Square is close by as well. Snug Harbor on Frenchman Street has great jazz/blues and dinner...a short taxi ride away, or walk via Decatur Street during the day. The Orleans Collection is a museum/house tour that is free and gives you a sense of what it's like to live with a courtyard in the Quarter. Check out the tour times, which are offered several times a day. The ladies have to visit the fancy hat store on Royal.

Very Charming; Great Place Our travel agent booked this hotel for us for a short business meeting. I was very pleased. Apparently this is an older historic hotel which went through a MAJOR remodel after Hurrican Katrina. (Someone said $50 million remodel). They did a top class job. Retained the older historic look and feel, but with a clean feel.As for location, it is about 2-3 blocks from Bourbon Street. Far enough away, that was quiet (in early December when we were there), but close enough to the fun stuff that everyone enjoyed it. Perfect location!The centerpiece of the facilities was a courtyard with a beautiful fountain and a pool (although it was way to cold to use the pool). The guest rooms were not large or modern, but were nicely laid out and were what one should expect for a historic hotel.Even though I was there for business, I brought my family, including three young children. We stayed in the parlor suite. It was perfect for our family. It had a room with a king size bed, and a separate parlor (a smaller room with a TV and a sofa, which pulled out as a bed). Once we had a crib brought in for my youngest, the parlor suite was perfect for us.The bathroom was nicely updated with lots of marble and granite and a nice bathtub and a massage showerhead. My only complaint about the room was the lack of personal coffee maker, which has become fairly standard in hotels these days. But that problem was quickly offset by the caraffes of free coffee in the lobby each morning.The staff was very accommodating and helpful. Since I was there for business, we utilized the meeting room and had great dealings with the group meeting staff. Paul Perez was very helpful and willing to do what it took to make our small group happy.I would like to go back someday with just my wife and enjoy the historic place with close proximity to the fun, without having to spend my time in business meetings.
Maison Dupuy - Pamper yourself       Maison Dupuy

Good Experience I did near exhaustive research to find the right place for my wife and I to stay on our Halloween trip to the French Quarter. And after weeks of this research, I was still uncertain so we held reservations at 4 places in the quarter, right down to the last date we could still cancel with no penalties...and at the last minute we pulled the trigger on Maison Dupuy. WHEW!!! Couldn't be happier.I have been to the Quarter twice before. I have family who was displaced from Chalmette in Katrina but still lives in the area. And an uncle who was a Quarter beat cop for 20yrs. On top of all of their advice, and my previous experiences, I must have read at least a dozen reviews of at least 25 hotels. After taking all of that in to consideration, then checking prices, availability, etc...it came down to Maison Dupuy, Chateau LeMoyne, Bourbon Orleans, and The French Market Inn.Lemoyne jacked their advertised price when I called so they were out. The French Market Inn was a bitt too far towards the river for our likes. And Bournon Orleans, altho with the best location, had horrrrrible internet reviews. So despite it's close proximity to the northern edges, and notoriously less safe areas of the Quarter, we chose Maison Dupuy.What we found was easy driving access. When coming in off Interstate 10, all you do is take the Vieaux Carre/Orleans Ave Exit and head Downtown following the signs to the Quarter and then there is a VERRRY clear sign that says FRENCH QUARTER VIA TOULOUSE. Well, just follow that and Maison Dupuy is a block down in to the Quarter on Toulouse.Parking in the Quarter has skyrocketed since Katrina. The Hotel wanted $28 a night so I drove around to find street parking and got a spot about 1/2block away. We checked in, and found what seems to be the case at every hotel out there in the Quarter==a snooty desk attendant. An effeminate black guy who treated me like I was the biggest [--] he'd ever seen. He assured me parking was as cheap there as anywhere. Knowing there used to be $10-20 garages, I took a ride around after we checked in. He was almost right. Cheapest places we found were like $24 a day. And since the $28 at the hotel kept the car right there for us, and it was valet parked==it was sadly, the best option. But plan on adding $30($28 plus at least a couple bucks for tip) a day to your stay at this hotel.The hotel lobby was decent. The elvator was excellent. In our couple days there, we only had to take the stairs a couple times(just b/c we like exercise and don't like to wait long)...but the elevator was almost always there within seconds of hitting the call button. The hallways had a slight funky smell, but if you can't stand some funky smells that run the gamut from pleasant to foul and all points in between, then the French Quarter is NOOOOT the place to go.Our room was very adequate. We knew going in that we didn't get a courtyard or street view, so we were OK with our view of the backs of buildings. The windows were painted shut, and appeared to have been so for 50yrs. But the AC worked fine(as did the heat, as we had wildly varying temps on our trip) so we were able to de-stale/refresh the room air pretty adequately. The stories of poor water pressure at this hotel, and in the FQ in general, are either flat wrong, or we just got lucky b/c we had fantastic water temps and pressure all weekend. Plenty of towels. The maid service was fantastic. Reallllly super friendly ladies. By the way, the valet guys were pretty friendly and heldful too. We had an ice machine 2 doors away. And the next floor up had another ice machine and a soda machine within a couple doors of the stairwell($2 per soda tho...but again, you're on vacation, so expect it). Our TV remote was broken and they sent someone from engineering up within 5mins. Nice guy who addressed me as Mr, had a hotel shirt on, and fixed the problem(just had to re-set the inputs in the rear of TV) within a couple mins and was gone. Excellent cable service, and in-room movies. We never got room service, so we can't speak to that.The hotel has two restaurants. Dominiques is quite fancy schmancy and has an excellent breakfast buffett. The courtyard is dynamite and was to host a wedding while we were there. there was about 10-12 balcony rooms, which we will be sure to get one next time. The pool was nice, but too cold to swim in at this time of year. But we spent an hour in the hot tub one morning over the decent free coffee, and free newspaper you get in the lobby....and the hot tub is excellent. really hot, plenty of room, etc.The location is freaking DYNOMITE! Quarter blocks aren't like regular city blocks. They are about 75-100ft tops. And the Maison Dupuy is literally a smidge over two Quarter blocks from the very heart of the party section of Bourbon. Close enough to make the Tropicle Isle in 2mins, but far enough away so that the hustle and bustle isn't too much at any time. Put it this way: despite it's being up by Toulouse and Burgundy, I still made Cafe DuMonde for Beignets one morning and BACK up to the room all in less than a half an hour. Left the room, elevator, walked down, waited in line, walked back, and up to room in about 25mins. So any location concerns should be thrown out the window.Overall, considering the location, price, amenities, etc....the experience was excellent!!

Lovely Boutique Hotel I booked the Maison Dupuy for two nights in August . I called the front desk before our trip and asked for a courtyard view. On arrival we were told by the somewhat arrogant manager that he could not grant our request. Once in our room we noticed we had a remote control with no batteries, low water pressure, and no ice or drink machine on our floor. On the positive side, the breakfast each day was wonderful although somewhat pricey.It was very convenient to everything and we felt safe walking around the area. The hot tub was the best! Really had hot water and could hold several people. Courtyard is beautiful and very peaceful setting. We would stay there again when we come back to NOLA.
Loved the Maison Dupuy 6 Senior Citizens in New Orleans for the first time. We lovedthis hotel. Wonderful staff! Lovely hotel! Beautiful court yard!Perfect location. Would return to this one again!

A Comfortable Stay We planned a girls weekend in New Orleans and found a great hotel package through bookit.com The reviews from others were mixed, but we found that it suited our needs perfectly. The hotel was clean, the staff was very nice and attentive, and the location was good. We were only a 4 block walk to the center of the French Quarter. We found that we didn't need a car except for shopping on Magazine Street/Garden District (which we recommend skipping). We had a balcony room with a private balcony (recommended). There are a lot of weddings that the hotel hosts but that just gave us something to do between 6:30-7:30 PM. All the outdoor noise settles down by 10:30 PM. When there are weddings planned you have use of the courtyard and pool until 4 PM. A lot of guests watched the lovely outdoor ceremonies from their baclonies. We event got a bottle of wine on the last night to settle in for the show. We were very comfortable at the DuPuy. One thing to note is that their restaurant, Dominque's is EXCELLENT but a little pricy, as is their breakfast buffet. We would recommend it for first timers to NOLA.

We enjoyed our stay. We had a seven day stay and although it started out bumpy it quickly smoothed out. The hotel staff was helpful and pleasant. One notable exception was a very bad front desk staff man who clearly did not enjoy his job, nor did he understand the meaning of reservations. He was easily recognizable by the fact that he had a horrible nail biting habit. He did not understand that when one reserved and paid for a specific room one should get it. Fortunately, other staff was there to help. We had a wonderful balcony room and got to enjoy the wedding parades as they passed by. Breakfast buffets at Dominique's was great. We were always pleasantly fortified for our days adventures. While it is close to Rampart we had no problems and there was never too much noise. Like any city you have to be aware of your surroundings and everyone was helpful about where to go. We were walking distance tours and hot spots in the french quarter. While there was not much evidence of hurricane damage where we were on tours it was extremely evident and very sad. We were amazed at the positive attitude of the people that lived there and their love of their city. The food, the people, the culture, and the history of the city made this a truly memorable vacation and one I recommend to all. I would highly recommend the hotel to all.

Too Good To Be True!! There is a reason so many incentives are listed for this hotel. 1) It is in a terrible location wayyyyy too close to Rampart St. 2) Very noisy..it is French Quarter, but this wasn't festive noise. 3) Do not let them valet park your car. The valet curbed my rims and scratched my door terribly. Now, management will not return my phone calls after the parking supervisor, Marvin, said that it happened there. 4) The staff is very rude. While explaining my car damage, the customer service representative accused me of being rude and hung up on me. Before she was able to hang up, I heard her call me a STUPID WHITE GUY. 5) Antonio Davis is the hotel manager. I have made many phone calls to him that have gone unreturned.Save yourself the hassle and stay at one of the good hotels in a better location with a higher caliber of staff. There is a reason that there are so many incentives listed for this hotel.

Loved This Hotel! My husband and I just got back from a week stay at the Maison Dupuy (8-20 thru 8-26). I have to say that we had a wonderful time. We checked in late on Wed. night and were given a mediocre room, seemed like the night staff did not really know what they were doing. But the next day we got up and were given another room with a wonderful view of the courtyard. Just a little info: they do not have mini bars or fridges in the room. They say they do but they do not. We were told that they were in the process of getting them in. And some rooms do not have an in room safe. Our first room did not but the second one did which I wanted to have. We also were given half off our whole stay on parking which is $28, put it down to $14 a day for us. And just so you know that is anywhere you go and if you park it there you know it is safe. The valet guys were all super nice, so was everyone else that worked there. The beds are to die for. I swear we did not get out of the bed till 11am every day. They were so comfy. They were always accomidating to as to when they cleaned our room. Our sheets were chnged every day and we got fresh towels with no problems. They have a lovely courtyard and pool. I read other reviews about it being taken up on weekends with weddings. Well we did not have any weddings while we were there. But we did not go there to hang at the pool anyway. We have one at home so that was the last thing on our plans. And it is in a perfect location! It is right down from Bourbon street and right next to the main road (rampart) which is right by the police station and the famous St. Louis Cemetary No. 1. We walked everywhere we went for the whole week. I am sure there are nicer hotels but for the price and location you just can not beat it. Our room was normally $489 a night before tax and we got ours for $86 through expedia. I did shop around and they had the best price.I have so many tips on things to see and do: I will write reviews on them in the correct places, but here are some of them.Restaurants:GW FinsJohnny Po BoysFranks ItalianCentral GroceryThe Market CafeThe Corner CafeChartres House CafePlaces to See:The CathedralJackson SquareMake sure you taste the creamy original pralines!St. Louis Cemetary No. 1, houses Marie Laveau's Tomb (we took many photos there and have actually came back home and found ghost images in them)St. Louis Cemetary No. 2, 3Ride the St. Charles TrolleyWe drove to the garden distrist by Tulane and went to the famous Lafeyette cemetary where Interview with a Vampire was filmed and all the Anne Rice books are writen after.We walked up and down all the side streets and went in and out of all the shops which was fun.Of course there is Bourbon street: not very kid friendly at all! One end of the street is mainly strip clubs but once you pass them then you are into your bars. If you like to drink you have to get a hand grenade from Tropical ISle but be careful they are strong but yummy.Also go on the Southern Comfort Walking Tour through Gray Line Tours. I heard it was great! You go to historic bars and they tell you about there special drinks and you get a chance to tatste them. I would definitely reccomend the Old Absinthe House! Ask them the history behind absinthe and get you one! They are $19 for one glass but it is the most interesting thing! Look up Absinthe and read about it before you go. It was definitely an experience.We ended up at Razoo most nights for the happy hour and the crowd watching. Plus most of the bars let you bring in your drink and they have no covers.Last thing we did was go to the Lower 9th Ward. Dont let anyone tell you it is not safe, that's just crazy. Of course dont go at night but if you go in the middle of the day it is fine. We drove our own car down there which is very close to the frech quarter. There were a ton of people about and lots of workers so no reason to feel threatened. We went to the exact spot where the levee broke during hurricane katrina and viewed many destryoed homes. It will put a new perspective on all that you have and all that we should be doing to help. It is just so sad that even after three years most all of the homes are still gone or abandoned.If you have any questions feel free to ask!

By FAR our favorite NO hotel!! We have stayed at the Maison DuPuy many times over the years and we are never disappointed. The Maison DuPuy is by far our favorite New Orleans hotel. It is 2 blocks from Bourbon Street in the Quarter, so it is close enough for all of the partying yet far enough away to be quiet. It is very clean and attractive, but above all, its staff is extremely helpful and friendly. During our recent stay, we found a couple of minor problems in our room. One of the bed-side lamps had a broken switch and would not turn on, and we were missing a TV remote control. I called the front desk and within 5 minutes an engineer was at our door with a new lamp and a remote. Being Innkeepers ourselves, we understand when there is a minor problem with a room. The key is how it is addressed by the staff when brought to their attention. We couldn't have been more pleased with their prompt response. For the price, this hotel can't be beat. I wouldn't hesitate to recommend the Maison DuPuy to anyone traveling to New Orleans.

Perfect New Orleans Experience Our arrival at the Maison Dupuy was greeted by valet (Marvin is awesome!) and we were taken into the small yet gorgeous lobby. Our room was smaller than we thought and obviously old, but it was still a great stay on an extremely comfortable bed.Watch your balcony preference, because the balconys on the street are shared with 3 other rooms and can get loud. (We heard a fight happening one night) We never saw any of the other balcony sharing guests, so I guess we lucked out on keeping our chairs outside. Hotel is about a 3 minute walk to Bourbon Street, and retains such an old world charm, we loved it. HINT* Skip the hotel breakfast and go over to Petunia's before 9:00. The food is so New Orleans authentic, the french toast is out of this world, and the lines are crazy after 9:30 so go early. Only a 2 block walk from the hotel, ask Marvin or hotel staff for direction.Only bad review is that we left an item in our room and called every day for 2 weeks trying to recover it. Hotel did not call us, we had to keep calling them to check status. Never found our item, didn't act like they were even looking for it.

Great hotel with lots of charm My family and I stayed here over spring break. This hotel was lovely. The staff was nice and helpful. The furnishing are nice and tasteful. The beds were really comfortable. The location is great. You are in the French Quarter without being in the middle of the party. We would all stay here again.

Good Value, Good Location We recently stayed at the Maison for a long weekend, and had no real big problems to report. The staff is friendly and helpful, there's a guard posted outside if you park your car there, and the pool is welcoming on a sweltering day. However, because of the budget friendly accomodations, our room window faced a brick wall. Eh...whaddya goonna do? It's 2 blocks from Burbon St, which is close enough to stumble home, but far enough to where you don't hear the excitement. :) I would stay there again.

Wonderful, charming hotel -- absolutely first rate Fabulous hotel. We stayed here once before -- right before Katrina in August 2005. It was wonderful then, it is even better now. Terrific service. Great buffet breakfast in Dominique's -- a four star restaurant. The rooms are pretty, the pool is beautiful and well-maintained, and the location is close to Bourbon street, but far enough away to get a good restful night's sleep. Everything is within walking distance. This hotel has it all. It's perfect for young couples, and young families -- older folks and old families, just about anybody who wants to experience the French Quarter and all that New Orleans has to offer. The rates were right, too. If you've never been to New Orleans, this is the way to go!

Value, Location,  My family and I spent a week at the Maison Dupuy at the end of June 2008, and I felt we received an exceptional value. With New Orleans still suffering from the havoc Katrina wreaked on the tourism industry, the hotels are all but giving rooms away. I almost felt guilty for staying at such a nice hotel at the paltry rate of $89/night. I would have easily paid two to three times that rate for the same room in another historical destination such as Savannah or Charleston! Not only did we receive a bargain rate, we were given half-off the $28/day parking fee, and the internet access was complimentary, although it is not indicated as such on the hotel鈥檚 website or on TripAdvisor.I had read some less-than-positive reviews before booking at the Maison Dupuy, and I can address all of the unflattering comments. One reviewer had made the comment that the pictures on the internet were misleading, and I can assure you, the rooms are EXACTLY as pictured on the hotel鈥檚 website. The bathrooms aren鈥檛 as glitzy as the one shown on the internet, but the one they feature is in the Honeymoon Suite, and they represent it as such. As a matter of fact, the bathrooms were quite nice, with marble tiles and granite countertops. Perhaps they were a bit small, but the Maison Dupuy touts itself as a boutique hotel, and make no mistake, boutique hotels usually have cramped rooms; however, in this case, these are the largest rooms I have ever encountered in a boutique hotel. Another comment I had read was that the d茅cor was a throwback from the 鈥?0s. I don鈥檛 know where this person had been in the 鈥?0s, but I think the rooms all look very tastefully done and up-to-date. The incredibly comfy beds all feature the fluffy white duvets and mounds of pillows, with the woven throw folded at the foot of the bed (never saw that in the 鈥?0s!) The furnishings were the typical antique reproduction hotel stock, but the upholstery and draperies were all very good quality and quite elegant in a conservative, traditional sense. Our room had an unbeatable view of the courtyard, which was lush and beautiful. The entire hotel had real brass accents, not the fakey polished brass junk that was popular in the 鈥?0s. I think they had a staff member who was solely dedicated to constantly polishing the brass!Someone had mentioned a musty odor which permeated the facility. I did not experience that at all, and if there is a questionable smell, I will be the first to detect it! Possibly there had been some water damage following Katrina, but if someone had noticed mustiness in the past, it is gone now.Another reviewer had complained about the weddings in the courtyard which interfered with their ability to utilize everything they felt they had paid for. Come on, now! The reason the courtyard is in such high demand for weddings is because it is so beautiful鈥e appreciative for having the good fortune to stay in a hotel with such a lovely courtyard, don鈥檛 complain about not getting to use it for an afternoon or two! We arrived on a Saturday, and it was the only day we were unable to use the courtyard/pool area. Anyway, it wasn鈥檛 closed all day, just from 5 pm until about 11 pm. My daughter loved feeling like an uninvited spectator at a wedding鈥t was all very breathtaking! I don鈥檛 think there is any real danger of experiencing severely compromised pool privileges as a result of constant weddings. Most brides who go through enough trouble to secure such a lovely location only get married on Saturdays, and only at night, when it isn鈥檛 a zillion degrees outside. I think, out of the whole week, it is not such an inconvenience having to sacrifice the pool for a few hours. We had a marvelous stay at the Maison Dupuy. From the bartender at the Bistro who remembered that my daughter preferred a pile of cherries on her ice cream sundaes to guest services to the wait staff in Dominiques to the valets to the housekeeping staff, we had phenomenal service. The only minor inconveniences we experienced was that the alarm clock in our room was broken, our clean towels were not delivered at all one day (we 鈥渂orrowed鈥?some from the pool), and on an occasion or two we were awakened by people loudly conversing in the hallways in the wee hours of the morning; however, I must admit it is not the hotel鈥檚 fault that some people are inconsiderate! We couldn鈥檛 hear a thing from the rooms around, above, or below us. We didn鈥檛 even hear noise from the wedding in the courtyard. The incidents mentioned above were such minor nuisances, that I feel silly for even mentioning them. Had I paid $489 per night, which was the rate posted on the back of the door to our room, I might have been very slightly annoyed. For $89 a night, I am thrilled that it was as impeccably clean, comfortable, and safe as we found it to be.  I will gladly tell you what everyone in New Orleans is begging for us to tell you鈥o, have a great time, and tell everyone you know to go, too. They are desperate for your tourism dollars. I just regret that I will probably never be able to afford to stay at the Maison Dupuy again once New Orleans gets back on its feet. Take my advice and go now while you can still take advantage of a great deal on a lovely hotel.

Always consistent This was our 4th stay at the Maison DuPuy and once again, we had a great time. We opted for a larger room with a balcony over Toulouse St. instead of the courtyard. Did we hear a little extra noise on Saturday night from revelers? Of course, but that was just one night. The rest of our 4 night stay was quiet and wonderful. If you want to be guaranteed a quiet room, take one of the smaller rooms facing the courtyard.

They Saved Our Honeymoon My new wife and I were looking forward to our honeymoon in Belize but Tropical Storm Arthur had other plans. We found ourselves without a place to stay and chose New Orleans as our next stop. I am so glad we did.The folks at the Maison Dupuy saved our honeymoon. We arrived after a long flight very late in the evening. The staff had our room ready and even sent up a cheese plate, bottled water and a bottle of champagne to our room. It was so nice to finally feel like we had our special honeymoon!The hotel is located a few blocks from Bourbon Street and a short walk from Lower Decatur and has a beautiful pool.hot tub area off of the courtyard. We stayed here in 2006 and had just as great of a time as we did this time. I can't say enough nice things about the Dupuy. Try it for yourself.

Loved the Maison DuPuy wonderful hotel, very helpful staffhad a charming room with a balcony overlooking the beautiful courtyardthe hotel had all the romance and ambiance we were hoping for in New Orleansour stay was simply wonderful - every restaurant we went to had top-notch service, fabulous foodwould recommend New Orleans and specifically the Maison DuPuy to anyone wanting a romantic getaway weekend

Just steps away from Bourbon! A beatiful hotel with very friendly and efficient staff. The MD is located just 2 blocks away from Bourbon Street, and that's just far away enough to enjoy a peacful nights sleep after a fun night on Bourbon. Valet service was very quick. Check-In took less than 5 minutes. Our room was very clean, and had a king size bed that was more comfortable than our bed at home! We had an amazing view of their beautiful courtyard (Pool, hot tub, fountain, patio w/ tables and chairs). Some rooms had balconies overlooking the courtyard, ours did not, but will next time! Great for a romantic getaway, honeymoon, wedding, girls night out! We went for our 12th anniversary. I'm planning on going back for our 13th!

Great hotel, great city !! My wife and I spent 3 days at the Maison Depuy in New Orleans, LA. We stayed in one of the cheaper rooms, but it was still very nice. I am not sure I have ever been in a room as quiet as this one. Considering the lively surroundings I am amazed we heard practically nothing when the door was closed. Although the price was very affordable (approx. $100 on weeknights,) the hotel felt luxurious and the decor was impressive. The fountain and courtyard are a great place to smoke the evening's final cigar and reflect on the day's frivolity. We enjoyed our stay and will gladly stay there again on our next visit to NOLA.

Absolutely LOVED IT! I fell in love with this hotel the minute we walked into the lobby. I decided to surprise my husband and take him on a trip for Father's Day. We just got back last night and I have nothing but good things to say about this hotel. The staff was WONDERFUL. They gave us great recommendations on where to eat and things to do. We had a king balcony room that overlooked the courtyard and the pool. I was out on the balcony every morning because it was so relaxing listening to the fountain. There were no weddings going on during our stay but even if there were it would not change my review. We did not come to New Orleans to hang out at the hotel pool so that would not have been a factor for us. It is 3 blocks (short blocks) from Bourbon street so you don't get any of the noise that you would get if you stayed at a hotel on Bourbon. We are going back to New Orleans in July of 2009 and we will definately be staying here again. The only drawback was the 28.00 a night parking but all of the hotels charge about that since street parking in nonexistent (overnight parking on the street is for residents only) and offiste parking is more expensive than the hotel parking so if you rent a car you just have to suck it up and deal with expensive parking fees no matter where you stay.

Beautiful hotel This hotel is at the edge of the French Quarter, but well within walking distance of everything. Our room had a private balcony that looked out over the courtyard. The room and bathroom was very clean and very comfortable and we loved the balcony. The pool is clean, beautifully landscaped and there is a great hot tub. The staff was nice--we had very little need for any staff services although friends that we travelled with requested a coffee maker and never got it. Complimentary coffee is available in the lobby beginning at 6:30 A.M., but our friends are very early risers, so available coffee is always a plus to them. My only criticism would be the closing of the pool area during weddings. We were there during the week and we left on Friday. A sign was posted in the lobby stating that the pool and spa would be closed beginning at 4:30 that afternoon until the next day. Had that sign been up when we checked in at 10:30 at night after being involved in a train wreck that day, I would not have taken very kindly to it. The pool and courtyard are divided by land-scaping and I would think it would be fairly easy to keep wedding events separated from regular guests. Also, you may request a courtyard room, but that does not mean that you will get one. We were very lucky. Restaurants we would recommend are Brennan's (of course!), Deanie's for fresh seafood at reasonable prices, Petunia's for breakfast, and Maison Bourbon for authentic New Orleans jazz. The French Quarter was basically untouched by Hurricane Katrina and I wondered if enough people were back to provide the kind of service we had on previous visits. The hotel had plenty of people on staff and all the restaurants gave the customary wonderful service. I would definitely stay at Maison Dupuy again. It is a great place.

Southern charmer We had our wedding at the Maison Dupuy on May 30. The pictures don't do it justice. It's a wonderful little hotel with great, attentive staff, especially Frank the concierge. I know alot of people complain about the fact that the courtyard is always being occupied with weddings. But that's hardly a reason to give the hotel a bad review. They host so many weddings because it's a great wedding venue. Our guests had a great time, and we're looking forward to spending our one year anniversary in the quarter.

Good decison to Stay at The Maison Dupuy Stayed at the Maison Dupuy on a Friday and Saturday night. All the amenities of a large hotel but still had a French Quarter feel as opposed to staying at a high-rise on Canal Street. No trouble with the check in. Room was large for the Quarter and was ready for us when we arrived at 2 PM. Had a king room overlooking Toulouse St. Courtyard view would be better but we were only paying $120 per night. Air conditioning worked great which is always important in NO in the summertime. Just a couple of blocks from Bourbon St so it was an easy walk yet far enough away you don't get the noise. It can be a long walk to Jackson Square area. Housekeeping was efficient. Hotel was very clean. Found the staff to be helpful and engaging. As others have noted, I think there were 3 weddings there over the 2 days we were there. They did take over the court yard but we were off looking for dive bars (try Fahy's across the street), so it was not a bother to us. Courtyard was nice for Sunday morning coffee, though. Elevators seemed a bit slow. Only item not exceptional was they did not slide my bill under the door so I had to go down to the front desk to checkout. I'm a discriminating traveller and I would have no problems whatso ever either recommending it or going back myself.

Great time We had no reservation but I had seen this place on Hotels.com before.The service is great, rooms are nice and comfortable. The first room we got had a really noisy A/C compressor. My husband called the reception and in about 5 minutes there was someone at our door with keys to a new room. He even helped us move our bags. Parking is pricey but is the rate for the area. And you do need parking option is you drive to New Orleans. The only thing I would not recommend is the breakfast buffet. Way to expensive. At the end, we had a great stay. I would recommend it and go back again.

Enjoyed, but Stayed 4 nights from May 16-20th. Check in went well, room was ready. We had a balcony room #317, had requested a courtyard though. Room was non smoking, very clean, but very small and laid out strangely. Our room overlooked Burgundy Street, not much to look at but we enjoyed the balcony, got lots of sun. First night (Friday) slept great, second night Saturday the noise from people yelling all about kept us awake off and on all night.
