There were at least 4 weddings held there between Friday and Saturday, this is my major complaint, the courtyard area is taken up with the wedding parties, not available for other guests. By 10:00pm the courtyard was available and we did enjoy taking a drink out there. Only had drinks in the bar twice, good service. Ate breakfast on the day we departed in the restaurant, could order from the menu, but choose the buffet because service was pretty slow. Front desk personnel were great in helping my daugher with incoming and outgoing faxes. Check out was fine, no problems. Housekeeping came very late on Saturday, but on Sunday were knocking on the door (even wtih the do not distrub sign out) at 8:30am. We felt the location was perfect for us, and even though our room was small, it was clean and doable. One of our best dinners was at the Bombay Club (at the Prince Conti Hotel) quiet, romantic with a great piano player. This was after 2 nights of dining with our large group. The swamp tour (Cajun Pride) was fun and entertaining, we also enjoyed the carriage ride through the french Quarter and the Charles Street Trolley. A great time, we are looking to returning next year! A couple side notes, we did try calling room service Tuesday morning, no answer, my daughter (in another room) requested an ironing board (iron was provided) several times with no result.

NOT a Good Experience!! We were very much looking forward to our romantic getaway but, unfortunately, a series of unfortunate experiences caused by your hotel, caused this weekend to be ruined.First, upon check-in we learned that the hotel pool/courtyard was going to be closed from 4:30PM on Saturday until Sunday morning because of a private event. While I appreciate the need for a wedding to be perfect, I was very upset to learn that the courtyard and pool (the reason we chose to stay at Maison Dupuy) would be closed for all that time. We had intended to spend Saturday evening lounging in your courtyard and enjoying it鈥檚 beauty. Because of your hotel鈥檚 decision to book a special event that closed the courtyard, this was not an option. When making our reservation, and again when confirming our stay, we were never notified that the courtyard would be closed.Once we checked in, we arrived at our room and I decided to go into the bathroom to take a shower to freshen up for the evening. As soon as I stepped in the bathroom, I stepped on a piece of glass that was on the floor and cut my foot. When I looked down I could see what looked like an entire wine glass that had been broken in the bathroom and not cleaned up by your housekeeping staff. While the cut was not serious, it did cause a lot of pain and prevented me from walking around and enjoying the French Quarter. In fact, we were not able to visit the Rodrigue exhibit at NOMA because I could not walk long distances. I immediately called housekeeping and my husband and I waited 45 minutes for them to arrive before finally leaving for dinner. Thankfully, the glass shards were cleaned up when we returned.When we left for the night, we went to turn off the bedside light and found that the on/off switch had been broken off and the only way to turn it on and off was by unplugging it. During our stay, I called the front desk three times requesting that it be fixed and it never was. Maintenance NEVER came to fix the broken lamp. By Saturday night, the cut on my foot was really hurting so we decided to stay in the room and watch television and relax for the evening. At about 6:00PM the special event鈥檚 reception started in the courtyard. The music was so loud in our room (room 418) that we could not even hear the television. We called downstairs and were told that it was a wedding reception and there was nothing they could do. This reception didn鈥檛 end until well after 10:30PM.On Sunday, we decided to leave as early as possible because we were exhausted by the horrible stay. We gave the parking our attendant our ticket and waited, and waited, and waited for our car. We asked a different parking attendant to find out what was taking so long because at least 5 other guests came after us and go their cars while we were waiting. Finally, after 45 minutes, our car arrived. The parking attendant told us that a church van was blocking us in. We were not offered any refund on our already expensive 48+ hours of parking that we paid for.
Perfect location, great food       Pool
Didn't enjoy the southern hostility       Leaving a can of air freshener in the room does not make it non-smoking

Not at all what is used to be This once was a nice hotel which has gone for the cheapercrowd, tatoo people, Mom Dad 3 kids in a room type deal + events. Way too small to handle both conferences and wedding events on the same day along with family outings.This used to be an exclusive New Orleans boutique hotelbut is now geared to lower end small company business conferences, cheap family getaway lets get drunk on Bourbon St crowd, and weddings anyday of the week which means: bottom line the facilities are not available 24/7 they are often closed such as the pool and courtyard. What was once a $400 night hotel for the business, elite traveler is now a $49-79night cheap 4 star; check any Experien or Yahoo or Priceline, this is the cheapest of all the original Dupuy owners would be very disappointed. Very crowded, very low class. We had business guests with written reservations well in advance, two were bumped out of the hotel; we were treated rudely, pulled our corporate account.

Another Great Stay! This was our second stay at the Maison DuPuy and it was even better the second time around. Check-in was prompt, the rooms were clean, air conditioning working, managment visible throughout the stay and the pool area was clean and even had a cart filled with beach towels. Was tempted to stay in the Garden District because we love it so much but the Maison DuPuy really did a great job changing our minds. We will be back!

Excellent Stay @ Maison Dupuy I have nothing bad to say about the hotel nor the people who work there. Rooms were updated and clean, staff was friendly and did what they could to accomidate my needs (which were very little since the hotel was excellent enough). 2 blocks from Bourbon Street, yet far enough away that you didn't have a problem getting to sleep because of the noise of staying someplace else on Bourbon Street.Had a King Deluxe room with a courtyard view. Very Nice. Would suggest trying for a Balcony room overlooking the courtyard for the full experience. (although it's really just an extra and not necessary)Be advised that parking is an extra $30ish a night.... but that is with all the hotels in the area. If arriving via NOIA, the cab ride from the airport to the hotel is $28 for 2 people, and extra $12pp after that. You really DO NOT need a car while staying in the Quarter or anyplace Downtown. You can get a day pass for the streetcars or buses... or pay $1.25 (0.25 for transfer) If renting a car for the day I would suggest using a place like Enterprise who will pick you up and drop you off before and after your rental.Pool area and courtyard was very nice. Did not eat @ Dominique's, but did eat @ the French Quarter Bistro. Very good food. I would stay here again, if not all the time I visit.For extra class and just to be pampered, request nightly turn down service. Very nice.

Great Hotel Stayed there for 2 nights on business. The hotel is conveniently located and quiet, although it is two blocks off Bourbon St.The room was confortable and very clean. There is no desk though, and it is a bit small (specially the bathroom).Restaurant (for breakfast) is good and cheap. Considered the price (~$110 per night) it is an excellent bargain.

Beautiful Wedding but Expecting Better Night Stay I am born and raised in New Orleans and had always wanted to stay in those gorgeous old boutique hotels in the Quarter. My friend threw a wedding together in only 4 months and chose the Maison Dupuy as the setting. Wedding: good food, great night candle lighting, beautiful fountain, inadequate seating for 60 guests (request tables both indoor and outdoor to solve that problem) The coordinator was brand new to the job and seemed overwhelmed at times but she did deliver a very beautiful wedding. Nothing went awry during the reception or the ceremony.1 Night Stay: comfy bed with feather duvet, beautiful balcony with view of courtyard, spacious room, friendly staff, minibar missing, the luxurious marble bath missing, malfunctioning a/c, breakfast overpriced, parking was standard Quarter ratesI would stay here again, but I wouldn't pay full price the next time around. I wrote a full review earlier but somehow deleted it accidentally. I'm willing to expand on my experience if anyone needs any more details.

It's an ill wind...... after the Katrina devastation some good! A total renovation makes Maison Dupuy a delight. The balcony street room in Spring was full of the warm air and street noises of this charming old quarter area. If you do not want to hear police cars and garbage trucks stay inside. New bathrooms and decor. Great value for our webrate $103....scary at the posted room rate of over $400!!! But truly charming with its inner courtyard and attentive staff. Be aware that asking for a courtyard balcony does NOT mean you get one but in fact the street balcony in some ways offered more privacy and a very Parisian rooftop view. Good location on the outer edge of the Quarter, the usual expensive valet parking. Neat feature for clean-niks is the pull out clothes line above the bath. Nice free computer access. Iron and board but no coffee maker. Rooms adequate size but not too good for business use perhaps. But hey...who does business in Nawleans anyway?

Kinda Ok... Too expensive for the money you spend though ;-( Nice hotel in the middle of French quarter. But way too expensive. Boy even the breakfast prices are way too expensive. Staff was not that friendly....But they have nice rooms that overlook the courtyard.

sad ;( The good news: The staff COULD NOT have been nicer or more helpul!The bad news: Housekeeping was a total miss. Our tub had a nasty black, moldy ring around the caulking. The toilet bowl was 'completely' lined in reddish mold. Our bed linen was never changed in 5 days! The first 3 days we left a tip, then gave up.While we loved the staff, sadly we will not stay there again That might be sad for them also, because while we just got back last Monday, we are already planning our next trip for April.Hope this helps....Patti and Gail from Miami, Florida

Stayed for Mardi Gras My husband and I were in New Orleans February 1-8, 2008 for Mardi Gras, which coincidently was my husband's 50th birthday. I wanted a nice hotel in the French Quarter, and was aware that that I would be paying top dollar during Mardi Gras. We paid $289 US a night for a King with a balcony overlooking the inner courtyard. The hotel is absolutely beautiful, and our room was very nice. However, that is where the positives end. We tipped housekeeping $4-$5 everyday. All we received was clean towels. I had put a paper coffee cup down on the bedsheet and left a small ring that remained there for 7 days. Obviously our linens were not changed. Our minibar did not work. I had done a lot of shopping and little bits of paper from my unwrappings remained on the floor for 7 days. I deep conditioned my hair, and rinsed it out in the sink. In the process I had splashed the mirror and tried to wipe it up with a face cloth but made a mess instead. You guessed it, the mirror stayed that way for our entire stay! A tour failed to pick us up, so I asked the front desk supervisor to call them for me, and it took her 20 minutes to find the number. She told us to go up to our room and she would contact them and then call us. A half hour passed so I went down to the front desk and got the number myself. I called from my room and it was a disconnected number. So I went back down to the front desk and said that I had been given a wrong number. I was given another number and it too was disconnected. The front desk made no offer to refund my phone charges of .75 each, even though they had given me two wrong numbers. We ate a number of times in the bistro, and service was either hit or miss, more of a miss. I had to ask that my coffee be filled up 3 times in one evening. I think that the housekeeping daily tip warranted more than my bed being made and towels being left. I know that Mardi Gras can be crazy, but when I experienced the lack of service from the front desk and the bistro there was only a couple of other guests around. I did not let the hotel ruin my Mardi Grad experience which was amazing. It simply is not worth the price that you pay!!!!

Really Bad Hotel Well when we first got there we were met up with just about everyone being rude to us. My sister was having a wedding there so I thought that since they are spending that kind of money in your hotel then you would be nice wrong. The car parking staff, and that is what I am going to call them were rude has hell, they acted like when you had to get somehting out of your car, that it was too much for them for you to walk down and get it. The rooms were nasty as hell and weren't worth the money that we paid for them. On the last day there, my sister wedding they decided to park the cars down the road in the not so nice area where my father car had gotten broken into along with this other car without telling us about it. Just goes to show you pay all this money for them to park your car and keep it safe and they decide to park it somewhere else down so that it get broken into. I think that it was a inside job, and dont expect the local police department to give a crap about your car or the people that did it, I dont know why they have a police department there in the first place. All in all if you do decide to go to this so called hotel, then be warry that they might park your car down the road, and not pay up if your car gets broken into. I would never stay here again.
We liked it--a lot!!       Sunday Champaign Brunch

I've stayed at nicer $50 motels We stayed there for the national championship game - payed a serious premium and got a fairly lousy hotel. Main DuPuy really was a quite pretty, the beds were comfortable, and the bathroom was mostly clean, but that was it. The mini-fridge was missing and the safe was not working, and I was told by Sylvia at the front desk that the mini-fridge was out-of-order with no explanation or apology, and Dean came up to look at the safe but had no new batteries (his comment: I tell them I need these things but they never buy them), and he never returned.  There was a film of dust on the closet door, a non-working lightbulb in the bathroom, an assortment of trash on top of the armoire, and the blow-dryer was the worst I've used in any hotel. After calling about the mini-fridge and safe and getting no resolution I made no effort to complain about the other issues. It also took 20 minutes to have our car brought up when we left, and we watched the gentleman we gave our ticket to chat and wander around for ten minutes before he went to go get our car. We refused cleaning service while we were there, due to the non-working safe, and I'm thankful we did because on 1/7 we heard a gentleman on our floor hollering about items being stolen from his room.  I tend not to be a needy traveller, but for any hotel, and especially one at this price, I expect a certain level of cleanliness and attention to detail that were obviously lacking in this hotel room. Frankly, I've stayed at nicer $70 highway motels, and if there was another hotel available in the French Quarter I probably would've left after checking out our room.

New Orleans in December A decent hotel. Although for the price you get a nice room, and that is it. Parking will cost you a minimum of $24/day. If you want the restaurant's breakfast buffet it will cost you $15/plate. Dinner prices are also steep. But it should be noted that this hotel is in the French Quarter in New Orleans, which is not generally known for affordable accommodations. Our request for a quiet room placed us in one directly across from the elevator. I do not know if that was the only one available - but I tend to doubt it. More like it was the motel letting us know where we stood with them. Ours was one of approximately 40 rooms reserved for out of town guests there to attend a wedding. With most, if not all, rooms being rented for a minimum of three nights. We used out ear plugs and were able to ignore most of the night time noise.  During the winter months I would suggest that you forget the heated year-around swimming pool. Which proved too cold for my wife to do laps, although I managed about 30 minutes before the water temp (high 60s - low 70s f) caught up with me.  The location is very nice for the wedding /reception, but the site's wedding planner was only marginally competent. At least in this circumstance. Some of the more interesting snafus included:-- the wrong wedding cake (switched somehow with one for a wedding the following day),-- cameras on the tables noting the names of another couple (also for another wedding), and less than one-third of the cameras which were purchased,-- horse and carriage, paid for but did not appear,-- bride's flowers failed to make it,-- microphone on the podium not turned on - making it pretty much impossible to hear the service,-- a band, scheduled to start playing at 11:00pm, failed to show. And through all of this the bride and groom were running around tending to logistics -- which should have been the responsibility of the planner. (This is just a heads-up in case you're looking to use this location for a wedding and/or reception.)  The bride's family also paid for something called a 'Cajun Gift Basket' which was to be placed in the rooms of each of the out of town guests. And which none of us received.  Our motel experience was not by any means unacceptable, although I now wish we had stayed at one of the chain hotels - located several blocks away - at half the room rate we paid.
sejour professionnel de qualit茅       vue de la cour interieure
Ne faites pas confiance 脿 ces gens-l脿.   showReview(16266348, 'full');

Stay away This is the worst hotel I have ever been since I was in college. The pics look cute so I was fooled. The truth is that there was no shampoo the night we arrived, I asked for some but they were out!!!, the body lotion was used, the TV control was out of batteries, the next day no one cleaned our room or changed sheets and towels and after staying there for 2 days of course no one thought of apologizing or at least replacing the shampoo. I was there for a conference and thank God I was not paying for it, but If I had to pay $290/night from my own pocket I would have called the police, the fire dpt. or both. Not recommended.

Think about it. My boyfriend and I arrived planned on a romantic weekend in New Orleans. Once we arrived to the hotel it was frightening!! It was located in a alley, we were both scared to death to get out of the car. Not only were we scared but there was so parking in front of the hotel to even unload our car. Once that was over we had to pay $30 dollars to have the car valet park offsite. Took 45 min to have someone find our car the next morning so that we could checkout. The room and bathroom were so small that two people could not walk around at the same time. The shower head was broken, the toilet ran constantly, and no water pressure even in the broken shower head. I would never recommend this hotel to anyone. The pictures on the website look nothing like it when you actually pull up to this dump!

Great Hotel with Charm As a frequent New Orleans visitor it is always nice to find a hidden gem and this hotel is just that. The location is great. I have always stayed in the French Quarter or on St. Charles St. Both had good and bad points, this hotel has both. It is one block from the French Quarter and the casino, it's close enough but not that noisy. I love the elegance of St. Charles and the streetcar, and it still not too far away from the action. The exterior could use a makeover, however, when you enter the lobbly it is a different world. The furnishings are period with marble floors and nice paintings. The rooms were nice and clean with lovely drapes. The remodeling on the restrurant was noisy but no problem. Very nice employees. This certainly has old world charm Will recommend to everyone!

Never again!!! I was VERY disappointed when my husband and I arrived at the hotel. We were celebrating our first honeymoon/vacation together! The pics on the website looked very nice and the room decor looked very clean and well set up. Where did they take those pictures? Although disappointed and almost in tears, my husband got me to agree to stay! The first room we checked into was room 103. OMG... the lamp wouldn't work and the safe was broken. The t.v. was too small to even watch and it was in the armoire' which was broken and would not close. The room was so small that you could barely turn around in. They offered to take off the charge of the safe or give us a different room. I wanted a different hotel, but settled for a different room(room 203) with double beds because I figured it had to be bigger. Indeed! The room had more space and for the most part was clean. The tub could've used some TLC! The safe WORKED! However, one lamp didn't so we had what felt like a candle on the wall for light the whole weekend. We didn't say anything because we didn't intend on spending much time there anyway. Some of the electrical outlets did not work. The safe was small but I didn't have alot to put in there! I donated to the Harrah's foundation while I was there! LOL... You are charged 4.95 for local/long distance calling, internet. The signal is TOO weak to use in your room so if you wanted to spend anytime online you must sit in the lobby. The phone in our room. DID NOT WORK.. By this time I was NOT surprised by anything!! I, however, never seen a bug in the place.I almost forgot...The ice machine didn't work either! I WOULD NEVER SUGGEST THIS HOTEL TO ANYONE!!!! Our first time in New Orleans was a GREAT, AMAZING, EXCITING,(etc) feeling. NO THANKS TO THIS PLACE.The location of the hotel is the only thing it has going for it! HOWEVER.. there are several in the same area so get a room there!

Decent value I booked this hotel through a website that specialized in New Orleans boutique hotels. Because we stayed for 3 days, we were able to get a deal ($62.50/nt before extras and tax). Parking was extra, but we self-parked and found some deals just a short walk away.PROS: location - 1 minute walk to Harrah's and Canal Street; 4 minutes to Bourbon Street; 10 minutes to Cafe du Monde. Value - most hotels in the area are much more expensive. Old hotel with lots of charm. Free wireless (though our room had a weak signal). The bed was ultra, ultra comfortable!CONS: the smell of SMOKE! The lobby, the room, everything had an old smoke smell. For this entire part of my trip I had a sinus infection. There was no breakfast, and parking through the hotel was very expensive. The bathroom light stopped working and the safe (mandatory fee) was too small to hold a laptop. Barely big enough to fit our Harrah's winnings! ;-)

Horrible!!! Disgusting!! I read the reviews and boy were they wrong!! This hotel is horrible! The only decent thing was Darlene, the front desk clerk. She was very helpful with all the problems we had. Very noisy, A/C wouldn't work half the time. The so called antique beds were just old and gross and the posts blocked the view of the tv. We had to turn the bed sideways to see, the 12 channels they offer. We called for our truck and waited an hour and a half. The next day they brought it to early and we got a ticket. Overall, the worst hotel I have ever stayed at. Would only go by to say hi to Darlene, hopefully from outside. Don't stay here unless the streets are full!!

Good Value and Location The Pelham is a boutique hotel with lots of charm. It's a unique experience and makes you feel closer to the New Orleans culture.Harrah's casino can be seen from the front door, Canal is one street over with shops and restaurants. Location is good, parking is up to you. I actually parked on the street at night for free at a meter. There is a lot across the street for $10 a day or you could pay the valet $28 for in and out privledged parking at the hotel. Bourbon and French Quarter are also close. It felt safe, lots of tourists in the business district. Good value hotel, I think I paid $65 off of expedia.com. All I can say is do your research and see if its for you. I would recommend the hotel as it was quiet at night and the beds were comfortable. The room has high ceilings and French decor. It was a nice change from the big franchaised hotels.

Overall a good hotel! I picked this hotel up for 77.00 a night for the last weekend in March.It takes a bit of navigational luck to drive to this hotel by car as all of the nearby streets are one way. I would definitely advise not parking in the surface lot across the street from the Pelham unless you will be leaving you car there and not moving it and like to wake up in the morning. You must pay your $10.00 a night into a box by 7am and if you arrive in the evening, you must pay $10.00 overnight and another 10 for the next day, ends up being a bit of a ripoff. The Harrah's Casino is literally a block away and the parking garage is 2 blocks (but connected underground to the casino as well). If you gamble for 30 minutes they will validate your parking and it is free, I did this for the remainder of our trip.Onto the hotel itself: The outside is nice but nothing spectacular, most of the buildings immediately around it are for sale and abandoned but this is by no means a bad part of the CBD to stay in. You can walk across the surface lot and be immediately on Canal St. or you can walk one block to the Harrah's Casino right off Canal as well. I'd advise only taking those 2 routes to the hotel though as most of the streets in the CBD are empty at night, but those two have high traffic all night long.The staff was relatively unfriendly but it did not bother me too much. They check you in/out and got me towels once, but did not seem particuarly interested at all. The room was actually pretty nice. Although the only light sources are the lamps and the windows. It is pretty dark inside the rooms even with the light on. But overall was comfortable and a nice place to stay. We stayed in 410 which has 2 double beds.This hotel does charge 2.95 for an in-room safe and 4.95 for wireless internet. I find these charges to be a bit ridiculous but since I got the room so cheap I didn't really mind, plus I used the wi-fi. I enjoyed my stay here. It is more convenient to Jackson Sq. and Cafe Du Monde, Decateur Street than a hotel I previously stayed on Conti St. above Bourbon.I'd recommend this hotel if you plan to visit Harrah's or need easy highway access on I-10 or 90. Overall it was a good stay and will stay here again if the price is right. Its certainly not a luxury hotel, nor does it have the charm of some of the FQ hotels, but it worked for us this time.

It's a New Orleans hotel... Now let me explain what that means. It means, there is no such thing as a value when dealing with hotels. You get what you pay for, and unless you drop a lot of cash, you're not getting a lot. Rooms will be small or seem that way since they're oddly shaped (unless you're staying somewhere on Canal or anywhere not the French Quarter). Hotels will have hidden fees. All hotels in New Orleans charge those weird phone and safe fees, even if you didn't use them. And you will pay a lot for parking, but you won't use your car the whole time you're there anywhere. So why not pay whatever they want to make sure your car is safe? And, the staff will be friendly. Now the Pelham is on the nicer end of a New Orleans hotel for what you pay. (You'll end up paying twice what you thought. See: hidden fees.) The room is a place to sleep and shower (both bed and bathroom were very nice). Big gorgeous windows, very clean, and nice housekeeping staff that won't just walk in when you don't answer in one knock! The convenience of the location, though, well it depends. For what we needed it was convenient. The hotel is a short walk from the casino and some shops and restaurants. The French Quarter is a little farther away, but FEELS much farther away in the heat.
nice little hotel great location       nice room

Good hotel, great location Hotel was in a fantastic location in the south of Boston within easy walking distance of both Copley Square and downtown Boston.The room was a reasonable size and clean. They were also fantastic at offering a late check out - 2pm on a Friday afternoon - much appreciated.Only negative comment is that the windows do not give much sound insultation and as the hotel is above a bar and on a busy bus route you should come prepared with ear plugs.By the way, you can get a great breakfast at the coffee shop around the corner.Would definitely stay there again.

basic clean accommodation This is basic accommodation. Room is small, good location, clean (although sheets not changed in an 8 night stay). Friendly if slightly defensive staff. Note that this hotel is near the Mass, turnpike so you have traffic noise all night. There would not appear to be any quiet rooms (according to front desk). Great gay sports bar downstairs and dont miss Billy's Cafe round the corner for great lunch or breakfast. Nice staff and really cheap.

Perfect for us! After reading some of the reviews we were worried about going to the hotel. We took a cab from logan to the hotel which took around 15mins. When we arrived we noticed the hotel was next to a bar, but we never heard any noise from the bar throughout the out week. Our room was nice, (nothing amazing) it was clean, comfy and had all what we needed. It had a TV which had loads of channels (although we hardley watched tv). The bathroom was small but really clean and everything worked. We had it cleaned daily with fresh towles. There was no tea and coffee in the room but there was a machine downstairs and you could have a bucket of ice in your room. The hotel was in a brill place, 5 min walk from back bay subway and if you get a good map you can walk to many attraction and malls. Lots of restaurants and starbucks and dunkin dougnuts around. The hotel were really informitive and called us taxi's often, they let us keep our luggage in the hotel after check out too as our floght was in the evening. Overall wewere really pleased and it was cheap too.

Great location! This inn is in a neighborhood that is indicative of Boston's architecture with brick townhouses. The local coffee shop was great and we were within walking distance of the Prudential shops and restaurants and several underground stations. The room was small but nice and clean.

Mixed Bag This hotel while quirky and cool, with friendly and knowledgeable staff, and having a great location to explore downtown Boston neighborhoods (Back Bay, South End, Beacon Hill, Downtown, etc.), also has small rooms and bathrooms, is a little more expensive than we'd hoped for (certainly given the size of the room), and has a horrible air-conditioning system. Our air conditioner (located in room 508) was a tiny window unit that blew light cool air inconsistently, would freeze up if left on high, and would also leak water after time no matter the setting. We stayed there 3 nights while on our honeymoon, and getting up in the middle of the night to adjust the air conditioner is decidedly un-romantic. Still, if you're looking for great location for the price (most hotels in Boston exceed $200/night, and this one was about $160), and like the hominess of its staff, this is good hotel. I'd give it a grade of a C+/B-. (Note to the staff: UPGRADE YOUR FRIGGIN' AIR-CONDITIONING UNITS PLEASE!).

Chandler Inn is a dungeon!! My fiancee and I were horrified by the conditions of the Chandler Inn. Trust me when I say that the photos online are VERY deceiving. Our room was extremely small, dark, dirty, and scary. In addition, there was an odd, musty odor that made my stomach turn when we walked in. I didn't think it could get worse, but the teeny tiny bathroom was disgusting and the toilet paper roll left on the dispenser was an old roll with like 2 squares left on it!!! We wanted to check out immediately but there were no other hotels available for the weekend so we suffered through the first two nights. We asked for an upgrade if available and the staff was less than friendly and not helpful. On top of all this, the cleaning staff threw away some of our clothes in a bag we left in the room and we barely received an apology for it. The ONLY thing that was positive about this place is that when we thankfully had an opportunity to switch hotels, they did not charge us for the nights we didn't stay.

The Chandler was not what it advertised to be... I decided to stay at the Chandler because of their great website and claims of being a boutique hotel, unfortunately this was not the case. While there is a great little bar attached to the hotel the hotel itself was basically a 1 star at best. I have honestly stayed at nicer hostels with a bit better upkeep. My room smelled of old cigarettes and overall needed to be aired out for a few days. The bed had a rubber sheet over the mattress that squeaked every time you turned over and the bathroom was quite tiny, to the point of being uncomfortable. The positives were a pleasant staff, great water pressure and a lovely neighborhood with great restaurants within walking distance.

Total misrepresentation on website My husband and I searched for a hotel on Expedia for a 2 night stay in Boston and the Chandler Inn is located exactly where we wanted to be. Before booking on Expedia ($140 a night) I checked out the hotel's website and it looked like a completely different hotel. I assumed they went thru a renovation and that the photos on Expedia were old, so I went through with the reservation and requested a King bed. When we arrived, they had me sign in and on my reservation it was written in large letters EXPEDIA. The elevator up to our room was done in all grey and opened up into a dingy stairwell from which you then enter a long hall to your hotel room. When we got into our room, Room 404, I was shocked by the size and look. It looked nothing like the rooms on the hotel's website. It was a creepy little room with stained carpet, very cheap furnishings, no luggage rack, no closet (just a tiny faux blonde wood laminated armoire), a polyester bedspread on a FULL-SIZE BED and a view of the office building directly across the street - out of one small window that was bolted shut and had an air conditioning unit that took up half the window. There was one outlet in the entire room and everything was plugged into it, so to charge a phone, we had to choose something to unplug. The light fixture in the ceiling gave off a depressing fluorescent hum and the bathroom was so tiny we couldn't put any of our toiletries in it, we had to keep them all on the only surface in the room - the small desk. The bathroom door had been painted so many times, that it didn't shut properly. We went downstairs and asked about another room as I had requested a King size bed, but was told they only had twins and queen-sized beds (ours was not a queen - but a Full...there is a significant difference). I suspected that they had Expedia rooms and that since we got a good price we were given this small, dingy room, but after reading other reviews, I guess they're all the same. I haven't stayed in such a depressing room since backpacking through Europe on a punishing budget. The only positive things were the location and the cleanliness of the room. One last note: it would be really nice if the older guys at the front desk were a little warmer; really, I mean, curt one-word answers don't cut it in customer service anymore. Just because people don't want to pay the truly outrageous hotel prices that seem to have become standard in the past few years, doesn't mean we deserve substandard customer service. Bottom line: I think we can all do much better than this hotel. At the very least, they should provide truthful representation on their website of the rooms they offer.

Good hotel for tourists The hotel is located in South Boston, in a quiet area with many shops and restaurants. The historical area of Boston is not far (you can walk there in about 20min).It can be a good choice for baseball fans as well: Fenway park (home of the Red Sox) is in walking distance.Rooms are nicely furnished, with small bathrooms. They don't serve breakfast in the hotel, but it's not a big deal since there're a couple of good breakfast places in the nearby.Good hotel, I'd suggest it.

The Chandler Inn: Great Location, Great Deal The Chandler Inn is a nice hotel. It has a stylish lobby, with very nice staff who take care of you immediately. In addition, the staff are very helpful and knowledgable about the neighborhood and giving directions. In the lobby there is a great coffee/tea/hot chocolate machine. Next to this machine there are stairs but don't fear there are also two elevators. The room I stayed in, the standard twin, was a no frills room. It had everything it was supposed to have (which is listed on the website). The bathroom wasn't exquisite, but it was simple, like the room. My room had a window overlooking the street (beautiful!!). Furthermore, it is difficult to find such a bargain in such an upscale city.The simplicity and plainess of the Chandler Inn surprised me, and I enjoyed it. However, this may also repulse you. So it's not that the Chandler Inn is bad it is clean, safe, comfy. It's just a matter of perspective and preference.*Note: When you leave the hotel, you have to return the key to the receptionist. It sounds silly, but if you ask why they will willingly tell you (it is a very sound reason).

The Chandler...a NIce little GEM! We've already stayed at one of Boston's pricier hotels. After searching through the internet, my husband found what seemed to be a nice place to accomodate our 3 night stay. Overall, the staff was attentive, our room SMALL(but clean and attended to daily...everything worked, by the way!), the neighborhood quaint and picturesque(great walking/running and so close to downtown...unbelievable!) There are nice restaurants and conveniences (though not FRILLY enough to pamper those with 'champagne and caviar' tastes) that dot the area. We're a FIT couple anyway so the hotel's proximity to what Boston has to offer was appreciated. We also appreciate a great value, good service and cleanliness. We're as fussy as anyone else, but we gave the Chandler Inn a chance and our experience there will hopefully be repeated next year. Yeah, it was good enough for us!

Not a lot not to like This is my 3rd stay at the Chandler Inn. This time for 5 nights taking in a conference and some other business. I find it hard to understand the negative reviews this hotel gets. Sure, its a budget hotel - but you know that when you book it. With the Marriotts of the world @ circa $300 per night you are not going to get the Ritz for $150 per night in Boston. Regardless of what people have paid that is the 'going' rate. Don't use the hotels own site use one of the others - the rates are better.Yes the rooms are small and the bathroom smaller. I understand the guy who said the rooms remind him of his college dorm - but they are entirely adequate. The location is great (5 minutes to Backbay station or 10 minutes to Boyleston) with cafes around the corner, a CVS across the road and pizza and other food within a few minutes walk. The neighbour pleasant and non threatening and the hotel is clean. I've always found the staff pleasant and helpful.There appear to be some refurbished rooms (last time I stayed on the 8th floor in one) but I prefer the non-refurb room I stayed in the 1st time and this time as it has a desk. The free wifi works well but not, I guess, in all rooms as I've seen a few people sitting in the corridor with their laptops. Lets face it you are not going to stay here if you are on a corporate expense account. But as a budget choice in Boston I don't see much not to like. I'm back in Boston for another conference in June and have already booked my room.

Poor The prices here are out of date - I paid USD259 per night in April 2008. The rooms were small, no bath, no fridge and no aircon. There was also a large patch of water on the floor which the management were uninterested in fixing.Service standards from the staff were mixed -some were helpful, some not interested. Rooms were only cleaned in late afternoon, and then only after asking reception to send up a cleaner.The bar downstairs looks nice, but it is a gay bar so not suitable for families or couples. As it is non-smoking the customers tend to hang around outside the bar/hotel.

Ummm... It was bad! The staff was very hospitable and very friendly. The room was extremely small and the beds were very uncomfortable. The bathroom was about 5 by 3 including the bathtub. The shower head was, let's see, there was no shower head, it was just a stick coming out of the wall and the water kind of sprayed out of the little hole. It looked like a metal hose.The mold on the ceiling of the shower was the deal breaker for me since I am severely allergic to it.You can't rent movies and you have to turn in your key everytime you leave the hotel.So, don't let the price fool you, just beware!

Great place for a cost effective stay in Boston The hotel room was very clean and a good size for the price ($150 per night). The room had a decent enough selection of TV channels and the free WIFI was great. The staff were really helpful and made us feel at home. This hotel does not have a restaurant but you can order in from a number of local restaurants for which the hotel provides a guide. The location was great as only a 5 min walk from Back Bay Metro station and a 10min walk from Copley Square, the nicest parts of Boston centre. The cab ride from Logan airport cost us $20. Best deals for the hotel are on online.
Overrated       The room

online photos from their website are totally bogus! Don't stay here.... Nothing annoys me more in hotel websites than doctored photos...I'm just angry with myself that I didn't catch it myself...We stayed in a deluxe room based on their online photos...if this was deluxe, I'd hate to see standard... The room was a glorified closet, that looks like a bad wanna-be Starck designer threw up orange all over the place, including the bathroom amenities, that smelled like Tang...In the photos, the room has a spacious desk and chair...the actual room has a table that is used by the DVD player, and a chair in the corner...If you look carefully at the photo, you can see that it has been stretched to give the appearance that the room is considerably larger than it actually is....The bathroom photo shows a huge walk in shower and bathroom...I've had larger bathrooms on cruise ships, though it was nice to be able to shower, shave and (well, you get the idea) all at the same time....And the free breakfast? It was a $5 voucher at a local diner....the diner actually served great breakfast food...but it wasn't free....All in all, the Chandler Inn is adequate for a Boston stay...but totally dishonest about what it actually is providing travelers...that's reason enough for me not to stay there again.

Grat price - Great location I found this hotel while searching online and decided to give it a try based on the price and positive reviews.To start, the hotel staff were very friendly and helpful. The hotel was cute!, the room was simple and clean...... small, but had a very comfortable queen bed and the bathroom/shower was fine. Why spend another $100 a night to stay anywhere else???? I recommend this hotel and will return---- J.R -- Troy N.Y

reminds me of my college dorm room The hotel is located in the south part of Boston, somewhat close to the Prudential Center and other central Boston things. However, it is a rather character-less hotel, inside and out. My first reaction when I walked into the room was that it reminded me of my college dorm room - plain beige wallpapered walls, beige finishes, beige bedding - no character of any sort (aside from the one red plastic desk chair).The room was clean, the bathroom, albeit very small, was also clean. However, for $149 a night, I expected MUCH more.The problem really was in other areas:1) NOISY - at 7am, there were construction noises coming from above (5th floor) that continued until 9am! what's up with that?2) no heater... The thermostat was set at 65 degrees - which isn't that bad if you have nice blankets... However, the blankets were those really thin, cheap fuzzy poly things, that provided little warmth on a snowy winter day in Boston.3) no one at the front desk - I called the front desk twice after 11pm, and no one answered.4) we asked for a queen bed. However, the bed was a full and not a queen.Another annoyance, though minor, is the TV control. A lot of the Direct TV channels were unavailable, and so you had to surf through each individual channel to find what was available. There were literally hundreds of empty channels - and the printed channel guide was incomplete (for example, Comedy Central was on 230-something but was not listed on the printed channel guide).
Not bad   showReview(21736086, 'full');
Devono aver aggiornato le camere...   showReview(19735915, 'full');

Warning - Do not stay here What a near disaster! Made reservations here for the weekend of the Boston Marathon. When making confirmation for my stay they had no record of me reserving there. Was barely able to get a room somewhere else at considerably more money and it wasn't near as close to the area I wanted to be. YOU HAVE BEEN WARNED - Stay Away.

Great Location to visit Boston We stayed at Milner hOtel  nights at the end of Oct 2008.The staff was always very helpfull and rooms was not moderns but very well equipped and very clean.The Hotel is a few step from Boston Common and from Theatre district.Really great was the breakfast including every kind of delicious....Yogurt,Pancakes fruit juie tea coffe donuts...really great also the price!!!

Avoid At All Costs Please avoid this hotel at all costs-- this place is a public health hazard!!! We checked in yesterday, and were on the bed watching a movie when my companion noticed a small black bug crawling across our restaurant guide. She squished it and it was filled with blood. I suspected bed bugs but didn't want to believe it, so I went online and sure enough, Harvard has a fact sheet on the web that described the bug to the tee (it was a juvenile,) including where to look and what signs to look for. We flipped up the mattress and the underside was crawling with adult bed bugs!!!! We were totally freaked out and pissed off. We went down to the desk, where they were nice and apologetic, and got a full refund. Small comfort considering we were exhausted and now looking for a hotel at 12:30 am. The worst part, however, was that the desk clerk told us this had been a problem before and they had sprayed but I guess it didn't work. This hotel is clearly shady and please don't expose yourself to that kind of health risk-- we now have to disinfect our luggage and all of our stuff, what a pain. But better than the alternative-- bringing them home!!!

If you like bedbugs you'll love the Milner Boston, MA After about 20 minutes to get checked in, I was given a key to my room. I entered the very small room, walked into the restroom and was greeted by a small beetle looking bug on the floor. I thought, no worries, just a beetle. After a long day, it was time for bed. The sheets weren't the crispiest I'd ever seen, but this is a two-star hotel. When I woke up, I saw another beetle crawling across my pillow. I contacted the front desk and informed them about the beetles. Throughout the day, I began itching. I noticed red bumps all over my body, I thought, Oh my God! They have bed bugs!! I complained and the management switched me to another room, which I learned (the hard way) had bed bugs as well. The bed bugs were one of the many problems at this hotel. The hotel is in desparate need of renovation. The bathroom tub was extremely grimy. This place needs need serious attention. It has potential, but it is poorly operated.

Avoid this hotel! One month before going to Boston, it was hard to find an affordable hotel room so I booked a room in the Milner Hotel, being the cheapest one, without paying too much attention to the negative reviews it received. I鈥檓 a low budget traveller and usually choose the cheapest I can find at the best location (which doesn鈥檛 always mean it鈥檚 cheap). I鈥檝e never had such a bad experience as in the Milner Hotel. I do not mind a small room and even the fact that there鈥檚 no door between the room and bathroom doesn鈥檛 bother me. There was always a lot of noise at night. I was sleeping on the 5th floor near the back alley, where a dump truck collected trash every night + at some times people were talking and even yelling. The room clearly wasn鈥檛 isolated well enough. The second and worst problem was the cleanness. After one night I had several flea bites on my arms and legs (+ it got worse the other 4 nights :-(((. I asked the housekeeper to change the sheets (although I wonder if that would鈥檝e helped, probably those fleas were in the dirty carpet) but they never did. They never sent anyone to reset the phone either (the voice mail settings on the phone had been changed, I never got any of the messages that my friend left me). I wonder if I can report this flea problem to a healthcare service in the US? Apart from that I had a few minor problems: curtains falling down when trying to close them (I had to 鈥榟ang鈥?them up again several times), the lamp on the nightstand which didn鈥檛 work at all, and hardly any warm water in the shower (best I could get was lukewarm). I reported this when checking out but I doubt they fixed it by now as they never seemed to care about the flea and voice mail problem either. Taking everything in mind, this room definitely isn鈥檛 worth a $129 per night!

A Throwback to the Simple life...... We stayed at the Milner prior to our cruise, we and another couple got quite a laugh out of our stay, after reading the reviews we were ready for the worst.......but actually enjoyed seeing what rooms were like eons ago....the narrow halls, the can't bend over showers, the three person elevator, and the miniscule breakfast room, and the outdoor old-fashioned fire escape.....but our room was very clean, the staff were pleasant and helpful and it was within walking distance of what we wanted to see....after staying in some of the newest ,most beautiful, and highest priced places, we would do the Milner again in a heartbeat..as for all the people who panned it, get a grip, slow down, and remember that Hilton did not build the first hotel........m

Did the job! Hey, I went to the Milner with a degree of trepidation as the reviews were a mixed bunch. I decided to go there as it was central and cheap. Mathew and Jackie (cute) were cool at the front desk, chatty and helpful. I was a random English guy on my own, there to see the sights, so for me the hotel was fine. Yes the rooms are small, I was in 413, on the fire exit staircase (nice), and when 'Pearl's' club spilled out onto the streets you knew about it, and yet overall, the place was fine.I didn't do breakfast in the 'Nook', looked small, and to be honest breakfast in one of the many diner's in the city is much more fun.Give it a try if you just want a place to dump your stuff and get on with seeing a great city day and night. Gladis

Perfectly fine for no-nonsense, no frills It's a perfectly fine place to hang your hat. When I'm travelling on business, I want clean, quiet, inexpensive, well located. I don;t want or need the luxury amenities. I'm not in my room enough to make those worth the price. I read the other reviews for Milner, and I suspect most of the negatives were from people with expectations of luxury. Nope. You wont get that. It's a bit dated, but the paint is relatively recent. Lighting could be improved to make the corridors more pleasant. Front desk staff was competent. (although one traveller did have issues with the newbie behind the front desk. Ultimately the manager took care of the problem). Morning breakfast was reasonable. Internet connection spotty. Room was TINY. I was travelling single, and I got single: a twin bed in a small room. But the room was quiet and clean. I booked for one night via a web site. Then, my business plans changed, so I called the hotel directly, got rebooked for another night, at $50 less than the web site! It's in a great location in the theatre/downtown district, near everything one needs. I'll go back. Not a place for the fantastic honeymoon or partiers. But fine if all you want is a clean, quiet, acceptable place to sleep.

Location great, hotel a bit grotty The hotel staffw ere lovely and welcoming.However, the hotel itself was not very clean, very run down in general, and in need of refurbishment.BUT great great location! To be reommneded for budget travellers, if you're not too fussy! the price was great too.

Avoid this one like the plague I attended a conference in Boston for a week in Oct 07 and booked this hotel on the internet after searching all hotels online in the vicinity of the conference centre to no avail -unless I could have afforded $650 per night which was all that was left! (onference was at the Sheraton hotel, and all their rooms were booked out). The Milner鈥檚 description and photos made it SOUND OK - and it was convenient enough...BUT.....in reality it is a FILTHY HOVEL. I feel I should report to Health department. IT IS A DISGUSTING PLACE and NOBODY there seems to care about it 鈥?except the handyman !For 'quaint' read 'falling apart'. Service is apathetic at the best of times although there was one young guy who was helpful. My room described as double room with desk and private bathroom was small, shabby, run down and dirty. The curtains were crappy and didn't meet in the middle so I was potentially overlooked (in bed) from across the road when the light was on. The shower tray was cracked and held together by tape; there was no door between the toilet and bedroom, and the washbasin was in a separate corner of the room. There was a huge stained area of ceiling tiles in the washbasin corner from an old water leak. No wardrobe but a hanging space with rail and 3 plastic hangers in the room. Nowhere to store luggage. The only good point was free internet access.The handyman told me that the hotel is half refurbished (5th floor is apparently more modern, avoid 3rd for sure!!) and the whole place NEEDS repair and refurbishment but management is not listening to what needs doing.Next morning I requested a change of room, and was put in the suite on level 6 (lift stops at level 5) so a walk up with luggage to the ATTIC. This was bigger with a small desk - window blinds have not been cleaned this century I reckon and the room reeked of stale tobacco smoke. The carpet was dirty too, not sure when it would have last been vacuumed, and the toilet needs attention -water dripped into the bowl continuously between flushes. Anyway I stuck it out 鈥?it鈥檚 a noisy place because the lift shaft is next to it so I got vibrations through the pillow at times..... (apparently this is the manager's suite when he is there so now I know his standards I can understand why this place is so run down....)Went to 'breakfast' once 鈥?a tiny little dirty area off the main foyer - floor filthy and sticky, nobody to assist, tables dirty, make your own waffles or find cereal, few yogurts and unappetising hard boiled eggs sitting in a bowl on ice.... make your own tea or coffee, use plastic cutlery (obviously recycled and stacked in containers unwrapped), muffins, doughnuts and bread in their plastic wrappers to help yourself to..... felt sick at the sight of it so didn't go back. TV was playing all the time, some inane rubbishy show.Thank goodness I was able to transfer out of this dreadful filthy place for my last night and stay at the Sheraton in deluxe comfort for not much more than the Milner charged.Milner should be knocked down; it is overpriced, filthy and unpleasant. If you want cheap accommodation try camping or a Youth hostel, definitely don't come here; if you want value for money then this place is a RIP-OFF

Good location, not as bad a feared Stayed in a single room for 5 nights. Main reasons for choosing this hotel were price, location and availability. Was running in Boston marathon.Was a bit apprehensive after reading some of the reviews on this website before travelling, but it was not that bad.Hotel is more like a BB/guest house with 24hr reception.Room had an AC/heater unit in window - this had to be kept on overnight as it was cold and wet when I stayed in Boston. Noise of unit may annoy some people, but when its keeping you warm you don't care!Room was small, there was no door separating the toilet/shower from the bedroom.Bed was against wall with window that did not shut flush, so had to stuff a pillow against window to keep cold out.Light switches looked ancient, took a while to get light a over bed on/off. Started off pulling socked in and out!Room was quiet, only noise was from traffic during night.Breakfast was eat as much as you want (or is that can).Cereal, bagels, make your own waffles, english muffins.Cereals in single serving boxes, so had to take more that one.Breakfast served in 2 quite small rooms, if hotel busy you may struggle to get a seat and just end up carrying it up to your room.Lift was out of order until morning I checked out, was on 1st floor so this didn't bother me.

Impressive Hotel Having stayed at many different hotels in Boston, including Hilton, Sheraton and Hyatt, I can honestly say that the Radisson holds it own against all of them. The rooms are crisp and clean. Bathrooms are a good size and completely remodeled and look great. The room carpeting and wallpaper are all new and clean. Outside hallways are spotless and elevators are fast. The hotel has installed Sleep Number beds which can take a bit of getting used to and you will either like them or dislike them. If you book your room on the east end of the hotel you will have the best city view of any hotel in Boston. Also make sure you don鈥檛 get a room that鈥檚 adjoining to another room. We were at first put in one of those rooms and all was fine until the 鈥渘eighbors鈥?moved in. They were extremely loud people and we could hear every word coming from the door including their arguments and dinner reservations, etc. They became so annoying that I went to the front desk and asked to be moved. I was promptly moved to a room that didn鈥檛 have the adjoining door and it was very quiet and well insulated. The best thing the hotel has going for it is it鈥檚 staff. All are very friendly and respond quickly to any issue. From Pre-arrival emails to switching rooms to my departure I was very impressed with the staff. They are currently remodeling their pool and work out area as both are closed for a few months. When this is complete, this hotel will be even better. We booked a bed, breakfast and parking package at a great rate. I highly recommend this as many hotels are charging $40 a night to park now. The breakfast buffet was good at the Theater Caf茅 with very friendly staff. It was great way to fill up before walking the city. All in all, this hotel is a great value for your money.

Quite nice Just got back from a one-night stay there. Great location -- within easy walking distance from Boston Common and Quincy Market. We had a very nice large room on one of the top floors. Breakfast was nothing special, a bit overpriced, but, all in all, a very good experience with the hotel.

Great location, good price I stayed there for 4 nights with my wife in Nov 2008. Had a great time. It is one of the best locations you can find in Boston. Eating joints are conveniently located, so we didnt get a chance to try the in house dining. The room was on the top floor and had a beautiful view of downtown. Neither the airport nor Cambridge were more than 5 miles away. In short - we accomplished a lot by just walking around.

Very nice!! Excellant value with breakfast and parking package. The service was very good. The rooms with nice with a balcony. The area is not bad at all, and walkable to anywhere in the city. Would stay at the Radisson again.

Good Value Just got back from a girlfriend getaway stay at the Radisson this weekend. Although the Radisson is not the most high end hotel in Boston it really is a great value. I did a lot of research for hotels in Boston prior to selecting the Radisson and it was the most economical for what you get. Rooms were clean, check in was friendly  professional and the location is VERY good. We were able to walk to Newbury Street and the Prudential Center with relative ease. There are also some good restaurants very close to this hotel. I noticed that there were a lot of other girlfriend getaway groups staying and even a bunch of guy friend getaway groups too. The only complaint I have is with breakfast, which we only had on Saturday morning. If you order off of the menu be prepared to wait an inordinate amount of time for a simple meal. I'd suggest getting the buffet instead.... it's a much better meal and deal anyway.

Great place to stay in Boston Just got back from 3 nights in Boston at the Radisson. Loved it! The hotel wasn't super fancy, but nice. Our room was BEAUTIFULLY clean everyday. Really exceptionally clean I would say. I was on a high floor with a great view of the city. Personally the balcony was a little scarey for me but that's my problem. Because I was attending a conference in a different hotel, I didn't have much contact with the staff but what I did have was friendly. The location was super!! good restaurants of a variety of cuisines all in the immediate area. Right in the theatre district. Just a couple blocks to Boston Common. A leisurely stroll to the Quincy market area (maybe 20 minutes very relaxed pace). I grabbed a sandwich from the cafe. It was fine. Also had the breakfast buffet one morning. It was good but not spectacular. I would have liked it a lot better had it been included (apparently they have a bed and breakfast deal I missed) rather than full price ( I think it was like $17). And I paid way less for my room than what I see here as average room price. I'll definitely stay here next time.
Great location, reasonable rooms       The view from our room at the Radisson Boston
Pleasant Stay Nice hotel, great location. The only damper on the room was there was no LCD TV and the desk and TV armoire were beaten up, otherwise the room, bed, bathroom and view were very nice.

Very Nice - Huge Room!! Lovely stay for 2 nights. The hotel was very clean and in a good location for us to do what we wanted to.We asked for, and got, an upper level room and the views were great. Some good restaurants within walking distance, DEFINATELY try Montien, the Thai restaurant that does the BEST crispy thai phad noodles EVER!!!!! also went to Jacob Wirth and that is the 2nd oldest pub in Boston!!

Good experience Stayed here with a conference, and had a very nice experience. The location was great, the concierge was fabulous. We walked three blocks to the Freedom trail, and were also near a subway stop and Boston Common. The hotel was in the Theater District, so when the baseball game was rained out, we were able to get last minute tix to the Blue Man Group a block from the hotel.The room was nice as well, and clean. The bed was great, we had fun playing with the sleep numbers.I was happy with the price of the hotel, booking at the conference rate, but would have questioned the price if we'd had to pay full rate. Enjoyed our stay.

Great rooms, great stay! We found this hotel to be ideal for our family. Since there are five of us, including 3 teenagers, we need two rooms when we travel, which can get pricey. We were given a terrific rate on both rooms and got adjoining rooms high up with a really great view of the city. We were impressed with the Sleep Number beds, the amount of room we had, and the cleanliness...a nice surprise. A great find in the heart of the Theatre District of Boston - within walking distance to everything. Only glitch: my husband misheard the woman at check-in advise him of our free breakfast.....we went to the cafe inside the hotel that she'd suggested, had a light meal from their buffet, and were presented with a check for over $70!! We asked at the front desk about having that discounted, since we weren't expecting that expense and since it was SOO high, but since we'd gotten a great deal on our rooms, they weren't able to reduce the charges. Oh, well. But we did love the hotel and the location and would definitely seek it out again!

Good location, disappointing exterior Given the close poximity of a number of stylish hotels in the same price category the Radisson should aim for a better first impression by doing something about the terrible facade, sprucing up its entrance and remodelling its drab lobby which looks like a 70s Holiday Inn.The room was adequate, the bathroom was in mint condition, and the beds were perfect - the best beds we have slept in ever.The balcony had not been cleaned in ages, but since the views were nothing to write home about anyway, that did not really matter, but somehow compounded the bad impression you have from the start when arriving at this hotel.
Very nice stay in the very centre of Boston       bathroom - spacious, clean and comfortable

Good Hotel - Great Location! I stayed for business and the conference I attended was on the 6th floor of the hotel so that is the main reason I chose this property. I stayed 9/16 to 9/18 at a rate of $239 plus taxes which was the conference block rate. I was very pleased with the room. It was average size on the 20th floor with a great view. The beds were comfortable (sleep number adjustable beds) and the furnishing were relatively modern. The bathroom looked nice although not that big. They leave a USA Today paper outside your door each morning. My main complaints with the room was no mini fridge and no soap dish/shelf in the shower so you had to bend down to grab your soap and shampoo. The outside of the hotel is not glamorous, nor is the lobby but that really didn't concern me. The pool was average size and they had a decent fitness center with a couple of treadmills and a couple of cross trainers both with personal color tvs. There are no weight machines and no free weights with the exception of a few dumbbells. The main thing that is great about this hotel is the location. You are right in the middle of the theater district and 2 blocks from Chinatown. Fanheuil Hall is about a 15 minute walk. Boston Common is a five minute walk and the closest T stop is the Boylston stop which is also 5 minutes from the hotel. One block away across the street is City Place which has a food court which includes Dunkin Donuts, Starbucks and Cold Stone along with some chain restaurants like PF Changs and Rock Bottom. Legal Seafoods is across the street (great seafood!!!) and McCormick and Schmicks is a block away which has great happy hour FOOD specials (be warned the alcohol is grossly overpriced - $5.25 for a Coors Light draft)Would stay here again in the future for pleasure if could get a better rate. I've heard that people have booked for less than $200 per night and I'd say if you can find that, it is a great deal.

good choice for business or tourism Stayed at the Radisson 3 nights on business, rooms are recently redone an are better than average.Good bathroom and showers, great beds, although TV鈥檚 are old style.Breakfast buffet OK, the Rustic Kitchen restaurant attached is excellent for dinner.Great concierge service, poor lifts (elevators) too slow!!

Good Location in Boston Stay: Aug 2008. Rate $170+taxes see below.Location: within easy walking distance (even with a wheelie case and aged 70!) from the MBTA T-system Boylston St station. (Get a Charlie-Card from Logan Airport-much cheaper and more interesting than a taxi-even arriving at 21:00 hrs.)Welcome friendly and cheerful. Dining-room staff cheerful and helpful.Good buffet breakfast but with sufficient choice for variation over three days; a la carte also available (but we had inclusive package via Internet booking). If you like two TVs on different channels and a simultaneous view of the traffic at Stuart St / Charles St crossing, sit at the natural-light end of the dining room鈥攐r on the terrace for traffic noise only; otherwise have greater peace in the other half of the room.Room on 22 Floor. Clean, some traffic noise (over-looked the road crossing; we had asked for a room not facing the road!-so minus points for this)鈥攂ut used earplugs. Surprisingly we found no fridge. Plenty of space for moving about and clothes storage. Huge bed (UK Super King/US King) with the option to change the hard-/softness of the mattress on the left and right sides independently.Free internet use in reception / lobby. Helpful local advice centre in lobby area. UK and other non-US visitors beware of prices: those quoted are without taxes (it tells you this) but the taxes are: State 5.7%, City 4%, CCF 2.75%, so you need to add 12.45% to the stated room price and allow for the normal US tipping expectations. If you want a hotel in the centre, without paying for luxuries you will not use (our usual choice), then this will meet your needs.The hotel is near enough for you to buy food from a market and then watch bats flying as you have an evening picnic on Boston Common just one block away. Not perfect but a good choice, we鈥檇 choose it again.

Great Location for Seeing the Sights I stayed in the Radisson Hotel Boston the weekend of 9/12-14/2008. The location is great. It's just a couple blocks from the subway station, which is also very easy to navigate. The room we had was on the 19th floor and very nice and spacious w/ a balcony that overlooked part of the city. The concierge was extremely helpful with directions and handed us printed directions to our destinations. It rained most of the time we were there and the doorman handed us umbrellas on our way out every time. The value was great because I used my Radisson Points (10,000 each night for a total of 20,000) and got a discounted room rate of $135/nt. This hotel was running above $330/nt so this was a bargin! I would highly suggest staying here. The service makes all the difference!

Superb Location, Nice Rooms I picked this hotel based on good reviews and a reasonable price (under $200) for Labor Day Weekend. I was not disappointed and would stay here again in a heartbeat. We had a room on the 23rd floor with a balcony and view of the Prudential Center. The room was extremely spacious and very clean. There are numerous eateries to choose from across the street- Legal Seafoods, Maggianos, McCormick  Schmick, RockBottom, Bennigans. For a quick breakfast, Au Bon Pain, Dunkin Donuts and Starbucks. There is a 7-11 one block away. The Boston Common, T stop  shops on Newbury street are about a block  a half away. It is in the heart of the Theatre district.Pluses:Location, Location, LocationSleep number bedsGreat deep tub for soaking and rain shower headIn room safeFabulous housekeepingHelpful bellmenMinusesElevators could use some cleaningExpensive parkingPricey in hotel restaurant

Good Time in Boston We stayed at the Radisson, near the Common. This was a pretty good location, close to a Trolley Stop  not too far to walk to the Pru Center. We arrived a little early at 1:30pm but were able to check into our rooms. We were two couples  wanted to be in rooms on the same floor with a good view. The reception agent (not very friendly  almot rude) advised us that there was only one room availabe to meet that request. so we ended up on a lower floor. The room itself was fine - we enjoyed the Sleep Number beds - kept very clean. The maid, however, did not discard the water from the melted ice in the bucket for two days. Breakfast in the restuarant was OK except for the LONG wait for our food that we ordered off the menu vs. choosing the buffet. The Consierge was NOT helpful at all. I called down to the desk for help with a dinner reservation. He was obviously busy with other guests and asked if he could call me back in my room which he NEVER did. I ended up making the calls myself. Overall, Boston is a great place to visit. We had some great meals at Fleming's (steak house), Top of the Hub and Artu (Italian) in the North End. Even though we're Yankee fans, the tour of Fenway was good. Try to make plans ahead for the Duck Tour as it was sold out on the day we wanted to go.
fabulous location Thanks to the reviews I selected this hotel.Great location, staff very helpful and the rooms were betterthan expected. I would stay here again.

COMFY but with Construction Views My Husband  I along with our 2 month old stayed at the Radisson for 4 nights Aug 8-11 2008. We flew in and arrived at 11 AM without reservations and were so surprised that we could not only have a room with a high floor (23rd) but that we could go ahead and check in and have our room at 11 AM. The lady who checked us in was very pleasant. The bellhop was very courteous and he even gave us lunch and dinner recommendations as he walked our luggage up for us. It was such a nice treat to be able to take a nap while our baby did right when we got there. The room was very nice and clean and large enough for the 3 of us. We got a king room on the 23rd floor, but were a bit dissapointed that our gorgeous view was of large construction of a high rise building directly in front of the hotel. They started early too, like at 7 am banging, although it was a distant sound. It was still a sound not all pleasant to the ears. The linens on the bed were very comfy with the down. The maids were very generous and gave us PLENTY of towels and washcloths. With a 2 month old, we needed them! The maids arrived promplty between 10 and 11 am and this worked out perfect for us as we were always leaving at that time. One thing that was a dissapointment was there IS NO FRIDGE OR MICROWAVE. Which I'm sure is a reason to drum up business in the hotel bar and restaraunt, but a bit of a shock as most hotels of this stature have them, their food should speak for itself right? We never ate at the restaraunt as it seemed a bit overpriced by the looks of the food. We usually always try out the hotel restaraunts but didn't want to this time for that reason. However Legal Seafood is directly across the street and also the California pizza kitchen and another mediteranian restaraunt across the breezeway that was to die for! The concierge should recieve a RAISE-- he was EXCELLENT he booked us everyday with something! We went to Cape Cod, booked Dinner reservations, Booked taxi's-- He tooked care of everything and really made us love our vacation! He also recommended his favorite lunch place--The Intermintent Tavern--GREAT!!!! They had awesome food-- not much of a place from the looks, but you must GO!! the food was lovely. THANK YOU!!One thing that was unnacceptable though was the business center--only had 2 computers--in which teenagers who had walked in off the street were using to play solitare  get on myspace. I had to print out our boarding passes on the morning of our flight and I had to get the concierge to help me with it. That was VERY nice of him. I think the business center should be monitered by room key if you ask me!For the Money this was an awesome place to stay, but next time well make sure we have a fridge and microwave--as with a baby we sure would have had an easier stay, especially storing milk.

The Ideal Place To Stay In Boston! Located in the heart of Boston, this Radisson hotel is an above average hotel. An attentive, friendly and professional staff greet you in the welcoming lobby. We were taken to our room which was big,spotlessly clean and furnished as advertised with a Sleep Number Bed. OMG! Just the bed was reason enough to love this place! We had our own private balcony with a gorgeous view of central Boston.There are tons of restaurants in the area, access to public transportation, Boston Common and Boston Public Garden are only 2 blocks away. If you need directions or trolley tickets, it is all available at the front desk. Excellent value for your money if you don't count the insane price they charge you for parking. It is my only complaint. They should be ashamed of themselves charging 33 dollars a day to park your car! There are many public lots close by that charge much less so be forewarned.
Great location - couldn't have asked for better!       Sunset view from hotel room on the 21st floor!

Great Location, Loved the Hotel Our family stayed in this hotel from July 28-August 3, 2008. We picked this hotel because they let you reserve a room on their website with 5 people in a room, because of the reasonable price and because of the great location, in the theater district, near the parks and subway. We had 2 adults and 3 children, one of them in a crib. I checked the hotel rates a week before we left at the Radisson website and got an even cheaper rate with no cancellation penalty. We paid an average of just under $200 a night.The room was average size with a balcony, we had room 2007 on the 20th floor, with a wonderful view of the Back Bay skyline and the John Hancock building. The room was very quiet when the balcony sliding door was closed. The bathrooms were pristine and clean, looked like brand new tile and fixtures, the shower was the rainfall type shower head, wonderful.The bellmen and concierge were helpful with everything from finding a drugstore and a cab to finding a screwdriver so we could change batteries in a toy. Our toilet had a problem one day and a building engineer was in our room within 5 minutes and had it fixed in 10 minutes.The other reviews were accurate in describing the nearby food court and 7-11 convenience store, both in the adjacent block. We were only a few blocks from China Town as well. I recommend Legal Seafood across the street as well as Finale, an outstanding dessert restaurant in the Boston Park Plaza Hotel building 2 blocks away. Also in the nearby City Place food court is the Gray Line office, from which we booked BeanTown Trolley Tours and a Gray Line All-day Cape Cod Tour. The Radisson is a stop on the BeanTown Trolley, as is City Place, another convenience.

Nice Overnight Stay I arrived at noon for a one night stay at the Radisson. I was pleasantly surprised to find they had a room available. Check-in was quick and cordial. I got to my room on the 9th floor and found it as it should be- clean, up-to-date and comfortable. The view was of the indoor pool and treadmills in the fitness center on the floor below. The bathroom was large enough, with the sink inside the bathroom, however, there was only an inch between the door and the toilet. I found that odd, since the bathroom was large enough- it's the placement that was off. The bed was comfortable. The room was spacious. There were two easy chairs and a table, in addition to the desk, two beds, and chest with a TV.
