We called the front desk again at 1:30am and asked if they had any earplugs and was just told no. If you stay at this hotel, make sure your room is not across from Mr. Dooley's Bar and higher up than the 5th floor.

ruined our trip I will not detail the problems we had with this hotel but they ruined what could have been a great time, there was a mess up with our booking which the desk was not very helpful with at all, the cleanliness of the room left alot to be desired, and the bar staff have some scam going which i couldnt quite figure out and neither could there boss, i will say the concierge and door staff were very helpful. if staying in this area then the sports bar next to the aquarium t station is well worth a visit, decent drinks and good food with friendly staff.

Worst Experience If you are a Federal employee, I'd advise you to stay away from this property. I arrived on Monday night for a three night stay while attending training. I provided my official identification and travel orders. The desk clerk told me that this information wouldn't be sufficient since my travel orders were e-mailed to me, I didn't have a tax exempt number (?), and I didn't have printed travel orders on official stationary, sign by my department head describing the purpose and length of my stay. I told him that he was wrong. He said that he'd check with his accounting office and leave me a message the next day. Apparently there was no one after four who could deal with this dilema. When I went back the next day, the clerk told me that the accounting person had called during the day when he wasn't working and asked if I'd like to speak with this person.  The next day the person in charge of my training spoke with the accounting person. A resolution was reached. If I provided a Form 9828, they would not charge sales tax for my stay. That afternoon, upon returning to the hotel, I provided the desk with the completed form with the direction to bring it to the accounting person. Upon checking out, the charges were still there.

Claustrophobic room; rude staff, great location I am surprised to see all the reviews of this hotel describing their large rooms. Our experience was not pleasant. We came to Boston to celebrate St Patrick's Day with my sister who lives in Boston. My sister and her son came with us as we checked in. A rude young woman at the desk smirked to my husband in mock surprise oh, your family is very large, implying that we were trying to stuff extra people into the room. We should have left the hotel at that point! Our room was very small (even by Manhattan standards!) and very dark- overlooking an interior alleyway. Our ceiling light had a naked bulb -- I asked for a globe to cover it as soon as we entered the room - but when we returned 4 hours later it was still not done. After a second request they finally fixed it. The tub drain did not work properly either. We picked this hotel for the excellent location,but I will never stay there again. Our overall impression was that it was an old, dark, cramped and aging building with creaking elevators and rude staff. There are other hotels in the vicinity that are a better choice.

Superb staff and great rooms! Stayed here for a convention in early March. Great view of Boston Harbor from my room on the 15th floor. Huge room with super comfy bed. Very quiet! Hotel bar was posh and the drink prices reflected that, but it is downtown Boston. Hotel bar closed at 11:30pm, but the staff was very helpful in helping us find some cheaper, more relaxed places to hang out that were very close by. Even on weeknights some of the local dance/karaoke places were hoppin'. Had room service for breakfast and it arrived quickly and everything was still hot. Only complaint was the limited table space (small round table next to bed full of stuff and a cluttered desk). Not really convenient for eating in your room. Everything was very clean and the shower and bath fixtures looked brand new (Kohler). Elegant lobby and brass finishings everywhere. After checking out (and reaching home 5 hours later), I realized that I left something. The cleaning staff could not find it, but said they would check in the laundry area. Got a call the next day. Great service!

Boston in the snow What a great hotel, wonderful city everyone so friendly. It snowed on our first day but that did not stop us, staff at the hotel were so so helpful, with directions and maps. Restaurant was very nice with staff on hand to advise on all aspects of food choices. I stayed here with my daughter (who is 18) and even she enjoyed it and we know how teenagers are so hard to please. I would go back tomorrow if I could. Complmentary coffee and warm apple cider were available in the foyer during the course of the day.This hotel was in a great location and all attractions in easy reach, and walking distance.. I did think that being in the financial district it may well of been very business orientated, but believe me what a great hotel.
Excellent Service and Great Room Great service and huge suites bigger than an Embassy Suite but same idea of the two separate rooms. Within walking distance for many Boston options.

Nice Hotel in Good Location Stayed at the Hilton for 3 nights, A nice sized room with a King Bed which was amazingly comfy.Was very Close to fenuil hall and quincey Market and near the waterfront too (Boston is quite a close packed city).

We'll be back again We were a group of five girls from Northern Ireland travelling to Boston for a Christmas shopping trip. We had booked a triple and double room. On arrival we were shown to 2 identical rooms each with 2 double beds (queen sized for the UK readers, huge for single sleepers but tiny for 2 adults sharing); we mentioned to the wonderful bell boy we'd booked a triple and a double and we (the 3 sharing) were easily upgraded to a king suite with sofa bed. The rooms were well kept, clean and with adequate space, with lovely crabtree and Evelyn toilettries The staff we fantastic in the hotel; I had problems using a $500 travellers cheque in one shop (not accepted in most of Boston due to a freud problem), yet the conceierge went totally out of his way to find a store who would cash it for me, he was amazing, thanks Charles. The reception was welcoming with wood panneling and seasonal Christmas decor, enhanced by complementary hot chocolate or mulled apple available from mid afternoon onwards. The restaurant provided lovely food, but it was was pricey: there is an excellent Irish pub for evening meals and deli's for breakfast on the door step though. The location was great, the city is so walkable, Quincys Markets is 3 minutes walk away, yet the hotel was quiet- some of us who had previously stayed in NewYork for shopping trips were amazed at how silent the rooms were at night, and how quiet the streets were. We were so happy, we're already booked again for Dec 2008 which says it all!

Great Stay Booked a package through Trailfinders, great deal (usually book everything myself). On check in had been upgraded to a suite. Wonderful service, couldn't fault anything. Hotel location good near everything we wanted to see. Would stay again .

Great stay at the Hilton Stayed at the Hilton for 3 nights up to 30 Dec. We were in Boston to attend a family wedding and had a total of 8 rooms between 14 people which were conveniently all located on the same floor. Really liked the hotel, the room and bathroom were spacious, clean and well kept. As others have noted room size is really pot luck, we had a pretty decent double room, however my brother who was staying on his own had a room about twice as large as ours! In any case our room size was perfectly adequate for our needs. Beds were large and comfortable and there was a lovely selection of toiletries in the bathroom. Our room was kept clean and well tided and all staff we encountered were friendly and helpful. Some of my family who were flying back to Ireland on 31 Dec asked for and were given a late checkout free of charge. Location is pretty quiet but there are still a number of restaurants closeby and you can either walk or take a short taxi journey to all sights.There were a couple of irritations during our stay. The water in the rooms cost a hefty $4.50 per bottle. Arriving off a long flight from Germany we didn't have much opportunity to go out and buy cheaper water, so ending up paying $9 for approx. 1 litre of water! In saying that the next evening when we got back to our room, we'd been given a couple of bottles of complimentary water, which was a nice gesture. My fiance was keen to check his emails whilst we were there. The hotel was advertising a rate of $9.99 for 24 hours in-room internet access via the TV (there was a keyboard attached). On signing up for this however it didn't work and when we rang the concierge they informed us that it was unavailable and that we should use the internet in the Business Center at a rate of $10 for 10 mins (which we didn't)! Other than these couple of minor issues our stay was very enjoyable and I would definitely recommend the hotel to other travellers to Boston. We would definitely stay here again.

Nice but some frustrations I wanted to love the Hilton, and in some ways, I did, but in others, we were disappointed. My husband and I just came back from enjoying two days there relaxing over New Year's, and there were positives. Our room was clean and large by city standards, but I agree with earlier posts that size of room is completely luck of the draw based on what I saw on the floor diagram. The bed was very comfortable, and the location of the hotel was great for being out and about in the city for First Night -- close enough to get there fast but far enough away to avoid the worst of the noise. The staff was great -- helpful and courteous, though we were disappointed that our request for an upper-floor room was not duly noted until we pointed it out, and then we were only put on floor 9 (of a 15 floor hotel). Our room maid was wonderful, however. Breakfast in the hotel restaurant was fabulous -- a really good buffet though it was part of a package for us. Not cheap if you have to pay separately, but worth it.And that brings me to the negatives. The hotel nickels and dimes you with charges for things that in other hotels might be part of the high rate charged. Wireless internet is on a per-day charge, and if you instead decide that you'll just use the hotel's Business Center, be prepared to pay a minimum of a $10 charge then $1 per minute after 10 minutes. This seemed ludicrous to us who just wanted to check our e-mail. The bottles of water in the room were available for a mere $4.50 each (we bought some of our own nearby for a lot less), and a $80 charge for dinner in the hotel bar when we only had a few drinks and two light entrees seemed really high, even by hotel restaurant standards. In general, it seemed that the four-star rating was not really warranted given how many of the little extras one expects at four-star locales involved extra charges here. In addition, there were some aging issues -- the sheet that had a hole along the edge where it was folded over on our bed; the scratchy towels that were too old to still be soft and fluffy; the slightly worn wood on the furniture like the arm chair and entertainment center. The room was also quite noisy, in part due to the expected city sounds, but also due to how easily we could here our loud neighbors across the hall as they came and went.It was not a bad experience -- in fact, we were quite happy when all was said and done. But with a little more inclusiveness in their rates and some upgrading of slightly aging fixtures, this hotel could more fully embody a four-star experience.

Fantastic food! Booked through Trailfinders and when we asked what the 'Trailfinders Bonus' quoted on the voucher meant ... we promptly got upgraded to a suite! Fabulous room with the biggest and most comfortable bed we've ever slept in! Also very quiet. The buffet breakfast isn't cheap, but it is delicious and has something for everyone.We also had 2 evening meals in the restaurant - these too were delicious. The restaurant staff were excellent.A good location as only a short step from the harbour and from Feneuil Hall market. Would definitely book again.
Lit confortable, tr猫s propre et tr猫s tranquille.   showReview(18881036, 'full');

Great Service and Big Room Our stay at the Fairmont was almost perfect. The staff were the most courteous and helpful of any hotel at which we've stayed. The concierge gave great recommendations on dining and things to do in the area and check in and out was smooth and easy. The room (a standard room with two queen beds) was much larger than rooms at comparably priced hotels and we really enjoyed a relaxing time.Two reasons prohibit me from giving this hotel 5 stars. (I won't even mention the $21 a night parking. I realize that this is the case pretty much anywhere, but it's highway robbery. At least the valet service was excellent and efficient). First of all - why charge for high speed internet when you're already getting $120 for the room (not counting parking)? That seems a bit greedy and unnecesary. Secondly, they charged me for a local phone call! It only amounted to fifty cents, but still. In a hotel this nice and service oriented you would think that internet and local calls should be included.Overall though - this was a great stay, we fully intend to return, and heartily recommend the Fairmont to anyone.
Professional Staff        23rd Floor King Room

Would absolutely stay again We booked an air/hotel package through Travelocity with the purpose of seeing the King Tut exhibit at the Dallas Museum. Booked a regular King room and were pleased and surprised at check-in to be upgraded to a suite. The desk agent told us that he didn't have any King bed rooms left so was upgrading us to a king suite. Strange as the bartender later told us they were only at 12% capacity and we never saw a single other guest on our south tower elevators in 3 days. Hey, no complaints! The suite is wonderful. Nice walk in closet, sofas (one pulls out) and eating table in the sitting room with flat screen tv, large desk and sitting table in the bedroom with another large flat screen. The only complaint is with the design of the bathroom where the door nearly hits the toilet. You'd think that in the design of a suite they could've found another couple of feet to steal from the bedroom to make the bath more comfortable. Still, this is NOT a big deal.Service was incredible throughout. Very nice concierges who were helpful as was the rest of the staff. The bar never had more than 4 other guests in it. They told us that this is the low season for their main business which is conventions. Maybe that's why it was so nice and quiet. We were a little grumpy about the nickel and dime-ing that happens with the internet service. $13.95 to connect (wireless or wired) in the room. Then because I don't have a printer, I had to use the hotel's business center to print our boarding passes -- another $7.99 for those 6 minutes. At the price per night, I'd expect this to be less.The restaurant is one block from the museums which was perfect for us, and one block from the free McKinney Ave Trolley which can take you uptown a bit to more restaurants and shopping. The downtown area where the hotel is has zero restaurants for breakfast that we could find. If you don't mind walking, there are several good restaurants within about 1/2 mile. The very pricey but excellent Stephan Pyles is one block away. The Dallas Fish Market is also great (about 1/2 mile). We also walked to the JFK museum, about 3/4 mi. I think, and on the way the Village Corner Bakery is a good breakfast spot. We did this trip without a rental car which is doable but ONLY if you like/don't mind walking...a lot...for everything. This area has little but office buildings. We would stay here again for the service and quality.

Even better the second time! This was our second stay at the Fairmont. The level of service here is excellent. This stay we booked a Gold level room and felt it was really worth it. We had a corner room that was very nicely decorated in a more contemporary style than the room on our first stay. The bathroom door wasn't typical, it was more like a pocket door. There was a HUGE shower that was very enjoyable. The bathroom also had a makeup mirror, which I missed in the regular room. Still had a big walk in closet. The evening appetizers and morning breakfast were nice. Drinks are available but not included in the price of the room. We enjoyed the in room Nespresso machine as well as the one in the lounge. Before our trip I emailed the hotel for restaurant ideas. The concierge staff responded quickly and very professionally to our requests. They made all our dinner reservations for us, so we had no worries about where to go for dinner. We had one dinner in the hotel's Pyramid restaurant. The service was outstanding. The wine steward was a great help and provided some great information. My husband thought the filet he had for dinner was one of the best ever. My lamb needed a bit of work, but was cooked as I ordered. We shared a charcuterie appetizer and it was a good choice. We didn't order a dessert as the hotel had delivered a pice of cake to our room to celebrate my birthday. Every staff person at this hotel greeted us warmly, and it didn't seem forced as I would have expected. The housekeeping staff left me a thank you note for leaving a dollar tip on the bed every morning and evening. It's hard to find any real problems at this hotel. It is an older property, but the service is more than enough to make up for that. I will certainly stay here again and I will book the Gold room for future stays as well. Thank you Fairmont Dallas!!

First Class Service We purchased a $299 package which included dinner at the Pyramid for 2, free valet parking and 2 VIP tickets to Tutankhamun exhibit at Dallas Museum of Art. The room is supposed to be a suite but we realized after we'd unpacked that we were not booked into a suite. The front desk offered to move us but we had to get to dinner so we asked for free room service for breakfast and late check-out, both of which we received. The air conditioner was not working and it was an unseasonable 75 degrees outside; an engineer came up to fix it and we froze the rest of our overnight stay. The shower heads are for short folks, although the bed was comfortable and the 14th floor room was very quiet. The VIP tickets, as promised, got us ahead on line so that we had less than a 5-minute wait even though there were groups of school children at 9 AM! Although this is not a first-rate hotel in terms of accommodation, it has the finest staff we have encountered in a long time and we stay at many 4 and 5-star hotels in the U.S. and abroad. To a person, every staff member we spoke to was happy and gracious. We complained about our room service espresso--weak and cold--and in 5 minutes we received replacements that were both hot and excellent.

You MUST stay at the Fairmont! By far one of the best hotel experiences I have ever had. Not sure where to begin because everything was superb. Great location within walking distance of many places. Right around the corner is the fantastic restaurant Stephan Pyles. JFK Museum just a 10-minute walk, as is the entire Historic District with many other restaurants. The staff here goes out of their way to welcome you and greet you every day, from Front Desk people to Housekeeping, etc. The rooms are spotless and well appointed. The beds are so comfortable you might not want to get up in the morning! The hotel bar and restaurant, Pyramid, has great food for breakfast, lunch, or dinner. Or if you'd rather like something light there is a Starbucks off the lobby to get a coffee and pastry in the morning. I honestly cannot think of anything that was negative. I would not stay anywhere else in Dallas.

Great Service Had a very nice 4 day stay. The hotel is older and if you look closely you'll notice a few nicks and scratches around, but generally nice facilities. Everyone was very nice - front desk, reception, concierge, valet, housekeeping, bar. I was very impressed with the consistently friendly service. Oh, one complaint was the low-flow showerhead. Yuck. But what do I know, maybe Dallas is having a drought.The aquarium was an easy walk (2 or 3 blocks) and was great. The West End neighborhood was also an easy walk and had lots of restaurant options (lot of steakhouses, no surprise, but some other options too).Would definitely stay here again.

Nice stay I stayed at this hotel for 3 nights while attending a conference at the Dallas Convention Center. I was very satisfied with my choice. The service at this hotel is top-notch. My room was very nice 鈥?my favorite part was the large walk-in closet. Inside this big closet was an oversized safe that fit both my camcorder in its bag and my camera. The TV was a large flat screen. The bathroom was a little small and the tub and toilet could be updated, but the vanity was very nice. There were two plush robes available to use. I had to call the front desk right after I arrived to report a problem with the toilet flushing properly and someone arrived in less than 10 minutes. Housekeeping did an outstanding job, room service was good, and the concierge was always very helpful. The buffet breakfast was very good, although it lacked a good selection of fresh fruit. I have only two minor complaints about the room. At night you can hear the elevator running. If you sleep lightly as I do, it may bother you at first. I did get used to it. The room only had one electrical outlet that I could access. When I needed to use the iron or recharge my cell phone, etc., I had to get down on my hands and knees and crawl under the desk to plug it in.This hotel is within walking distance to many things, including the Plaza of the Americas, the Dallas Museum of Art, the Dallas World Aquarium, the West End, and the Sixth Floor Museum. I got a special rate of $155 per night and it was definitely a good price. I do think I would be hesitant to pay the rack rate of $300-$400. I only say this because the room is nice but not especially luxurious.

Good location-great beds we got a great deal through Hotwire for Texas/ou weekend. the hotel is in a great location-only a few blocks from West End and Victory Park. The lobby was very nice with a relaxing atmosphere in the bar area. we didn't use the pool, but we had a great view of it from our room and it looked nice. The bed was one of the best i have ever slept in. The only downside was parking was $21. that is a bit steep in my opinion. I would stay there again if i needed a downtown hotel.

Nice Location Downtown...Charming Excellent, solid, business hotel in Downtown Dallas. Walking distance to many great neighborhoods and very close to the Historic District where the JFK Museum is found. Lots of entertainment in that district too. Right across the street is a very high end restaurant called Charlie Palmer. Pricey but well worth it! Also within a 1/4 mile walk of the Dallas Arts District. Dallas Museum is worth it. Great exhibits...nice collection. Modern Art museum is quite quite cool.The rooms are fine, but not really large. Kind of reminds you of an old style hotel from pre-war. Rooms are in good shape, clean, and latest amenities.Stayed here for a conference.

Fairmont Dallas - the BEST luxury hotel in town! Booked one of their new Fairmont Gold Suites via Expedia.com, and was a little worried if the pictures and descriptions were 'too good to be true', but we felt the rate was appropriate for a club level - type suite at a luxury hotel (around $400/night). What can I say... I was SOOO impressed with the entire experience! We were escorted to the Gold floor as soon as we got out of our car at valet, and introduced to our private concierge at the Lounge. We were checked in, had dinner reservations made, and got a snack, within minutes of arriving - WOW! The suite was worth every cent - completely brand new everything. Loved the bed - didn't want to get out ever! Having access to the private lounge was the best part - we made it our 'home-away-from-home' over the next few days. My husband used it to get away from me for a few hours to do some work (ha ha), but it worked out nice for me because I used that time to relax and watch some sappy girl movies. The restaurant was fantastic - food quality, service, wine list - we were happy with everything at Pyramid. The location is perfect - I read some other reviews saying how there is nothing to do in the area, but those people must have been blind! The Dallas Art Museum and Nasher Sculpture Museum are 1 block from hotel, and we even walked to the Victory Park for dinner and a show at House of Blues the last night. Everything was perfect - you MUST stay at this lovely hotel!

THIS is a Fairmont hotel????? My niece got married at the Fairmont and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. I suppose the wedding part went ok. The Bride was happy and that is what mattered. BUT if Fairmonts are supposed to be in the upper echelon of hotels, this one falls EXTREMELY SHORT.We arrived after check in time the day of the wedding (about 3:20) and had 2 rooms booked. I would guess there were about 25 - 30 rooms booked for this wedding. One room was ready and the other was not. Same thing happened to my brother, one room was ready and one was not. We had plans to go to dinner before the wedding at a restaurant nearby. We waited in our sons' room for our room to be ready......nothing.....nothing. I finally called down about 4:30 as I needed to change clothes for dinner and wanted my room. They said they would put it on a priority cleaning status and that it would be at least another 30 minutes and that they would call (shouldn't they just bring me my keys???). Had to scrap our plan for dinner and just go grab a bite at the hotel bar. ( Mediocre at best). Mother of hte bride walked by and asked how things were and if we were settled....we told her we were still waiting for our room....she went to desk and got a manager and came back with keys. The room had just been cleaned! So we got into the room about 5:30. A/C did not work well at all. Room was hot even though it was set on 72....there was no way the room was 72. We turned it down and turned up the fan speed. Bathroom temp was unbearable, had to bring my makeup/hair supplies out to the desk in order to have some decent ventilation and cool air. Sons' room was the same as temp goes...as was my brother's rooms. Was a sweaty mess by the time we left for the wedding downstairs.......lovely way to feel!Room was still warm when we came back up.....front desk staff was not helpful.Would NEVER stay here again!

Pleased with the Fairmont Dallas! Overall, we were very pleased with our recent stay at the Dallas Fairmont, located in downtown Dallas. The hotel is very clean, and our room was spacious with floor to ceiling windows (room 1910). The pool was good, but not spectacular; it could use a little modernization. I was very impressed with the level of service. The staff, from the valet to the concierge, were all extremely friendly and helpful. I appreciated that they even remembered my name and greeted me on arrival and departure. We ordered room service for twice and were very impressed both times. I emailed Phillip, one of the concierges, prior to our arrival with some questions and his responses were helpful and efficient. Keep in mind that the area around the hotel is pretty dead on weekends. We struggled finding a place within walking distance to have breakfast. We don't travel to Dallas very often, but we would definitely stay at the Fairmont again.

Recommend as a thumbs up This was a Very Good Experience. The front desk personal friendly  helpful, Concierge desk extremely helpful and accommodating, rooms clean  quite spacious, and comfortable beds. The reservation department was informative and easy to work with. The media center had one printer down and it added a minor expense. There is fine dining and food available at the bar area, however there was no moderate restaurant. Definitely would recommend and stay there on my next Dallas trip.

Fairmont is just okay I stayed at the Fairmont for a business conference. From what I heard, Fairmont is supposed to be a superb hotel.That was not the case. It is run down and is in need of some updates. They had a few nice amenities, like a flat screen TV, and large rooms, but that was about it. The desk only had one electrical plug for my computer and the bathroom was nice, but needed some deep cleaning. The clock radio was from the 80's. I also noticed some spots on the sheets. They were clean, but had permanent spots. I wouldn't pay that much to stay there for a vacation. It's not worth paying that much for the name. Go down the street to the Westin.The hotel is also in a neighborhood without much to do. There were a few nice restaurants, but it is definitely an 'office' area of town.

Exceptional Hotel The Fairmont Dallas is a great hotel, and for $149/night, a decent value. I highly recommend it to anyone staying in Dallas.Facilities: The lobby is upscale and never too crowded. They have a nice pool  gym, as well as an upscale restaurant. A starbucks opened the day I checked out.Rooms: Very comfortable beds and nice bathroom with ample space. They even had a walk-in closet. My only complaint is that the rooms could be bigger. It was a tight squeeze with 2 beds in it.Food: I ate at a few catered events and it was very good compared to most other hotel food I have had in the past. Service: Was great!! Everyone there was super helpful, room service was a breeze. I even had a small problem with the bill and it was corrected quickly with no questions asked.
Mixed bag: Lovely Room but...       Fairmont Gold Floor suite living room

Excellent Experience I booked this hotel via the hotel website and came up on a really good deal. It was a 3rd night free deal. So I paid $99 a night for the first 2 nights. The hotel was very nice and a good location downtown. It was actually the weekend of the Dallas/Green Bay football game. The staff was very helpful and I just really enjoyed the hotel. The bed was super comfortable. I would highly recommend The Fairmont, Dallas TX.

Repeat Customer! I stayed at the Dallas Fairmont 3 years ago, and it's still as good as it was then. Fantastic location...Walking distance to the art district and JFK memorial and plenty of good dinning. Rooms are very comfortable, clean and quiet and the service is friendly and quick. I ate downstairs at the buffet, and it was really good. All food was warm and fresh. Would be nice if they allowed members free access to the business center (internet), but that's a minor thing, and overall you can't miss with this hotel.

Fantastic Fairmont Location is fantastic - heart of the Art district in downtown Dallas - a mile from the happening spots in the evening at Mcinney Ave; connected to the underground from the lobby of the hotel (was a boon for me as my place of business was 3 blocks away and was walking distance and the underground tunnel system was very convenient and comfortable and safe); for the fitness fanatics, register yourself online in the President's club Loyalty program and get free wireless access and the 24 fitness club (with free apparel once you move up - 10 night stays in a calendar year)In-house restaurant is on the expensive side ($50 and up for a decent dinner), but they do have a cafe that has a limited menu; outside there are a couple of steakhouses within walking distance.Outstanding friendly service at the concierge, front desk, and efficient housekeeping.Impeccable interiors, flat screen tvs in all rooms that I stayed in. Their loyalty progam web interface sucks big time with the Canadian counterparts lagging far behind in updates and transparency of your credits/earnings. You really have no clue of what you earn and they are extremely sloppy with crediting you accurately for the extras...but, the comfortable beds and outstanding service  location makes up for all of that.

High noise levels and tired rooms mar good service It sounded like an unmissable opportunity -- a combination of two Fairmont upgrade certificates and a last-minute cancellation at the hotel meant I obtained an enormous king bed suite for the equivalent of $150 a night instead of the $350 a night it should have cost. I should have known it was too good to be true.I often wonder whether the management at hotels actually spend the night there occasionally to see what guests go through. If the Fairmont by chance does this, it's been some time since the last try-out. They need to take a look at this property.First impressions are good. It's in an excellent location downtown and the lobby is as plush and impressive as you'd expect from a Fairmont. The service was good. Unfortunately, the room wasn't the same. It was the size of a small European country with a large sitting room and an enormous bedroom. The furnishings looked a tad tired and for some bizarre reason the insides of all the windows were soaking, so the first noise I head was a gentle drip-drip of water dripping on to the carpet. The bathroom was small and the tub was miniscule, no longer than about four and a half feet, so I had real trouble getting washed. And this in what was undoubtedly supposed to be one of the best rooms in the hotel.Worse was to come. I was on the 21st floor of the south tower in a room that looked out both over a highway and some sort of industrial facility (or a massive block of air conditioning units) which churned out an amazing amount of noise. I quickly fled the bedroom and took refuge on the sofa bed in the sitting room, which of course happened to be next to the elevator machinery. So I slept badly all three nights.Everywhere there are signs of people asleep on the job. The TV turned on with the greatest of difficulty (I had to press the button with both thumbs) and when I called downstairs to ask about the handy Internet on the TV screen function the person at the other end said Oh, I've got a note here, it doesn't work.According to the room guide you could either have a formal breakfast in the restaurant or something less formal in the lounge downstairs. Nothing was on offer in the lounge for the three days I was there. That said, the restaurant breakfast was very good (as tends to be the case with Fairmont) and I consider $18.50 for an unlimited hot buffet in the morning a great offer. Dinner in the restaurant was pretty good too.A hint -- don't bother paying the daily $20 valet parking charge. There are plenty of parking meters and lots very close to the hotel.If I came back I'd insist on a room well away from the noisy side of the hotel. That is, if I come back. I think I might try somewhere else in Dallas the next time I'm in town.

Fair Enough Fairmont We stayed here for 2 nights and had booked a smoking room yeah i know how bad it is but well we were on holidays and the option was there. I found the check in staff quiet abrupt, she growled that firstly she did'nt think they took travellers cheques and that she did'nt have a smoking room because they were busy, fair enough but i had gone to the trouble of phoning to enquire about both issuses and was told neither was a problem. The receptionist stomped around because i had a few traveller cheques to sign and then gave me a key and i had to ask her what floor, i found her attitude a bit crap and i was after an 11 hour flight with stopover and delays. The room was nice but small and the bed was small for a kingsize but squash in and it was comfy. We had a corner room so maybe avoid this type. The bathroom was small but spotless with nice selection of toilitries and towels. Concierge desk was a breath of fresh air very polite and helpful. The hotel itself is lovely a bit of old fashioned glamour in a handy location quiet close to Dealey Plaza and there is tourist office also near Dealey Plaza which was convient .Breakfast outside the hotel is mission impossible,however if you walk towards Dealey Plaza there is a carpark on open ground and on it in a corner is a strange almost invisible little blue and white hut which was fab...looks aren't everything as you stand outside,my husband has a serious food allergy so we can't just eat anywhere. For restaurants there are a few nice ones just 4/5 minutes stroll from the hotel and they are lovely.Not a lot to do downtown at the weekends its a bit deserted. Overall we had a good time ,hotel is nice and well kept

Don't Stay Here! Horrible Experience - booked and prepaid through expedia and was booted out upon arrive due to overbooking. Unprofessional and rude front desk staff - dishonest. Hotel totally run down not worth a 2 star rating. Three Cheers to Expedia staff for great work at finding a wonderful 5 star hotel to replace this loser.

Very pleasant This is my third Fairmont and certainly the best so far. Like all Fairmont hotels (as far as I can tell) the bathroom was surprisingly small; however, the bedroom was huge, especially for the miserly $279/nt that I paid for it. The rooms are as dully conservative as you would expect for a business hotel of this type, but they are at least tasteful and up-to-date, not to mention immaculately maintained. The hotel's restaurants and bars are very pleasant and the staff are efficient and charming. There is nothing extraordinary about this hotel, but it is a pleasant place to spend a night or two.

Comfortable, clean, friedndly stay! I was booked here for a convention we are on so although I could have stayed at other hotels, this place was more convenient so we decided to be here.After I booked I read reviews and I like that a place can have so many opinions from 1 to 5 stars but it makes me nervous when so many are negative.I have to say that this stay has been NOTHING but pleasant.The staff calls me Mr...... The room service last night was short of excellent only because we felt the ham  cheese croissant should have been served warm, but my stak sandwhich was EXCELLENT. It was delivered between 11 pm and 11:20 (fast for room service).The temperature was easily adjustable (contrary to other reviewers).The bed was yummily comfortable. The breakfast buffet is one of the best we have ever eaten with thought given to how they served what they served.Little things...We couldn't bring toothpaste/deodorant...Rather than buy at the gift shop we asked directions for a local drug store. The polite valet suggested we ask the front desk and they gave us his/hers...Then toothpaste, shave cream...When I needed my boarding pass printed I went to the front desk for access to the business center. She said she could do it there but I thought it would be too much of a hassle for them to so I declined.The fee for printing there was so high I went back and said okay heres how you log in...She did it in 2 minutes!Yes, the exterior is a little dated (but made up for in an oppulant lobby). The room wasn't huge but comfortable and clean.Bottom line is this: Would I stay again? YES!

Decent for the price We stayed here for one night after reviewing quite a few hotels in this area of Dallas. Our experience was quite positive. Helpful friendly staff at the reception desk. Our room was large, with a very comfortable bed and very clean. It is clear that rennovation money was spent on the rooms (rather than halls and elevator) but since the room is where we spent the most time - this worked for us. AAA rate was quite reasonable.

Okay service, dirty rooms, internet hackers in the business cetner I stayed at this hotel with some colleagues for a business trip. I booked three single rooms with king sized beds, when I got to my room, there were two beds. But when I went downstairs to complain, the man at the front desk said since I booked through Expedia, they don't guarantee rooms.The room was okay, I was somewhat annoyed because there was what looked to be a food stain on the duster of the bed. A little gross.The breakfast was okay, the table dirty and the service was slow.When I checked out, I asked for a receipt, they couldn't give me one saying that since I booked through Expedia, they don't know how much I paid. This would have been fine but the woman at the front desk was outright RUDE.Lastly, when I got home, I noticed some weird things going on with my credit card. Turns out someone hacked my account and added themselves as an authorized user. The only way I can think this happened is someone either was watching or hacked my account when I was in the business center. There were some shady characters there, and I know not to look up financial information at hotels.Overall, no major issues but enough minor ones to make the stay unpleasant.

Hotel Staff Let In A Burglar to My Room! Warning - this hotel has HORRIBLE security practices.I stayed at this property 9/11-9/14 and, as a Starwood Platinum guest, was given a nice room on the club floor. However, I came back from work to find my Ipod, Bose Headset, and two sets of keys missing!After digging around, it turns out the housekeeping staff admitted to letting a stranger with no ID into my room. There didn't even bother telling me until I reported the crime to the police.After 8 calls to Starwood -and many promises up and down the chain - a week has gone by and I am still waiting on them to provide me a form to submit a claim. Not only was the hotel negligent - they are totally inconsiderate. How hard is it to send out an insurance form???NEVER STAY HERE. EVER.

Nice Hotel We booked a room with Prava Suites through Hotwire and were moved to this hotel. This is a nice hotel, with a new remodel. Rooms are comfy and updated with flat screens and Starbucks coffee too. The only problem we had was not getting our room cleaned the second night. The lady asked if we wanted our room cleaned, and we said yes, and we would be leaving soon, only to come back late that night to a dirty room. Hotel staff was not too concerned either. Who knows maybe the lady didn't understand English??Happy Travels!!

Needs some work This hotel has the potential to be a very nice hotel but seems to have stopped trying. The hot tub was out, the pool area is very stark and would benefit from some plants, the women's restroom at the pool area was out of order, ice machine on our floor was broke...Room was nice enough except for the ancient pepperoni we found on the floor by the drapes. None of these things would matter alone, but all together show a lack of attention to detail and customer care.The worst was the driver who took us to the Galleria Mall in the hotel shuttle. He crammed more people in the van than there was seat belts for. He did not wear a seatbelt. He had the radio set to an offensive rap station full of explicit sexual language. And when I asked him how he was he replied in an annoyed tone Bored.The best was the rest of the hotel staff who were very friendly and helpful.Would I stay here again? Not for the money.

Club floor GREAT! We stayed at this hotel for a conference, and were on the Club floor. Beautiful, spacious rooms with great views. Recently renovated, and it looks it. I did see the hallway on a lower floor, and it wasn't as regal. Our floor and room were great, as was the suite used for our meetings. (The bartender was very unfriendly, be warned.)

Average business-class. Booked room through SPG, used points. Stayed here due to proximity to events in Dallas area, lesser points category. Hotel indeed renovated. Rooms appear new, with flat screen tv. Good.Renovation of common areas (hallways/elevators) not yet complete, I hope. Ambivalent.Speant little time. This hotel will be fine. Just woudn't recommend to a travelista or someone looking for Ritz-type experience (duh- It's a Sheraton!).

Very nice and comfortable hotel. It is obvious that this hotel has just had some upgrading done. The lobby is very nice and clean. The rooms have new furniture, still smells new. The beds are very comfortable. The guest services staff were all WONDERFUL and very helpful. I loved the shuttle amenity...it'll take you just about anywhere in Addison and pick you up when you are ready, they're pretty quick too. This was my favorite feature about the Sheraton!

Better than I expected I arrived at the hotel and was a little disappointed from the outside. The exterior looked old and unloved and the parking lot was a little scary. However, upon entering the room I was pleasantly surprised. I stayed on the 14th floor (labeled a Starwood Preferred Guest floor, which I am) and the room appeared to have been recently remodeled. Flat screen TV (although with only a couple dozen channels), Starbucks coffee, Bliss soaps and shampoo with a yummy mandarin mint scent, comfortable bed with fluffy white comforter. Very much on par with what I have seen from the newer Sheraton hotels. Good deal for the money ($162 with taxes on a weekday).
Worth the $40/night on Priceline       fitness center

Not what I expected Booked two rooms for three nights. Could not get one room with two double beds for any of the nights or even a roll away bed. I booked this through Priceline so that was probably one of the problems. The hotel could not accomodate us on anything. Do not know if this was due to us being priceline customers or the fact that they had a hotel full of youth soccer players who had free reign of the hotel. The continual running up and down the halls yelling and screaming did not add to the atmosphere. Rooms were fairly decent but seemed hollow. The doors were paper thin and being close to the elevator was a pain due to the constant flow of people all night. Having to listen to their loud conversations while trying to sleep was not pleasant. Only two of three elevators worked and the two that worked were extremely slow. My son called for a channel guide because there was not one in the room, the lobby sent one up. The next night my daughter in another room called for a channel guide and they made her go down and get it. I guess this place is hit or miss on the service and we definitely had a stay that was far from pleasant. We are not fussy people as were are a family with four kids and know traveling is never going to be perfect but this was not what we were expecting from a hotel of this supposed caliber. I am glad I did not pay the going advertised rates because I would have really been upset. Happy travels.
Awesome Hotel Stay       Room

brand new sheraton (sort of) stayed at the sheraton north dallas, which opened on jan 25th, last week. It was actually the wyndom galleria, but now it has new management. I actually booked the hotel thinking it was the wyndom, so it was a surprise when i drove up to a sheraton. With new owners, there are new furnishings, new carpet, etc... it feels like a new hotel. There is construction going on to redo the rooms. The worst noise though was the aircondition/heater turning on at night. Very very noisy. Also the highway could be heard (i 635 is right outside). The location was great...the galleria is a minute away (not close enough to walk, though). The staff was very friendly and kind. The internet connection was free, wireless, and very slow. no fridge or microwave. everything was clean.

Gone down hill We arrived on Christmas eve for 3 days. The T.V. was a joke. No schedule in room and none on TV. Asked desk for channel line-up and were told she didn't have any extras. Asked to have a copy of the master made and when she tried to do it the copy machine broke! Engineer came and said to try channel 17 and we found out we had NO channel 17!The gal on the front desk was new and alone. She tried but was lost.Ice machine was out of order.Cable was very limited and we had step through every number.Had used the Doubletree for years in Phoenix for business. This was not the chain I knew.

Hotel OK -- you can do better elsewhere My family used to stay at this hotel decades ago when I was a kid, but I hadn't stayed here in 25+ years. My husband and I stayed here for several days over a weekend. We were in town to see family and also were working during the trip, so we used the internet access. Overall, I wasn't impressed, and I will not stay here again. On the positive side, the front desk staff were nice, the hotel had been renovated fairly recently, Doubletree still gives out their famous chocolate chip cookies, and the location is convenient (right by Northpark and the freeway). The biggest negative was that we got stuck in a smoking room, despite having talked to them on the phone in advance and gotten their commitment to reserve a non-smoking room. When we arrived to check in, they said they they didn't have a record of that and no non-smoking rooms were available. So we were stuck; if we had walked out and gone elsewhere, we would have been stuck with the first night charge as a cancellation fee. So we sucked it up and stayed there. What I suspect happened, is that because they had a very large conference in the hotel that weekend (some kind of personal success tony robbins type thing) -- my guess is that the conference ended up wanting more rooms / more non-smoking rooms, and the hotel accommodated the conference people at the expense of those few of us at the hotel that weren't part of the conference. Which makes sense from a financial perspective, but it screwed up our stay. The non-smoking room had been cleaned of course, but it did smell quite musty -- and the worst part, when I got home, was realizing that all my clothes absolutely STANK of smoke. I'm not particular sensitive to smells -- but once out of the room, it was obvious how bad the air had been. I ended up washing, dry-cleaning, and airing out all clothes, shoes and luggage I'd taken on the trip to get rid of the smell. A minor annoyance is the internet fee. It's standard for a lot of upscale hotels (the Ritz Carltons of the world) -- but, most of the business hotels now (and all the discount hotels) offer internet as complimentary. So that additional $10-per-day ding is unnecessary and I was a little surprised that Doubletree was still charging it. We weren't bothered by the conference crowds, but then we didn't use any of the public areas (they did look pretty crowded when we walked through). Parking was a bit of a hassle. The hotel shares its parking with the two big office towers next door, which means parking during the week is crowded, and then parking at the weekend was crowded due to the conference. The main front-door lot isn't large enough, and the underground parking is a little confusing/badly signed, and creepy and isolated at night ( so if you're a female guest alone, you might be uncomfortable parking in the underground garage esp at night ). Bottom line: there are a lot of hotels within a few miles of this place -- you can get a better deal than this.

What an excelllent place I stayed at this Double Tree hotel 2 times. Both were wonderful . My retreat had a party at this Hotel. They give this delious cookie upon checkin. You just have to ask about and it is so soft and soooo good, but enough about that. The Room was clean  in excellent condition. I had extra towels all the time. When I needed something I just had to ask and it was there. The beds were changed daily.Their buffets are a little high priced for me, the food is ok. I did not mind the short walk to the food courts so I paid half of the price that buffet was.There are several places to go in walking are accross the street to the right. Also in the back toward the right. It is a very convient spot to stay.The only thng wrong was the cofee maker, I could not get it to work. The workers were really polite. The check out was swift and very easy. I would reccomend this to my mother, wait I alreay did and she loved it too.

GreatStay We went to Dallas to pick out a puppy from a breeder and just wanted a cheaper place to stay. We were very pleasantly surprised with this hotel. We got a corner room that had two walls of windows! It has an awesome view and with all the windows it almost felt like we were outside. The bed was extremely comfortable and the bathrooms very clean. They even gave us pipin hot cookies when we checked it. I imagine this place houses a lot of conventions, but there was none there when we went so it felt like we had the whole place to oursleves. We will for sure stay there again. I did not like that we had to pay for internet, but the corner room seriously made up for it!

Really good hotel; marginal location I was here, solo, for a three day set of meetings. I was fully pleased with the property.Check-in, and ensuing interaction with front desk, were all very positive, crisp and well-handled. I鈥檓 Hilton Gold, so was given a very nice corner room on an upper floor; floor-to-ceiling glass on two of the four walls- nice, even though the view was highway and office buildings. Room was certainly clean. Yes, yes, the bathroom had big stars on the wallpaper, and the hardware was in black metal鈥?this is Texas, and it was done in good taste. Bathroom also clean. The whole hotel had very solid wifi, and I was super happy about this.I must commend this property for the conference room we were in. Excellent food, frequent beverage refills, brand name stuff, and they responded to side requests very quickly. The restaurant was good, and that鈥檚 important鈥?because there is nothing (as previously reported) in walking distance. One day, they even had a separate table out in the lobby for quick sandwiches. Very smart, nice touch.There is a Starbucks about a football field distance from the hotel, and they opened at 5:30am while I was there.Good visit. I wouldn鈥檛 stay here as a base to tourist Dallas, but if you need to be in one of the adjacent office buildings, or have meetings here, it鈥檚 absolutely fine. (and chocolate chip cookies at check-in rock!)

Lovely lobby, good ambience The Doubletree at the Campbell Centre in Dallas has charm and character; values so often lacking in large hotels aimed at business travellers. The hotel boasts a framed collection of native American arrow heads and the lobby is decorated in a vibrant and tasteful way. There's a comedy club next door. I had a corner room with good views and high speed internet, while breakfast was hearty with a good range of choices. The staff seemed attentive and friendly and there was plenty of parking out front.

Watch your wallet! We stayed at this hotel while at a high school class reunion. It advertised free wireless internet access, but we found out that it's only free in the lobby, which can be noisy and crowded.If you want to use your laptop in your room, it will cost you $10 a day.And don't even think of using the phone to call anyone. Local calls are more than $6 each, though nothing in the hotel information gives the price. Heaven knows what long distance would be. We complained when we checked out and the manager said he would take $13 off our bill, paid by credit card. We'll be waiting to see if that actually happens! If not we'll protest the charge with the credit card company.Two Midwesterners

Good Hotel My stay at the Doubletree Hotel was for a conference. The hotel is located in what a friend of mine described as an 鈥渋sland d in a sea of freeways.鈥?Nestled between two office towers called the Campbell Centre I and II, the hotel is near the Northpark shopping mall. This upscale shopping mall is within walking distance of the hotel and there are several good restaurants located near the mall. However, there is no way to walk to any place close by due to the lack of sidewalks or pedestrian paths. The only way to get anywhere safely is by car, the hotel shuttle or a taxi. Be prepared to rely on your own wheels, a taxi, a shuttle or a friend鈥檚 car for getting around or risk being hit by a car trying to walk anywhere. If you do drive yourself, there is free outdoor parking in front of the hotel entrance. You can also use the free underground parking directly under the hotel. Ask at the front desk when you check in about it and they will give you the access code for gaining entry and exit. There is an elevator you that will take directly from the underground parking garage directly to your hotel room floor. At check-in the staff at the front desk was very friendly and they give out free fresh baked cookies in the afternoons. The front desk was very good about answering questions and making suggestions for dinner and lining up transportation via the hotel shuttle. The rooms appear to be recently remodeled and were clean. The beds were comfortable and they were fitted with down comforters and down pillows. My bathroom was papered with large stars, for the Lone Star State, somewhat overwhelming. The bathroom amenities consisted of face and bath soap, shampoo, conditioner, body lotion, and a small tube of face cream, all Neutrogena products. Be aware that the water from the tap is not pleasant to drink. However, the hotel doesn鈥檛 miss a beat and provides a large bottle of water on the dresser for $4.00. You might want to consider going to the convenience store next to the hotel or the Bay Street Deli next-door for cheaper bottled water. See my notes below for locations of these places. All the rooms have floor to ceiling windows with good views. I was located on the 4th floor. During the time I stayed here a winter storm arrived with rain and cold. Upon arrival my windows were covered with condensation and there were puddles of water on the floor window ledge. A leak in the window created a constant drip. When the rain stopped the condensation went away as well as the drip. The heating and cooling system worked well, but the room had a slight musty odor that must have been due to the high humidity in the room. The windows could not be opened, so there was no way to get any outside fresh air into the room. During my stay housekeeping was prompted, but they didn鈥檛 seem to do a good job of vacuuming the room each day. They also didn鈥檛 leave an extra roll of toilet paper, so if you arrive and it is low, ask for more.The hotel has a workout room and an outside running/walking area on the 2nd floor. The equipment was a good variety, high tech, some with individual TVs and included treadmills, bikes, weight machine, free weights and best of all a really clean exercise room! I didn't check out the pool. The hotel also has an agreement with local nearby gym that you can use for $15 a day. You can try to walk the short distance to the gym, but I would suggest that you use the hotel shuttle to get there or risk being run over by the local traffic. Room service was prompt, but the prices, were a bit high. They also charge an additional 21% for a room services tip and a $2.00 service fee in addition to the regular sales tax. A bowl of soup, $4 on the menu ran to almost $7 with the add-ons. The restaurant food, which is also the room service vendor, was good and the selection was adequate. However, if you don鈥檛 want to spend a lot there is place called the Bay Street Deli that is located just off the hotel lobby near the restaurant in one of the Campbell Center buildings which are connected to the hotel. The Deli served a quick hot breakfast, hot lunch and sandwiches. To get there go past the hotel restaurant and gift shop, up the stairs, through the double glass doors and into the Campbell Center building. You will see it on the right as you walk down that hallway. The prices there are very reasonable; I paid $5 for a large two enchilada meal with pinto beans and coleslaw. This was not a simple quick dish, it really tasted like something you would get a good Mexican restaurant. The Deli is not associated with the hotel. There is also a bar lounge that is open to the lobby, just across from the hotel restaurant. The lounge opens into an area that is also a library of books that you can take to read. There are hundreds of hardback books available with a variety of titles. It is on the honor system to return them.The conference rooms were well lighted. The room we were in was somewhat cool, but when requested the hotel staff was able to elevate the temperature to a decent level. The noise level from another conference, across the wall divider from our conference, at times was annoying. There is light rail train that you can take to downtown Dallas and areas north of the hotel. This light rail train runs right by the hotel. Unfortunately, you have to take the hotel shuttle to the train station down the road a ways as the train does not stop at the hotel.If you do need to visit a convenience store there is one located just next to the hotel on the east side. To get there safely you will need to go through the underground parking garage and walk out the east entrance drive, across the light rail tracks and into the convenience store parking lot. Again, there are no sidewalks, so be careful. Not the greatest place to be stranded for a week, but it was pleasant and I would come back.

Is this a hotel or a disco? I posted a review a couple of months ago about how much we enjoyed this hotel. I wish I could say the same about our most recent stay but that is just not the case. This was probably our worst hotel stay ever and I don't know if I can go back to see if they 'break the tie' and redeem themselves by staying another time. When we arrived at the Doubletree we were pleased to get a great room on the 20th floor. We left for dinner and when we returned there was a band playing on the 21st floor that was incredibly loud - it sounded like we were in a disco. The bass was so loud it sent ripples through the bottled water on the nightstand. We called down to the front desk and were assured that the party would end at 10. So we figured we'd watch a little tv and wait until it ended. 10:30 came and the band was still going strong. We called downstairs again and the assured us that by 11 they would wrap it up and be done but if we wanted to change rooms they would move us. Since I was already unpacked and in bed I didn't want to move so we decided to tough it out another half hour. At 11:15 I called again - band still going strong and we were told the manager was on the way upstairs because they'd had complaints to the 16th floor. At 10 past midnight we called downstairs AGAIN and were told that it is a birthday party and they paid for the room until 1 am so the band might play that long. I threw on some clothes and went down to the front desk where two morons who were not at all apologetic and told me they could do nothing about the noise but would move us (reluctantly) to another room. We went back to the room, packed all of our stuff and MOVED in the middle of the night to the 5th floor. We called the Hilton Diamond line 4 times in the midst of all of this and they told us they called the manager of the property but there was nothing they could do. When we finally got to our new room we could still hear the bass pounding away all the way down to the 5th floor but finally got some sleep. The next morning we went down and asked to speak with the manager who was too busy to see us. We have 260 Hilton nights in the last 12 months and this is the WORST Hilton property we've had in all of that time. We have loved this hotel in the past and are terribly disappointed in the lack of interest on the part of the staff and management at this hotel. They could care less that the ridiculous planning that would allow a party with a loud band to hold the hotel hostage until 1 am would make the rest of their guests very unhappy.Bottom line is if a facility wants to book parties that go on to the wee hours be a nightclub - if you want to be a HOTEL where people SLEEP shut the music down at 10. But you can not do both. We have contacted Hilton corporate about this complaint and would encourage others to do so also if they have a similar issue.

Ghastly, Horrible, Filthy hotel - Stay away !! I stayed at this hotel 3 weeks ago and it was a disaster. They are claiming that the room they gave me is newly-renovated. Renovated??Hello???! The room was horrible! The furniture are tacky. They are uncomfortable, disgusting and cheap-looking. Also, the room was not properly cleaned - there are hairs in the bathroom. The breakfast area was filthy! The parking area (basement) was sickening- it's flooded with water!  What a waste of money!! I should have just stayed in a Motel 6 - they are much better than this hotel!  I defnitely would never come back at this one - even if they pay me!

Terrible Decision I was booked in this hotel for three nights, but could only take it for one. I agree with another reviewer that this hotel does not meet Hilton standards and I cannot understand how it can have an 鈥淓mbassy Suites鈥?sign on the front. I arrived very late and entered my room which was reeked of stale cigarette smoke, moisture problems, and disinfectant. It was a non-smoking room. The room d茅cor and fixtures were in serious need of updating, adding to the dingy feel already created by the dim lighting and yellowed ceiling from years of tobacco smoke.The sheets on the bed were old and thin, and the pillows were in bad need of replacement.The good news: There appear to be renovations taking place, so if you end up going to this hotel is may be worth asking for an updated room at check in. I was so turned off I found another hotel.

Horrible Hotel I booked this hotel on the Hilton website assuming this was up to Hilton standards. This was not even up to Motel 6 standards. The room smelled of disinfectant, the heating/air conditioning system was loud, the control impossible to manipulate, resulting in swings of temperature from hot to cold. The fan in the bathroom was so noisy it was better to bathe in the dark. The wireless internet would not work. When reported to the front desk, I was treated more rudely than I have been in many years. We originally booked a two night stay and left after one horrible night. Hilton should be ashamed.

Horrible!!!!!!!!!!! Cant believe this is a Embasy Suites Hotel! This hotel is in HORRIBLE shape! There was blood on the walls, the TV had speakers that were blown and you couldnt change the volume to even turn it down. They replaced the TV with another piece of junk TV. I stay in the Embassy suites on purpose but I wont anymore. I told Hilton about my experience and all I got was a cheesy generic email saying I was already contacted and I WAS NOT CONTACTED. My belongings were stolen from the room, the elevators were broken, there were a lot of angry people staying there, it was HORRIBLE

OK for business travellers. The room I got was OK. It is standard suite from an Embassy Suites. The hotel is generally clean except the underground garage, which is a little too smelly and dirty for me. It is located at the intersection of major freeways so the noise is a given. But I slept OK.Some of things inside need major improvement. Like their gym, pool, furniture. They are just TOO old.We had to venture out to get a good meal. They are quite a few good restaurants around. The one inside the hotel is just mediocre.In general it is all right. But don't expect it to Wow you.

Good But Not The Best The hotel was alright. When we arrived to our room it was beautiful!!! What a sight but what a noise. The train was below our room and it was very noisy. All night we listened to the horn blowing. Next morning when we woke up there was a leak coming from the vent. We had to switch rooms and the next one we were in was very dusty and still had the trains noise. It was still nice though. The food was great and there was a great staff!! I would go back only if I had to.
Big Convention Hotel and Impersonal       View from West End

Here for a conference I stayed at the Hyatt when attending very large conference held there. We arrived at the Hyatt Regency by cab. The front desk staff was friendly and helpful. I was assigned to a room with 2 double beds in the Reunion Tower. The lobby level is large and beautiful, but it was somewhat confusing to navigate. There is a very expensive coffee/snack shop and gift shop with very limited seating. The elevators were essentially efficient. I never waited longer than 2-3 minutes, even during busy times.My room was clean and comfortable. The bedding was luxurious! There was a small closet with an ironing board and iron. The TV was a decent size but I didn't much of a chance to watch it. The bathroom was also very nice. They provided plenty of towels and toiletries. My only complaint about the room was the lack of electrical outlets. I needed to plug in my laptop and cell phone chargers, and I found only 2 outlets and they were very difficult to reach.We did not eat in any of the hotel's restaraunts, but they looked nice. We did enjoy cocktails at the second floor bar, and we found the prices reasonable and the service adequate.Overall, I enjoyed this hotel and had a good experience.

As expected. The Dallas Grand Hyatt is about what I expected from a large city Hyatt. I did not find any of the negativity expressed in other reviews (kids, noise etc.). The food is expensive, as is food in all major hotels in major cities.Rooms were clean, staff friendly and beds very comfortable. Kennedy Book Repository museum walkable and train station very close.Was there for a meeting and the hotel proved a nice venue.

Nice Hotel if on business at the convention Stayed here while exhibiting at a convention. It is about the closest hotel to the convention center (3 blocks) and reunion arena (next door) that you will find.Overall the rooms were very well kept and the service from the staff right up with any top notch hotel. Had a couple meals at the Centennial Diner and they were very good. Prices are a little higher than probably warranted, but still a good meal.Be aware that this hotel is not the easiest to get to in Dallas. In fact, downtown dallas is somewhat hard to drive within. It took me 30 minutes to get back to the hotel at night. I was only 1.5 miles from it, but very confusing to drive.I would stay here again on business, but would not for recreation.

The Superdome? This is a really nice hotel, with a nice staff. They just attract a client base that reminded me of the Superdome after a hurricane.If you travel in cargo shorts and flip-flops, sporting your newest tattoos and an unlimited supply of cigarettes. This is your Graceland. The staff is very tolerant of this business model. I assume since there are so many rooms they always have vacancy so they just fill it up with large groups and anyone walking down the street.I would not pay the rates they advertise, if you use priceline they are always the buyer of a cheap fair, and it shows.

biggest raping my wallet ever suffered The bed, linens, furniture and decor was beautiful with down comforter and pillows, The service was okay, but the cost what horrible. The room was medium sized and because we were here for a huge conference, there were no discounts, so the room was $145 per night for a king. There was no microwave, refrigerator or any other common convenience, but the coffee could be purchased downstairs and the cost rivaled Starbucks but the flavor didn't. The lamps were equivalent to a mid 80s motel except with fluorescent bulbs. Valet parking is $20 per night, and the internet is a whopping $10 for 24 hours. Oh and our key cards for the room were decoded twice in 3 days. This place was a massive expenditure and ruined an otherwise wonderful weekend.

Great location Very nice, clean hotel. Restaurants way too expensive for the average family (about $13 for an average breakfast plate). Would recommend the Corner Bakery several blocks away for breakfast. Bar is also very expensive, $8.50 for a simple whiskey and 7-up. Extremely small pool for the size of the hotel, not many deck chairs. Requested frig 3 weeks in advance, none available on check-in, told it was first come, first served even if it was reserved. Finally got a frig. Very polite staff, although housekeeping knocked on the door at 830 AM. Great location, walking distance to at least 3 museums, the JFK 6th floor museum in the Dallas School Book Depository Building is a must-see. Lobby seating very limited, we were there for volleyball, not many places for team members to hang out together. One last tip, don't drink the $4.50 bottle of water in the room!

Overrun by screaming 13 year olds Wow - DO NOT STAY HERE if you want to sleep. If you are interested in roaming bands of hundreds of unsupervised screaming children, apparently this is the place for you. There's really not much for kids at the hotel or in the area, so they were just chasing each other all over the hotel and joyriding in the elevators with the hotel staff doing nothing about it. Multiple times I waited over 20 minutes to get on an elevator along with a lot of annoyed adults. A group of kids would show up and literally push people out of the way to get on an elevator. I pointed out the  100 or so people waiting on an elevator to the front desk staff and they suggested I go up to the 2nd floor and try to get on there. Another 100 people were waiting for the elevators on the 2nd floor. I went back down and asked where the stairs are - to my room on the 12th floor.The atrium area echoes sound so badly that the sound of the bar, restaurant, and lobby (oh and don't forget all the screaming kids) is amplified and very loud inside the rooms, even with towels shoved under the door and the tv on. I'm not saying the hotel should be supervising other peoples kids, but if they book kids dance competitions and volleyball tournaments and allow children to stay in rooms together without an adult, then they created this situation and should take the responsibility to deal with the result. Clearly Hyatt was not prepared for the situation they created, or is not interested in maintaining their reputation with business customers - or adults in general, for that matter.Other than that, the rooms were ok, although becoming a bit worn (peeling paint, torn wallpaper, scuffed furniture, stains) and it doesn't look like they are properly maintaining this hotel. Most likely their business has fallen off due to Reunion arena and renovating reunion tower and this is the result.On the positive side, the valet staff was great and very friendly. The (Parrinos?) restaurant was surprisingly very good.I got this room for $60 on priceline - so beware on priceline - if you bid on a 4 star hotel downtown, you are most likely to get the hyatt. Check expedia - I stayed at the Adolphus and Stoneleigh previous weeks for ~130/night booking through expedia. The extra money is definitely worth being able to sleep and not having to take the stairs 12 flights to your room.Unless you are a screaming 13 year old and want to spend the night joyriding in hotel elevators, I suggest you not stay here.
Big Hotel - Great Stay Business Trip - Food was great and room was great also!Business Hotel all the way.

Thrown out by the Maid!!! Everything went well right up to the morning of check out. We were there for our anniversary. The desk staff was efficient on check in and the valet parking was one of the most professional I've ever experienced. They were delivering cars in under 2 min! Wow.. can't say enough good about the valet parking employees. The wait staff in the bar was cordial and prompt. The problem.. THE PROBLEM.. was the maid.. the morning of our last day she is banging on the door at 8:22am.. BANGING ON THE DOOR .. when we finally wake up enough to put on clothes and peak out the door to see who it is.. (she is shouting through the door as well.. Hey.. Hello' wake up!! ) I am not kidding.. I have never been treated like this in any hotel.. When we open the door.. she says literally.. 'WHEN YOU LEAVE???... She wants us to hurry up and leave so she can clean the room.. I told her check out was at noon and we were in no hurry. Of course after being so rudely treated and mad we couldn't go back to sleep so we showered and got the hell out of there.. we were gone by 9am.. If Hyatt needs their rooms so badly.. we can do them even better.. We'll never stay in another one of their rooms.

Great View We had an average sized room with a great view of the city from the 22nd floor. I love Hyatt's beds - great linens and down duvet. A small refrigerator, and coffee maker were in the room. The pool looked very small and the water was murky so we didn't get in. Other Hyatt's we have stayed in have a sauna or steam room but this one did not. The restaurant we tried at the hotel had the exact same menu as the room service menu (including the same high prices - $20 for a chicken fried steak). All in all we enjoyed our stay and would return to this hotel.

Noisiest hotel ever. Avoid like the plague! I stayed in an atrium room. There is a sports bar in the atrium which is incredibly noisy, even at 1 AM, and the noise carries straight through the door. If you cannot get a non-atrium room-- especially if you'll be here on a weekend night-- you should find some other hotel. We are talking about serious noise here. I am not super sensitive-- I live directly next to the Bay Bridge in San Francisco-- but this is loud and disturbing, clanking of glasses, shouting, etc., and it's still going at 1 AM. The front desk people were nice about it, and managed to find me earplugs once I insisted and talked to the manager, and they took off most of my internet charges, but it doesn't make up for an intolerable room.

Fine hotel; horrible pool All you could expect from a Hyatt of this size; great convention hotel. Nice bar, snack area, etc. Rooms are nice (especially since I got it for $55 on price line!)However, we were extremely dissapointed in the pool! For a hotel of this size, I would have expected a MUCH larger pool. I've been in private backyards with larger pools. My kids were totally bummed and had to check it out 2 different times throughout the day b4 there was enough room for them to even get in. There are also very few deck chairs, so if you are looking to just lay out and get some fresh air, you might be sitting on the deck.Valet is $20 for 24hrs with in/out privileges. The park it yourself option is $10 with no in/out.
All that you expect from a Hyatt       The hotel

Wouldn't be my first chocie for a family vacation I stayed at the Hyatt for 4 nights in May. Check-in was a breeze and overall I didn鈥檛 have any problems with the room. The room was a good size and was clean. The Hyatt had a note in my room that said if you use your 鈥淧rivacy Please鈥?sign then the maids won鈥檛 change you room at all. I used this sign so I could leave my laptop setup when I was out of my room and to their credit the maids didn鈥檛 enter my room at all over the 4 days I was there (I left the sign out the whole time). I鈥檝e been to other hotels where they pretty much just ignore the sign and the maids enter at 8:00am anyway. I have different observations if you鈥檙e a business traveler versus a family traveling on vacation. I鈥檒l start with a quick tip for business travelers. I was traveling on business and high-speed internet is always key for me. I ended up on the 6th floor in a room pretty far away from the lobby area. When I connected to the hotels high-speed internet service via wi-fi (the only option possible in my room) the signal I got was very low. A number of times my connection would just drop when I was connected for even a short time. I asked at the front desk regarding what could be done and they gave me a device (they called it a booster) which plugged into my laptop and that did the trick.
